[Mrs. van der Luyden]297-mrs. van der luyden still wore black velvet and Venetian point when [she]297-mrs. van der luyden went into society -- or rather ( since [she]297-mrs. van der luyden never dined out ) when [she]297-mrs. van der luyden threw open [her]297-mrs. van der luyden own doors to receive it . [Her]297-mrs. van der luyden fair hair , which had faded without turning grey , was still parted in flat overlapping points on [her]297-mrs. van der luyden forehead , and the straight nose that divided [her]297-mrs. van der luyden pale blue eyes was only a little more pinched about the nostrils than when the portrait had been painted . [She]297-mrs. van der luyden always , indeed , struck [Newland Archer]214-archer as having been rather gruesomely preserved in the airless atmosphere of a perfectly irreproachable existence , as bodies caught in glaciers keep for years a rosy life - in - death . Like all [[his]1141-his family]1142-his family , [he]1141-his esteemed and admired [Mrs. van der Luyden]297-mrs. van der luyden ; but [he]1141-his found [her]297-mrs. van der luyden gentle bending sweetness less approachable than the grimness of [some of [[his]1141-his mother 's old aunts]1144-his mother 's old aunts]1143-some of his mother 's old aunts , [fierce spinsters who said " No "[297-mrs. van der luyden] on principle before [they]1143-some of his mother 's old aunts knew what [they]1143-some of his mother 's old aunts were going to be asked]1145-fierce spinsters who said " no " on principle before they knew what they were going to be asked . [Mrs. van der Luyden]297-mrs. van der luyden 's attitude said neither yes nor no , but always appeared to incline to clemency till [her]297-mrs. van der luyden thin lips , wavering into the shadow of a smile , made the almost invariable reply : " [I]297-mrs. van der luyden shall first have to talk this over with [[my]297-mrs. van der luyden husband]3236-my husband . "[297-mrs. van der luyden] [She]297-mrs. van der luyden and [Mr. van der Luyden]304-mr. van der luyden were so exactly alike that [Archer]214-archer often wondered how , after forty years of the closest conjugality , two such merged identities ever separated [themselves]1146-themselves enough for anything as controversial as a talking - over . But as [neither]1147-neither had ever reached a decision without prefacing it by [this mysterious conclave]1148-this mysterious conclave , [Mrs. Archer]214-archer and [[her]214-archer son]666-her son , having set forth [their]1146-themselves case , waited resignedly for the familiar phrase . [Mrs. van der Luyden]297-mrs. van der luyden , however , who had seldom surprised [any one]1150-any one , now surprised [them]1146-themselves by reaching [her]297-mrs. van der luyden long hand toward the bell - rope . " [I]297-mrs. van der luyden think , "[297-mrs. van der luyden] [she]297-mrs. van der luyden said , " [I]297-mrs. van der luyden should like [Henry]297-mrs. van der luyden to hear what [you]666-her son have told [me]297-mrs. van der luyden . "[297-mrs. van der luyden] [A footman]1151-a footman appeared , to whom [she]297-mrs. van der luyden gravely added : " If [Mr. van der Luyden]304-mr. van der luyden has finished reading the newspaper , please ask [him]1151-a footman to be kind enough to come . "[297-mrs. van der luyden] [She]297-mrs. van der luyden said " reading the newspaper "[297-mrs. van der luyden] in the tone in which [[a Minister]1152-a minister 's wife]1153-a minister 's wife might have said : " Presiding at a Cabinet meeting"--not[297-mrs. van der luyden] from any arrogance of mind , but because the habit of a life - time , and the attitude of [[her]297-mrs. van der luyden friends]740-her friends and [relations]1155-relations , had led [her]297-mrs. van der luyden to consider [Mr. van der Luyden]304-mr. van der luyden 's least gesture as having an almost sacerdotal importance . [Her]297-mrs. van der luyden promptness of action showed that [she]297-mrs. van der luyden considered the case as pressing as [Mrs. Archer]214-archer ; but , lest [she]297-mrs. van der luyden should be thought to have committed [herself]297-mrs. van der luyden in advance , [she]297-mrs. van der luyden added , with the sweetest look : " [Henry]304-mr. van der luyden always enjoys seeing [you]214-archer , [dear Adeline]264-adeline ; and [he]304-mr. van der luyden will wish to congratulate [Newland]214-archer . "[297-mrs. van der luyden] The double doors had solemnly reopened and between [them]1156-them appeared [Mr. Henry van der Luyden]304-mr. van der luyden , tall , spare and frock - coated , with faded fair hair , a straight nose like [[his]304-mr. van der luyden wife]572-his wife 's and the same look of frozen gentleness in eyes that were merely pale grey instead of pale blue . " [I]304-mr. van der luyden had just finished reading the Times , "[304-mr. van der luyden] [he]304-mr. van der luyden said , laying [his]304-mr. van der luyden long finger - tips together . "[304-mr. van der luyden] " Ah , there 's a great deal to be said for that plan -- indeed [I]214-archer think [[my]214-archer uncle]3238-my uncle [Egmont]308-egmont used to say [he]308-egmont found it less agitating not to read the morning papers till after dinner , "[214-archer] said [Mrs. Archer]214-archer responsively . "[315-viii] [VIII]315-viii . It was generally agreed in [New York]2-new york that [the Countess Olenska]234-the countess olenska had " lost [her]234-the countess olenska looks . "[234-the countess olenska] [She]234-the countess olenska had appeared [there]732-there first , in [[Newland Archer]214-archer 's boyhood]1189-newland archer 's boyhood , as [a brilliantly pretty little girl of nine or ten]1190-a brilliantly pretty little girl of nine or ten , of whom [people]637-people said that [she]234-the countess olenska " ought to be painted . "[637-people] [[Her]234-the countess olenska parents]1025-her parents had been [continental wanderers]1193-continental wanderers , and after a roaming babyhood [she]234-the countess olenska had lost [them]1025-her parents both , and been taken in charge by [[her]234-the countess olenska aunt]1194-her aunt , [Medora Manson]229-medora manson , also [a wanderer , who was [herself]229-medora manson returning to [New York]2-new york to " settle down]3265-a wanderer , who was herself returning to new york to " settle down . "[229-medora manson] [Poor Medora]316-poor medora , repeatedly widowed , was always coming [home]649-home to settle down ( each time in [a less expensive house]1196-a less expensive house ) , and bringing with [her]229-medora manson [a new husband]1197-a new husband or [an adopted child]1198-an adopted child ; but after a few months [she]229-medora manson invariably parted from [[her]229-medora manson husband]663-her husband or quarrelled with [[her]229-medora manson ward]1200-her ward , and , having got rid of [[her]229-medora manson house]819-her house at a loss , set out again on [her]229-medora manson wanderings . As [[her]234-the countess olenska mother]605-her mother had been [a Rushworth]285-mrs. lefferts rushworth , and [her]234-the countess olenska last unhappy marriage had linked [her]234-the countess olenska to one of [the crazy Chiverses]1203-the crazy chiverses , [New York]2-new york looked indulgently on [her]234-the countess olenska eccentricities ; but when [she]234-the countess olenska returned with [[her]234-the countess olenska little orphaned niece]1204-her little orphaned niece , whose parents had been popular in spite of [their]1205-their regrettable taste for travel , [people]637-people thought it a pity that [the pretty child]1207-the pretty child should be in such hands . [Every one]653-every one was disposed to be kind to [little Ellen Mingott]260-ellen , though [her]234-the countess olenska dusky red cheeks and tight curls gave [her]234-the countess olenska an air of gaiety that seemed unsuitable in [a child who should still have been in black for [[her]234-the countess olenska parents]1025-her parents]1209-a child who should still have been in black for her parents . It was one of the misguided [Medora]229-medora manson 's many peculiarities to flout the unalterable rules that regulated American mourning , and when [she]234-the countess olenska stepped from the steamer [[her]234-the countess olenska family]1211-her family were scandalised to see that the crape veil [she]234-the countess olenska wore for [[her]234-the countess olenska own brother]1212-her own brother was seven inches shorter than those of [[her]234-the countess olenska sisters - in - law]1213-her sisters - in - law , while [little Ellen]260-ellen was in crimson merino and amber beads , like a gipsy foundling . But [New York]2-new york had so long resigned itself to [Medora]229-medora manson that [only a few old ladies]1214-only a few old ladies shook [their]1214-only a few old ladies heads over [Ellen]260-ellen 's gaudy clothes , while [[her]260-ellen other relations]1215-her other relations fell under the charm of [her]260-ellen high colour and high spirits . [She]260-ellen was a fearless and familiar little thing , who asked disconcerting questions , made precocious comments , and possessed outlandish arts , such as dancing a Spanish shawl dance and singing Neapolitan love - songs to a guitar . Under the direction of [[her]260-ellen aunt]1194-her aunt ( whose real name was [Mrs. Thorley Chivers]317-mrs. thorley chivers , but who , having received a Papal title , had resumed [[her]1194-her aunt first husband]1217-her first husband 's patronymic , and called [herself]1194-her aunt [the Marchioness Manson]318-the marchioness manson , because in [Italy]63-italy [she]1194-her aunt could turn it into [Manzoni]64-manzoni ) [the little girl]1218-the little girl received an expensive but incoherent education , which included " drawing from [the model]3266-the model , "[1194-her aunt] a thing never dreamed of before , and playing the piano in quintets with [professional musicians]1219-professional musicians . Of course no good could come of this ; and when , a few years later , [poor Chivers]317-mrs. thorley chivers finally died in [a madhouse]1220-a madhouse , [[his]1217-her first husband widow]1221-his widow ( draped in strange weeds ) again pulled up stakes and departed with [Ellen]260-ellen , who had grown into [a tall bony girl with conspicuous eyes]1222-a tall bony girl with conspicuous eyes . For some time no more was heard of [them]1223-them ; then news came of [Ellen]260-ellen 's marriage to [an immensely rich Polish nobleman of legendary fame , whom [she]260-ellen had met at a ball at [the Tuileries]26-the tuileries]1224-an immensely rich polish nobleman of legendary fame , whom she had met at a ball at the tuileries , and who was said to have [princely establishments in [Paris]3-paris , [Nice]21-nice and [Florence]65-florence]1225-princely establishments in paris , nice and florence , [a yacht at [Cowes]66-cowes , and many square miles of shooting in [Transylvania]67-transylvania]1226-a yacht at cowes , and many square miles of shooting in transylvania . [She]260-ellen disappeared in a kind of sulphurous apotheosis , and when a few years later [Medora]229-medora manson again came back to [New York]2-new york , subdued , impoverished , mourning [a third husband]1227-a third husband , and in quest of [a still smaller house]1228-a still smaller house , [people]637-people wondered that [[her]229-medora manson rich niece]1230-her rich niece had not been able to do something for [her]229-medora manson . Then came the news that [Ellen]260-ellen 's own marriage had ended in disaster , and that [she]260-ellen was [herself]260-ellen returning [home]649-home to seek rest and oblivion among [[her]260-ellen kinsfolk]1232-her kinsfolk . These things passed through [Newland Archer]214-archer 's mind a week later as [he]1233-he watched [the Countess Olenska]234-the countess olenska enter [the van der Luyden drawing - room]1234-the van der luyden drawing - room on the evening of the momentous dinner . The occasion was a solemn one , and [he]1233-he wondered a little nervously how [she]234-the countess olenska would carry it off . [She]234-the countess olenska came rather late , one hand still ungloved , and fastening a bracelet about [her]234-the countess olenska wrist ; yet [she]234-the countess olenska entered without any appearance of haste or embarrassment [the drawing - room in which [New York]2-new york 's most chosen company]1235-the drawing - room in which new york 's most chosen company was somewhat awfully assembled . In the middle of [the room]991-the room [she]234-the countess olenska paused , looking about [her]234-the countess olenska with a grave mouth and smiling eyes ; and in that instant [Newland Archer]214-archer rejected the general verdict on [her]234-the countess olenska looks . It was true that [her]234-the countess olenska early radiance was gone . The red cheeks had paled ; [she]234-the countess olenska was thin , worn , a little older - looking than [her]234-the countess olenska age , which must have been nearly thirty . But there was about [her]234-the countess olenska the mysterious authority of beauty , a sureness in the carriage of the head , the movement of the eyes , which , without being in the least theatrical , struck [his]1233-he as highly trained and full of a conscious power . At the same time [she]234-the countess olenska was simpler in manner than [most of [the ladies present]1238-the ladies present]1237-most of the ladies present , and [many people]1239-many people ( as [he]1233-he heard afterward from [Janey]263-janey ) were disappointed that [her]234-the countess olenska appearance was not more " stylish"--for[1239-many people] stylishness was what [New York]2-new york most valued . It was , perhaps , [Archer]263-janey reflected , because [her]234-the countess olenska early vivacity had disappeared ; because [she]234-the countess olenska was so quiet -- quiet in [her]234-the countess olenska movements , [her]234-the countess olenska voice , and the tones of [her]234-the countess olenska low - pitched voice . [New York]2-new york had expected something a good deal more reasonant in [a young woman with such a history]1240-a young woman with such a history . The dinner was a somewhat formidable business . Dining with [the van der Luydens]275-the van der luydens was at best no light matter , and dining [there]732-there with [a Duke who was [[their]1243-they cousin]1183-their cousin]1242-a duke who was their cousin was almost a religious solemnity . It pleased [Archer]263-janey to think that [only an old New Yorker]1245-only an old new yorker could perceive the shade of difference ( to [New York]2-new york ) between being merely [a Duke]1246-a duke and being [[the van der Luydens]275-the van der luydens ' Duke]1247-the van der luydens ' duke . [New York]2-new york took [stray noblemen]1248-stray noblemen calmly , and even ( except in [the Struthers set ) with a certain distrustful hauteur]1249-the struthers set ) with a certain distrustful hauteur ; but when [they]1243-they presented such credentials as these [they]1243-they were received with an old - fashioned cordiality that [they]1243-they would have been greatly mistaken in ascribing solely to [their]1243-they standing in [Debrett]68-debrett . It was for just such distinctions that [the young man]527-the young man cherished [his]527-the young man old [New York]2-new york even while [he]527-the young man smiled at it . [The van der Luydens]275-the van der luydens had done [their]275-the van der luydens best to emphasise the importance of the occasion . The du Lac Sevres and the Trevenna George II plate were out ; so was [the van der [Luyden]498-dallas " Lowestoft "[297-mrs. van der luyden] ( [East India]70-east india [Company]71-company]69-the van der luyden " lowestoft " ( east india company ) and [the Dagonet Crown Derby]1251-the dagonet crown derby . [Mrs. van der Luyden]297-mrs. van der luyden looked more than ever like [a Cabanel]1252-a cabanel , and [Mrs. Archer]214-archer , in [[her]214-archer grandmother]853-her grandmother 's seed - pearls and emeralds , reminded [[her]214-archer son]666-her son of [an Isabey miniature]1255-an isabey miniature . All [the ladies]754-the ladies had on [their]754-the ladies handsomest jewels , but it was characteristic of [the house]532-the house and the occasion that these were mostly in rather heavy old - fashioned settings ; and [old Miss Lanning]319-old miss lanning , who had been persuaded to come , actually wore [[her]319-old miss lanning mother]605-her mother 's cameos and a Spanish blonde shawl . [The Countess Olenska]234-the countess olenska was [the only young woman at the dinner]1259-the only young woman at the dinner ; yet , as [Archer]214-archer scanned the smooth plump elderly faces between [their]754-the ladies diamond necklaces and towering ostrich feathers , [they]754-the ladies struck [him]666-her son as curiously immature compared with [hers]234-the countess olenska . [The Duke of [St. Austrey]343-st. austrey , who sat at [[his]1260-the duke of st. austrey , who sat at his hostess 's right hostess]1261-his hostess 's right]1260-the duke of st. austrey , who sat at his hostess 's right , was naturally [the chief figure of the evening]1262-the chief figure of the evening . Being [a well - bred man]1264-a well - bred man [he]1260-the duke of st. austrey , who sat at his hostess 's right had not ( like [another recent ducal visitor]1265-another recent ducal visitor ) come to the dinner in a shooting - jacket ; but [his]1260-the duke of st. austrey , who sat at his hostess 's right evening clothes were so shabby and baggy , and [he]1260-the duke of st. austrey , who sat at his hostess 's right wore them with such an air of [their]754-the ladies being homespun , that ( with [his]1260-the duke of st. austrey , who sat at his hostess 's right stooping way of sitting , and the vast beard spreading over [his]1260-the duke of st. austrey , who sat at his hostess 's right shirt - front ) [he]1260-the duke of st. austrey , who sat at his hostess 's right hardly gave the appearance of being in dinner attire . [He]1260-the duke of st. austrey , who sat at his hostess 's right was short , round - shouldered , sunburnt , with a thick nose , small eyes and a sociable smile ; but [he]1260-the duke of st. austrey , who sat at his hostess 's right seldom spoke , and when [he]1260-the duke of st. austrey , who sat at his hostess 's right did it was in such low tones that , despite the frequent silences of expectation about the table , [his]1260-the duke of st. austrey , who sat at his hostess 's right remarks were lost to all but [[his]1260-the duke of st. austrey , who sat at his hostess 's right neighbours]1266-his neighbours . [The two]797-the two chatted together for nearly twenty minutes ; then [the Countess]1272-the countess rose and , walking alone across [the wide drawing - room]1276-the wide drawing - room , sat down at [Newland Archer]214-archer 's side . It was not the custom in [[New York]2-new york drawing - rooms]1277-new york drawing - rooms for [a lady]698-a lady to get up and walk away from [one gentleman]1279-one gentleman in order to seek the company of another . Etiquette required that [she]1272-the countess should wait , immovable as [an idol]729-an idol , while [the men who wished to converse with [her]1272-the countess]1281-the men who wished to converse with her succeeded each other at [her]1272-the countess side . [The young man]527-the young man had spent an unsatisfactory day . [He]527-the young man had lunched with [the Wellands]1317-the wellands , hoping afterward to carry off [May]221-may for a walk in [the Park]1318-the park . [He]527-the young man wanted to have [her]221-may to [himself]527-the young man , to tell [her]221-may how enchanting [she]221-may had looked the night before , and how proud [he]527-the young man was of [her]221-may , and to press [her]221-may to hasten [their]1319-their marriage . But [Mrs. Welland]218-mrs. welland had firmly reminded [him]527-the young man that the round of family visits was not half over , and , when [he]527-the young man hinted at advancing the date of the wedding , had raised reproachful eye - brows and sighed out : " Twelve dozen of everything -- hand - embroidered-- "[527-the young man] Packed in [the family]551-the family landau [they]1321-they rolled from [one tribal doorstep]1322-one tribal doorstep to another , and [Archer]214-archer , when the afternoon 's round was over , parted from [[his]527-the young man betrothed]614-his betrothed with the feeling that [he]527-the young man had been shown off like a wild animal cunningly trapped . [He]527-the young man supposed that [his]527-the young man readings in anthropology caused [him]527-the young man to take such a coarse view of what was after all a simple and natural demonstration of family feeling ; but when [he]527-the young man remembered that [the Wellands]324-the wellands did not expect the wedding to take place till the following autumn , and pictured what [his]527-the young man life would be till then , a dampness fell upon [his]527-the young man spirit . " Tomorrow , "[218-mrs. welland] [Mrs. Welland]218-mrs. welland called after [him]527-the young man , " [we]1324-their 'll do [the Chiverses]286-the reggie chiverses and [the Dallases]327-the dallases "[218-mrs. welland] ; and [he]527-the young man perceived that [she]218-mrs. welland was going through [[their]1324-their two families]1325-their two families alphabetically , and that [they]1324-their were only in the first quarter of the alphabet . [He]527-the young man had meant to tell [May]221-may of [the Countess Olenska]234-the countess olenska 's request -- [her]218-mrs. welland command , rather -- that [he]527-the young man should call on [her]218-mrs. welland that afternoon ; but in the brief moments when [they]1324-their were alone [he]527-the young man had had more pressing things to say . Besides , it struck [him]527-the young man as a little absurd to allude to the matter . [He]527-the young man knew that [May]221-may most particularly wanted [him]527-the young man to be kind to [[her]221-may cousin]690-her cousin ; was it not that wish which had hastened the announcement of [their]1324-their engagement ? It gave [him]527-the young man an odd sensation to reflect that , but for [the Countess]1272-the countess 's arrival , [he]527-the young man might have been , if not still [a free man]1328-a free man , at least [a man less irrevocably pledged]1329-a man less irrevocably pledged . But [May]221-may had willed it so , and [he]527-the young man felt [himself]527-the young man somehow relieved of further responsibility -- and therefore at liberty , if [he]527-the young man chose , to call on [[her]221-may cousin]690-her cousin without telling [her]690-her cousin . As [he]527-the young man stood on [Madame Olenska]240-madame olenska 's threshold curiosity was [his]527-the young man uppermost feeling . [He]527-the young man was puzzled by the tone in which [she]240-madame olenska had summoned [him]527-the young man ; [he]527-the young man concluded that [she]240-madame olenska was less simple than [she]240-madame olenska seemed . The door was opened by [a swarthy foreign - looking maid]1331-a swarthy foreign - looking maid , with a prominent bosom under a gay neckerchief , whom [he]527-the young man vaguely fancied to be [Sicilian]328-sicilian . [She]1331-a swarthy foreign - looking maid welcomed [him]527-the young man with all [her]1331-a swarthy foreign - looking maid white teeth , and answering [his]527-the young man enquiries by a head - shake of incomprehension led [him]527-the young man through [the narrow hall]1332-the narrow hall into [a low firelit drawing - room]1333-a low firelit drawing - room . [The room]991-the room was empty , and [she]1331-a swarthy foreign - looking maid left [him]527-the young man , for an appreciable time , to wonder whether [she]1331-a swarthy foreign - looking maid had gone to find [[her]1331-a swarthy foreign - looking maid mistress]1335-her mistress , or whether [she]1331-a swarthy foreign - looking maid had not understood what [he]527-the young man was there for , and thought it might be to wind the clock -- of which [he]527-the young man perceived that the only visible specimen had stopped . [He]527-the young man knew that [the southern races]1336-the southern races communicated with each other in the language of pantomime , and was mortified to find [her]1331-a swarthy foreign - looking maid shrugs and smiles so unintelligible . At length [she]1331-a swarthy foreign - looking maid returned with a lamp ; and [Archer]214-archer , having meanwhile put together a phrase out of [Dante]329-dante and [Petrarch]330-petrarch , evoked the answer : " La signora e fuori ; ma verra subito "[214-archer] ; which [he]527-the young man took to mean : " [She]1331-a swarthy foreign - looking maid 's out -- but [you]3290-you 'll soon see . "[214-archer] What [he]527-the young man saw , meanwhile , with the help of the lamp , was the faded shadowy charm of [a room unlike [any room [he]527-the young man had known]1338-any room he had known]1337-a room unlike any room he had known . [He]527-the young man knew that [the Countess Olenska]234-the countess olenska had brought some of [her]234-the countess olenska possessions with [her]234-the countess olenska -- bits of wreckage , [she]234-the countess olenska called them -- and these , [he]527-the young man supposed , were represented by some small slender tables of dark wood , a delicate little Greek bronze on the chimney - piece , and a stretch of red damask nailed on the discoloured wallpaper behind a couple of Italian - looking pictures in old frames . [Newland Archer]214-archer prided [himself]527-the young man on [his]527-the young man knowledge of Italian art . [[His]527-the young man boyhood]876-his boyhood had been saturated with [Ruskin]331-ruskin , and [he]527-the young man had read all the latest books : [John Addington Symonds]332-john addington symonds , [Vernon Lee]333-vernon lee 's " [Euphorion]334-euphorion , "[527-the young man] the essays of [P. G. Hamerton]335-p. g. hamerton , and a wonderful new volume called " The Renaissance "[336-walter pater] by [Walter Pater]336-walter pater . [He]527-the young man talked easily of [Botticelli]337-botticelli , and spoke of [Fra Angelico]338-fra angelico with a faint condescension . But these pictures bewildered [him]527-the young man , for they were like nothing that [he]527-the young man was accustomed to look at ( and therefore able to see ) when [he]527-the young man travelled in [Italy]63-italy ; and perhaps , also , [his]527-the young man powers of observation were impaired by the oddness of finding [himself]527-the young man in [this strange empty house]1340-this strange empty house , where apparently [no one]619-no one expected [him]527-the young man . [He]527-the young man was sorry that [he]527-the young man had not told [May Welland]221-may of [Countess Olenska]234-the countess olenska 's request , and a little disturbed by the thought that [[his]527-the young man betrothed]614-his betrothed might come in to see [[her]614-his betrothed cousin]690-her cousin . What would [she]614-his betrothed think if [she]614-his betrothed found [him]527-the young man sitting there with the air of intimacy implied by waiting alone in the dusk at [[a lady]698-a lady 's fireside]1345-a lady 's fireside ? But since [he]527-the young man had come [he]527-the young man meant to wait ; and [he]527-the young man sank into a chair and stretched [his]527-the young man feet to the logs . It was odd to have summoned [him]527-the young man in that way , and then forgotten [him]527-the young man ; but [Archer]214-archer felt more curious than mortified . The atmosphere of [the room]991-the room was so different from any [he]527-the young man had ever breathed that self - consciousness vanished in the sense of adventure . [He]527-the young man had been before in [drawing - rooms hung with red damask]1347-drawing - rooms hung with red damask , with pictures " of [the Italian school]3291-the italian school "[229-medora manson] ; what struck [him]527-the young man was the way in which [[Medora Manson]229-medora manson 's shabby hired house]1348-medora manson 's shabby hired house , with [its]1348-medora manson 's shabby hired house blighted background of pampas grass and Rogers statuettes , had , by a turn of the hand , and the skilful use of [a few properties]1349-a few properties , been transformed into something intimate , " foreign , "[229-medora manson] subtly suggestive of old romantic scenes and sentiments . [He]527-the young man tried to analyse the trick , to find a clue to it in the way the chairs and tables were grouped , in the fact that only two Jacqueminot roses ( of which [nobody]3102-nobody ever bought less than a dozen ) had been placed in the slender vase at [his]527-the young man elbow , and in the vague pervading perfume that was not what [one]519-one put on handkerchiefs , but rather like the scent of [some far - off bazaar]1352-some far - off bazaar , a smell made up of Turkish coffee and ambergris and dried roses . [His]527-the young man mind wandered away to the question of what [[May]221-may 's drawing - room]1353-may 's drawing - room would look like . [He]527-the young man knew that [Mr. Welland]339-mr. welland , who was behaving " very handsomely , "[339-mr. welland] already had [his]339-mr. welland eye on [a newly built house in [East Thirty - ninth Street]75-east thirty - ninth street]1354-a newly built house in east thirty - ninth street . [The neighbourhood]1355-the neighbourhood was thought remote , and [the house]532-the house was built in a ghastly greenish - yellow stone that [the younger architects]1357-the younger architects were beginning to employ as a protest against the brownstone of which the uniform hue coated [New York]2-new york like a cold chocolate sauce ; but the plumbing was perfect . [Archer]214-archer would have liked to travel , to put off the housing question ; but , though [the Wellands]324-the wellands approved of an extended European honeymoon ( perhaps even a winter in [Egypt]76-egypt ) , [they]324-the wellands were firm as to the need of [a house for [the returning couple]1359-the returning couple]1358-a house for the returning couple . [The young man]527-the young man felt that [his]527-the young man fate was sealed : for the rest of [his]527-the young man life [he]527-the young man would go up every evening between the cast - iron railings of [that greenish - yellow doorstep]1361-that greenish - yellow doorstep , and pass through [a Pompeian vestibule]1362-a pompeian vestibule into [a hall]1363-a hall with a wainscoting of varnished yellow wood . But beyond that [his]527-the young man imagination could not travel . [He]527-the young man knew [the drawing - room above]1364-the drawing - room above had a bay window , but [he]527-the young man could not fancy how [May]221-may would deal with [it]1365-it . [She]221-may submitted cheerfully to the purple satin and yellow tuftings of [the Welland drawing - room]1366-the welland drawing - room , to [its]1366-the welland drawing - room sham Buhl tables and gilt vitrines full of modern Saxe . [He]527-the young man saw no reason to suppose that [she]221-may would want anything different in [[her]221-may own house]1367-her own house ; and [his]527-the young man only comfort was to reflect that [she]221-may would probably let [him]527-the young man arrange [[his]527-the young man library]1368-his library as [he]527-the young man pleased -- which would be , of course , with " sincere "[221-may] Eastlake furniture , and the plain new bookcases without glass doors . [The round - bosomed maid]1369-the round - bosomed maid came in , drew the curtains , pushed back a log , and said consolingly : " Verra -- verra . "[1369-the round - bosomed maid] When [she]1369-the round - bosomed maid had gone [Archer]214-archer stood up and began to wander about . Should [he]527-the young man wait any longer ? [His]527-the young man position was becoming rather foolish . Perhaps [he]527-the young man had misunderstood [Madame Olenska]240-madame olenska -- perhaps [she]221-may had not invited [him]527-the young man after all . Down the cobblestones of [the quiet street]1370-the quiet street came the ring of [a stepper]1371-a stepper 's hoofs ; [they]1372-they stopped before [the house]532-the house , and [he]527-the young man caught the opening of a carriage door . Parting the curtains [he]527-the young man looked out into the early dusk . [A street]1374-a street - lamp faced [him]527-the young man , and in [its]1374-a street light [he]527-the young man saw [Julius Beaufort]230-beaufort 's compact English brougham , drawn by a big roan , and [the banker]609-the banker descending from it , and helping out [Madame Olenska]240-madame olenska . [Beaufort]230-beaufort stood , hat in hand , saying something which [[his]527-the young man companion]1376-his companion seemed to negative ; then [they]1372-they shook hands , and [he]527-the young man jumped into [[his]527-the young man carriage]1377-his carriage while [she]1376-his companion mounted the steps . When [she]1376-his companion entered [the room]991-the room [she]1376-his companion showed no surprise at seeing [Archer]214-archer there ; surprise seemed the emotion that [she]1376-his companion was least addicted to . " [You]1376-his companion 've arranged it delightfully , "[527-the young man] [he]527-the young man rejoined , alive to the flatness of the words , but imprisoned in the conventional by [his]527-the young man consuming desire to be simple and striking . " [I]259-mrs. struthers ca n't put a name to [you]255-archer -- but [I]259-mrs. struthers 'm sure [I]259-mrs. struthers 've met [you]255-archer -- [I've]259-mrs. struthers met [everybody]604-everybody , here , or in [Paris]3-paris or [London]79-london . "[259-mrs. struthers] [The Duke]343-st. austrey said " Rather "[343-st. austrey] from the depths of [his]343-st. austrey beard , and [Archer]255-archer withdrew with a stiffly circular bow that made [him]255-archer feel as full of spine as [a self - conscious school - boy among [careless and unnoticing elders]1404-careless and unnoticing elders]1403-a self - conscious school - boy among careless and unnoticing elders . [He]255-archer was not sorry for the denouement of [his]255-archer visit : [he]255-archer only wished it had come sooner , and spared [him]255-archer a certain waste of emotion . As [he]255-archer went out into the wintry night , [New York]2-new york again became vast and imminent , and [May Welland]221-may [the loveliest woman in it]1405-the loveliest woman in it . [He]255-archer turned into [[his]255-archer florist]1406-his florist 's to send [her]221-may the daily box of lilies - of - [the - valley]558-the - valley which , to [his]255-archer confusion , [he]255-archer found [he]255-archer had forgotten that morning . As [he]255-archer wrote a word on [his]255-archer card and waited for an envelope [he]255-archer glanced about [the embowered shop]1408-the embowered shop , and [his]255-archer eye lit on a cluster of yellow roses . [He]255-archer had never seen any as sun - golden before , and [his]255-archer first impulse was to send them to [May]221-may instead of the lilies . But they did not look like [her]221-may -- there was something too rich , too strong , in their fiery beauty . In a sudden revulsion of mood , and almost without knowing what [he]255-archer did , [he]255-archer signed to [the florist]1409-the florist to lay the roses in another long box , and slipped [his]255-archer card into a second envelope , on which [he]255-archer wrote the name of [the Countess Olenska]234-the countess olenska ; then , just as [he]255-archer was turning away , [he]255-archer drew the card out again , and left the empty envelope on the box . " [They]3350-they 'll go at once ? "[255-archer] [he]255-archer enquired , pointing to the roses . [The florist]1409-the florist assured [him]255-archer that they would . [X.]345-x. The next day [he]255-archer persuaded [May]221-may to escape for a walk in [the Park]1318-the park after luncheon . As was the custom in old - fashioned Episcopalian [New York]2-new york , [she]221-may usually accompanied [[her]221-may parents]1025-her parents to [church]1413-church on Sunday afternoons ; but [Mrs. Welland]218-mrs. welland condoned [her]221-may truancy , having that very morning won [her]221-may over to the necessity of a long engagement , with time to prepare a hand - embroidered trousseau containing the proper number of dozens . The day was delectable . The bare vaulting of trees along [the Mall]1414-the mall was ceiled with lapis lazuli , and arched above snow that shone like splintered crystals . It was the weather to call out [May]221-may 's radiance , and [she]221-may burned like a young maple in the frost . [Archer]255-archer was proud of the glances turned on [her]221-may , and the simple joy of [possessorship]1415-possessorship cleared away [his]255-archer underlying perplexities . " It 's so delicious -- waking every morning to smell lilies - of - [the - valley]558-the - valley in [one 's room]3352-one 's room ! "[221-may] [she]221-may said . " Yesterday [they]3353-they came late . "[255-archer] It was the traditional maidenly interrogation , and [he]255-archer felt ashamed of [himself]255-archer for finding it singularly childish . Since [their]1500-them last meeting [he]255-archer had half - unconsciously collaborated with events in ridding [himself]255-archer of the burden of [Madame Olenska]240-madame olenska . To look at the matter in this light simplified [his]255-archer own case and surprisingly furbished up all the dim domestic virtues . [He]255-archer could not picture [May Welland]221-may , in whatever conceivable emergency , hawking about [her]1272-the countess private difficulties and lavishing [her]1272-the countess confidences on [strange men]3456-strange men ; and [she]1272-the countess had never seemed to [him]255-archer finer or fairer than in the week that followed . "[0-i] [You]1501-you know , when it comes to the point , [[your]1501-you parents]1502-your parents have always let [you]1501-you have [your]1501-you way ever since [you]1501-you were [a little girl]1503-a little girl , " [he]255-archer argued ; and [she]1272-the countess had answered , with [her]1272-the countess clearest look : "[1502-your parents] Yes ; and that 's what makes it so hard to refuse the very last thing [they]1502-your parents 'll ever ask of [me]0-i as [a little girl]1503-a little girl . " That was the old [New York]2-new york note ; that was the kind of answer [he]255-archer would like always to be sure of [[his]255-archer wife]572-his wife 's making . If one had habitually breathed the [New York]2-new york air there were times when anything less crystalline seemed stifling . The papers [he]255-archer had retired to read did not tell [him]255-archer much in fact ; but they plunged [him]255-archer into an atmosphere in which [he]255-archer choked and spluttered . They consisted mainly of an exchange of letters between [[Count Olenski]278-count olenski 's solicitors]3458-count olenski 's solicitors and [a French legal firm to whom [the Countess]1272-the countess had applied for the settlement of [her]1272-the countess financial situation]3459-a french legal firm to whom the countess had applied for the settlement of her financial situation . "[1502-your parents] Here are the letters , [sir]3197-sir . If [you]3197-sir wish , [I]0-i 'll see [Madame Olenska]240-madame olenska , " [he]255-archer said in a constrained voice . "[0-i] Thank [you]3197-sir -- thank [you]3197-sir , [Mr. Archer]255-archer . Come and dine with [me]0-i tonight if [you]3197-sir 're free , and [we]1506-we 'll go into the matter afterward : in case [you]3197-sir wish to call on [[our]1506-we client]1507-our client tomorrow . " [Newland Archer]214-archer walked straight [home]649-home again that afternoon . It was a winter evening of transparent clearness , with an innocent young moon above [the house - tops]3466-the house - tops ; and [he]255-archer wanted to fill [his]255-archer soul 's lungs with the pure radiance , and not exchange a word with [any one]1150-any one till [he]255-archer and [Mr. Letterblair]357-mr. letterblair were closeted together after dinner . It was impossible to decide otherwise than [he]255-archer had done : [he]255-archer must see [Madame Olenska]240-madame olenska [himself]255-archer rather than let [her]240-madame olenska secrets be bared to other eyes . A great wave of compassion had swept away [his]255-archer indifference and impatience : [she]240-madame olenska stood before [him]255-archer as an exposed and pitiful figure , to be saved at all costs from farther wounding [herself]240-madame olenska in [her]240-madame olenska mad plunges against fate . [He]255-archer remembered what [she]240-madame olenska had told [him]255-archer of [Mrs. Welland]218-mrs. welland 's request to be spared whatever was "[3197-sir] unpleasant " in [her]240-madame olenska history , and winced at the thought that it was perhaps this attitude of mind which kept the [New York]2-new york air so pure . "[1509-pharisees] Are [we]1508-we only [Pharisees]1509-pharisees after all ? " [he]255-archer wondered , puzzled by the effort to reconcile [his]255-archer instinctive disgust at human vileness with [his]255-archer equally instinctive pity for human frailty . For the first time [he]255-archer perceived how elementary [his]255-archer own principles had always been . [He]255-archer passed for [a young man who had not been afraid of risks]3468-a young man who had not been afraid of risks , and [he]255-archer knew that [his]255-archer secret love - affair with poor silly [Mrs. Thorley Rushworth]242-mrs. thorley rushworth had not been too secret to invest [him]255-archer with a becoming air of adventure . But [Mrs. Rushworth]242-mrs. thorley rushworth was "[1510-that kind of woman] [that kind of woman]1510-that kind of woman " ; foolish , vain , clandestine by nature , and far more attracted by the secrecy and peril of the affair than by such charms and qualities as [he]255-archer possessed . When the fact dawned on [him]255-archer it nearly broke [his]255-archer heart , but now it seemed the redeeming feature of the case . The affair , in short , had been of the kind that [most of [the young men of]3470-the young men of [his]255-archer age]3469-most of the young men of his age had been through , and emerged from with calm consciences and an undisturbed belief in the abysmal distinction between [the women [one loved and respected]3472-one loved and respected and those [one]519-one enjoyed -- and pitied]3471-the women one loved and respected and those one enjoyed -- and pitied . In this view [they]3470-the young men of were sedulously abetted by [[their]3470-the young men of mothers]3474-their mothers , [aunts]1034-aunts and [other elderly female relatives]3476-other elderly female relatives , who all shared [Mrs. Archer]214-archer 's belief that when "[1509-pharisees] such things happened " it was undoubtedly foolish of [the man]3477-the man , but somehow always criminal of [the woman]3156-the woman . [All the elderly ladies whom [Archer]214-archer knew]3479-all the elderly ladies whom archer knew regarded [any woman who loved imprudently]3480-any woman who loved imprudently as necessarily unscrupulous and designing , and [mere simple - minded man]3481-mere simple - minded man as powerless in [her]3156-the woman clutches . The only thing to do was to persuade [him]255-archer , as early as possible , to marry [a nice girl]3482-a nice girl , and then trust to [her]3482-a nice girl to look after [him]255-archer . In the complicated old European communities , [Archer]214-archer began to guess , love - problems might be less simple and less easily classified . [Rich and idle and ornamental societies]3483-rich and idle and ornamental societies must produce many more such situations ; and there might even be one in which [a woman naturally sensitive and aloof]3484-a woman naturally sensitive and aloof would yet , from the force of circumstances , from sheer defencelessness and loneliness , be drawn into a tie inexcusable by conventional standards . On reaching [home]649-home [he]255-archer wrote a line to [the Countess Olenska]234-the countess olenska , asking at what hour of the next day [she]234-the countess olenska could receive [him]255-archer , and despatched it by [a messenger - boy]3486-a messenger - boy , who returned presently with a word to the effect that [she]234-the countess olenska was going to [Skuytercliff]57-skuytercliff the next morning to stay over Sunday with [the van der Luydens]275-the van der luydens , but that [he]255-archer would find [her]234-the countess olenska alone that evening after dinner . The note was written on a rather untidy half - sheet , without date or address , but [her]234-the countess olenska hand was firm and free . [He]255-archer was amused at the idea of [her]234-the countess olenska week - ending in [the stately solitude of [Skuytercliff]57-skuytercliff]3487-the stately solitude of skuytercliff , but immediately afterward felt that there , of all places , [she]234-the countess olenska would most feel the chill of minds rigorously averted from the "[1509-pharisees] unpleasant . " [He]255-archer was at [Mr. Letterblair]357-mr. letterblair 's punctually at seven , glad of the pretext for excusing [himself]255-archer soon after dinner . [He]255-archer had formed [his]255-archer own opinion from the papers entrusted to [him]255-archer , and did not especially want to go into the matter with [[his]255-archer senior partner]3488-his senior partner . [Mr. Letterblair]357-mr. letterblair was [a widower]3489-a widower , and [they]3490-they dined alone , copiously and slowly , in [a dark shabby room]3491-a dark shabby room hung with yellowing prints of "[1509-pharisees] The Death of [Chatham]360-chatham " and "[1509-pharisees] The Coronation of [Napoleon]361-napoleon . " On the sideboard , between fluted Sheraton knife - cases , stood a decanter of [Haut Brion]362-haut brion , and another of the old Lanning port ( the gift of [a client]3492-a client ) , which [the wastrel Tom Lanning]363-the wastrel tom lanning had sold off a year or two before [his]363-the wastrel tom lanning mysterious and discreditable death in [San Francisco]80-san francisco -- an incident less publicly humiliating to [the family]551-the family than the sale of [the cellar]3494-the cellar . After a velvety oyster soup came shad and cucumbers , then a young broiled turkey with corn fritters , followed by a canvas - back with currant jelly and a celery mayonnaise . [Mr. Letterblair]357-mr. letterblair , who lunched on a sandwich and tea , dined deliberately and deeply , and insisted on [[his]357-mr. letterblair guest]3407-his guest 's doing the same . Finally , when the closing rites had been accomplished , the cloth was removed , cigars were lit , and [Mr. Letterblair]357-mr. letterblair , leaning back in [his]357-mr. letterblair chair and pushing the port westward , said , spreading [his]357-mr. letterblair back agreeably to the coal fire behind [him]357-mr. letterblair : "[361-napoleon] [The whole family]1511-the whole family are against a divorce . And [I]0-i think rightly . " [Archer]214-archer instantly felt [himself]214-archer on the other side of the argument . "[0-i] But why , [sir]3197-sir ? If there ever was a case-- " "[0-i] Well -- what 's the use ? [SHE]1513-her 'S here -- [he]1513-her 's there ; [the Atlantic]1514-the atlantic 's between [them]1515-them . [She]1513-her 'll never get back a dollar more of [her]1513-her money than what [he]1513-her 's voluntarily returned to [her]1513-her : [their]1515-them damned heathen marriage settlements take precious good care of that . As things go over there , [Olenski]278-count olenski 's acted generously : [he]1513-her might have turned [her]1513-her out without a penny . " [The young man]527-the young man knew this and was silent . "[1513-her] [I]0-i understand , though , " [Mr. Letterblair]357-mr. letterblair continued , "[1513-her] that [she]1513-her attaches no importance to the money . Therefore , as [the family]551-the family say , why not let well enough alone ? " [Archer]214-archer had gone to [the house]532-the house an hour earlier in full agreement with [Mr. Letterblair]357-mr. letterblair 's view ; but put into words by [this selfish , well - fed and supremely indifferent old man]3498-this selfish , well - fed and supremely indifferent old man it suddenly became the Pharisaic voice of a society wholly absorbed in barricading itself against the unpleasant . "[551-the family] [I]0-i think that 's for [her]1513-her to decide . " "[551-the family] H'm -- have [you]0-i considered the consequences if [she]1513-her decides for divorce ? " "[0-i] [You]0-i mean the threat in [[her]1513-her husband]663-her husband 's letter ? What weight would that carry ? It 's no more than the vague charge of [an angry blackguard]1518-an angry blackguard . " "[1518-an angry blackguard] Yes ; but it might make some unpleasant talk if [he]1513-her really defends the suit . " "[1513-her] Unpleasant-- ! " said [Archer]214-archer explosively . [Mr. Letterblair]357-mr. letterblair looked at [him]3498-this selfish , well - fed and supremely indifferent old man from under enquiring eyebrows , and [the young man]527-the young man , aware of the uselessness of trying to explain what was in [his]527-the young man mind , bowed acquiescently while [[his]527-the young man senior]3500-his senior continued : "[1513-her] Divorce is always unpleasant . " "[0-i] [You]0-i agree with [me]0-i ? " [Mr. Letterblair]357-mr. letterblair resumed , after a waiting silence . "[0-i] Naturally , " said [Archer]214-archer . "[0-i] Well , then , [I]0-i may count on [you]0-i ; [the Mingotts]226-the mingotts may count on [you]0-i ; to use [your]0-i influence against the idea ? " [Archer]214-archer hesitated . "[0-i] [I]0-i ca n't pledge [myself]0-i till [I]0-i 've seen [the Countess Olenska]234-the countess olenska , " [he]357-mr. letterblair said at length . "[255-archer] [Mr. Archer]255-archer , [I]0-i do n't understand [you]255-archer . Do [you]255-archer want to marry into [a family]1519-a family with a scandalous divorce - suit hanging over it ? " "[0-i] [I]0-i do n't think that has anything to do with the case . " [Mr. Letterblair]357-mr. letterblair put down [his]357-mr. letterblair glass of port and fixed on [[his]357-mr. letterblair young partner]3501-his young partner a cautious and apprehensive gaze . [Archer]255-archer understood that [he]255-archer ran the risk of having [his]255-archer mandate withdrawn , and for some obscure reason [he]255-archer disliked the prospect . Now that the job had been thrust on [him]255-archer [he]255-archer did not propose to relinquish it ; and , to guard against the possibility , [he]255-archer saw that [he]255-archer must reassure [the unimaginative old man who was the legal conscience of [the Mingotts]226-the mingotts]3502-the unimaginative old man who was the legal conscience of the mingotts . "[255-archer] [You]255-archer may be sure , [sir]3197-sir , that [I]0-i sha n't commit [myself]0-i till [I]0-i 've reported to [you]3197-sir ; what [I]0-i meant was that [I]0-i 'd rather not give an opinion till [I]0-i 've heard what [Madame Olenska]240-madame olenska has to say . " [Mr. Letterblair]357-mr. letterblair nodded approvingly at an excess of caution worthy of the best [New York]2-new york tradition , and [the young man]527-the young man , glancing at [his]527-the young man watch , pleaded an engagement and took leave . XII . Old - fashioned [New York]2-new york dined at seven , and the habit of after - dinner calls , though derided in [Archer]255-archer 's set , still generally prevailed . As [the young man]527-the young man strolled up [Fifth Avenue]15-fifth avenue from [Waverley Place]81-waverley place , [the long thoroughfare]3505-the long thoroughfare was deserted but for a group of carriages standing before [the Reggie Chiverses ']3506-the reggie chiverses ' ( where there was a dinner for [the Duke]1263-the duke ) , and the occasional figure of [an elderly gentleman in heavy overcoat and muffler]3508-an elderly gentleman in heavy overcoat and muffler ascending [a brownstone doorstep]3509-a brownstone doorstep and disappearing into [a gas - lit hall]3510-a gas - lit hall . Thus , as [Archer]255-archer crossed [Washington Square]46-washington square , [he]255-archer remarked that [old Mr. du Lac]364-old mr. du lac was calling on [[his]364-old mr. du lac cousins]1181-his cousins [the Dagonets]296-the dagonets , and turning down [the corner of [West Tenth Street]3513-west tenth street]3512-the corner of west tenth street [he]255-archer saw [Mr. Skipworth]358-mr. skipworth , of [[his]358-mr. skipworth own firm]3514-his own firm , obviously bound on a visit to [the Miss Lannings]294-the lannings . A little farther up [Fifth Avenue]15-fifth avenue , [Beaufort]250-beaufort appeared on [[his]250-beaufort doorstep]3515-his doorstep , darkly projected against a blaze of light , descended to [his]250-beaufort private brougham , and rolled away to a mysterious and probably unmentionable destination . It was not an Opera night , and [no one]619-no one was giving a party , so that [Beaufort]250-beaufort 's outing was undoubtedly of a clandestine nature . [Archer]255-archer connected it in [his]255-archer mind with [a little house beyond [Lexington Avenue]83-lexington avenue in which beribboned window curtains and flower - boxes had recently appeared , and before whose newly painted door the canary - coloured brougham of [Miss Fanny Ring]349-miss fanny ring]3517-a little house beyond lexington avenue in which beribboned window curtains and flower - boxes had recently appeared , and before whose newly painted door the canary - coloured brougham of miss fanny ring was frequently seen to wait . Beyond [the small and slippery pyramid which composed [Mrs. Archer]214-archer 's world]3518-the small and slippery pyramid which composed mrs. archer 's world lay [the almost unmapped quarter inhabited by [artists]3520-artists]3519-the almost unmapped quarter inhabited by artists , [musicians]3521-musicians and ["[240-madame olenska] people who wrote]3522-" people who wrote . " These scattered fragments of humanity had never shown any desire to be amalgamated with the social structure . In spite of odd ways [they]3522-" people who wrote were said to be , for the most part , quite respectable ; but [they]3522-" people who wrote preferred to keep to [themselves]3522-" people who wrote . [Medora Manson]229-medora manson , in [her]229-medora manson prosperous days , had inaugurated a "[240-madame olenska] literary salon " ; but it had soon died out owing to the reluctance of the literary to frequent [it]3517-a little house beyond lexington avenue in which beribboned window curtains and flower - boxes had recently appeared , and before whose newly painted door the canary - coloured brougham of miss fanny ring . [Others]3523-others had made the same attempt , and there was a household of [Blenkers]365-the blenkers -- [an intense and voluble mother]3524-an intense and voluble mother , and [three blowsy daughters who imitated [her]229-medora manson]3525-three blowsy daughters who imitated her -- where [one]519-one met [Edwin Booth]366-edwin booth and [Patti]314-patti and [William Winter]367-william winter , and [the new Shakespearian actor]3527-the new shakespearian actor [George Rignold]368-george rignold , and some of [the magazine editors]3528-the magazine editors and [musical and literary critics]3529-musical and literary critics . [Mrs. Archer]214-archer and [[her]214-archer group]3530-her group felt a certain timidity concerning [these persons]3531-these persons . [They]3531-these persons were odd , [they]3531-these persons were uncertain , [they]3531-these persons had things [one]519-one did n't know about in the background of [their]3531-these persons lives and minds . Literature and art were deeply respected in the Archer set , and [Mrs. Archer]214-archer was always at pains to tell [[her]214-archer children]726-her children how much more agreeable and cultivated society had been when it included such figures as [Washington Irving]369-washington irving , [Fitz - Greene Halleck]370-fitz - greene halleck and [the poet of "[3536-gentlemen "] [The Culprit Fay]371-the culprit fay]3534-the poet of " the culprit fay . " [The most celebrated authors of that generation]3535-the most celebrated authors of that generation had been "[3536-gentlemen "] [gentlemen "]3536-gentlemen " ; perhaps [the unknown persons who succeeded [them]3535-the most celebrated authors of that generation]3537-the unknown persons who succeeded them had gentlemanly sentiments , but [their]3537-the unknown persons who succeeded them origin , [their]3537-the unknown persons who succeeded them appearance , [their]3537-the unknown persons who succeeded them hair , [their]3537-the unknown persons who succeeded them intimacy with the stage and the Opera , made any old [New York]2-new york criterion inapplicable to [them]3537-the unknown persons who succeeded them . "[3536-gentlemen "] When [I]0-i was [a girl]1521-a girl , " [Mrs. Archer]214-archer used to say , "[1522-we] [we]1522-we knew [everybody]604-everybody between [the Battery]1524-the battery and [Canal Street]84-canal street ; and only [the people one]1525-the people one knew had [carriages]1526-carriages . It was perfectly easy to place [any one]1150-any one then ; now one ca n't tell , and [I]0-i prefer not to try . " Only [old Catherine Mingott]236-old catherine , with [her]236-old catherine absence of moral prejudices and almost parvenu indifference to the subtler distinctions , might have bridged the abyss ; but [she]236-old catherine had never opened a book or looked at a picture , and cared for music only because it reminded [her]236-old catherine of gala nights at [the Italiens]85-the italiens , in the days of [her]236-old catherine triumph at [the Tuileries]3538-the tuileries . Possibly [Beaufort]250-beaufort , who was [her]236-old catherine match in daring , would have succeeded in bringing about a fusion ; but [[his]250-beaufort grand house]3539-his grand house and [silk - stockinged footmen]3540-silk - stockinged footmen were an obstacle to informal sociability . Moreover , [he]250-beaufort was as illiterate as [old Mrs. Mingott]216-mrs. manson mingott , and considered "[3541-fellows who wrote "] [fellows who wrote "]3541-fellows who wrote " as [the mere paid purveyors of rich men]3542-the mere paid purveyors of rich men 's pleasures ; and [no one rich enough to influence [his]250-beaufort opinion]3543-no one rich enough to influence his opinion had ever questioned it . [Newland Archer]214-archer had been aware of these things ever since [he]250-beaufort could remember , and had accepted them as part of the structure of [his]250-beaufort universe . [He]250-beaufort knew that there were societies where [painters and poets]3544-painters and poets and [novelists]3545-novelists and [men of science]3546-men of science , and even [great actors]3547-great actors , were as sought after as [Dukes]372-dukes ; [he]250-beaufort had often pictured to [himself]250-beaufort what it would have been to live in the intimacy of [drawing - rooms]3548-drawing - rooms dominated by the talk of [Merimee]373-merimee ( whose "[3541-fellows who wrote "] Lettres a une Inconnue " was one of [[his]250-beaufort inseparables]3549-his inseparables ) , of [Thackeray]269-thackeray , [Browning]374-browning or [William Morris]375-william morris . But such things were inconceivable in [New York]2-new york , and unsettling to think of . [Archer]214-archer knew most of [the "[3541-fellows who wrote "] fellows who wrote , " [the musicians]3551-the musicians and [the painters]3552-the painters]3550-the " fellows who wrote , " the musicians and the painters : [he]250-beaufort met [them]3550-the " fellows who wrote , " the musicians and the painters at [the Century]86-the century , or at [the little musical and theatrical clubs that were beginning to come into existence]3553-the little musical and theatrical clubs that were beginning to come into existence . [He]250-beaufort enjoyed [them]3550-the " fellows who wrote , " the musicians and the painters there , and was bored with [them]3550-the " fellows who wrote , " the musicians and the painters at [the Blenkers ']3554-the blenkers ' , where [they]3550-the " fellows who wrote , " the musicians and the painters were mingled with fervid and [dowdy women who passed [them]3550-the " fellows who wrote , " the musicians and the painters about like captured curiosities]3555-dowdy women who passed them about like captured curiosities ; and even after [his]250-beaufort most exciting talks with [Ned Winsett]326-winsett [he]250-beaufort always came away with the feeling that if [[his]250-beaufort world]3556-his world was small , so was [theirs]3557-theirs , and that the only way to enlarge either was to reach a stage of manners where they would naturally merge . [He]250-beaufort was reminded of this by trying to picture the society in which [the Countess Olenska]234-the countess olenska had lived and suffered , and also -- perhaps -- tasted mysterious joys . [He]250-beaufort remembered with what amusement [she]234-the countess olenska had told [him]250-beaufort that [[her]234-the countess olenska grandmother]853-her grandmother [Mingott]216-mrs. manson mingott and [the Wellands]324-the wellands objected to [her]234-the countess olenska living in [a "[3541-fellows who wrote "] Bohemian " quarter]3559-a " bohemian " quarter given over to "[1528-people who wrote] [people who wrote]1528-people who wrote . " It was not the peril but the poverty that [[her]234-the countess olenska family]1211-her family disliked ; but that shade escaped [her]234-the countess olenska , and [she]234-the countess olenska supposed [they]1211-her family considered literature compromising . [She]234-the countess olenska [herself]234-the countess olenska had no fears of it , and the books scattered about [[her]234-the countess olenska drawing - room]3420-her drawing - room ( [a part of [the house in which books were usually supposed to be "[1528-people who wrote] out of place " )]3563-the house in which books were usually supposed to be " out of place " )]3562-a part of the house in which books were usually supposed to be " out of place " ) , though chiefly works of fiction , had whetted [Archer]214-archer 's interest with such new names as those of [Paul Bourget]376-paul bourget , [Huysmans]377-huysmans , and [the Goncourt brothers]378-the goncourt brothers . Ruminating on these things as [he]3564-he approached [her]234-the countess olenska door , [he]3564-he was once more conscious of the curious way in which [she]234-the countess olenska reversed [his]3564-he values , and of the need of thinking [himself]3564-he into conditions incredibly different from any that [he]3564-he knew if [he]3564-he were to be of use in [her]234-the countess olenska present difficulty . [Nastasia]340-nastasia opened the door , smiling mysteriously . On the bench in [the hall]755-the hall lay a sable - lined overcoat , a folded opera hat of dull silk with a gold J. B. on the lining , and a white silk muffler : there was no mistaking the fact that these costly articles were the property of [Julius Beaufort]230-beaufort . [Archer]214-archer was angry : so angry that [he]3564-he came near scribbling a word on [his]3564-he card and going away ; then [he]3564-he remembered that in writing to [Madame Olenska]240-madame olenska [he]3564-he had been kept by excess of discretion from saying that [he]3564-he wished to see [her]240-madame olenska privately . [He]3564-he had therefore [no one]619-no one but [himself]3564-he to blame if [she]240-madame olenska had opened [her]240-madame olenska doors to [other visitors]3567-other visitors ; and [he]3564-he entered [the drawing - room]983-the drawing - room with the dogged determination to make [Beaufort]230-beaufort feel [himself]230-beaufort in the way , and to outstay [him]3564-he . [The banker]609-the banker stood leaning against the mantelshelf , which was draped with an old embroidery held in place by brass candelabra containing church candles of yellowish wax . [He]609-the banker had thrust [his]609-the banker chest out , supporting [his]609-the banker shoulders against the mantel and resting [his]609-the banker weight on one large patent - leather foot . As [Archer]214-archer entered [he]3564-he was smiling and looking down on [[his]3564-he hostess]1261-his hostess , who sat on a sofa placed at right angles to the chimney . A table banked with flowers formed a screen behind [it]3571-it , and against the orchids and azaleas which [the young man]527-the young man recognised as tributes from [the Beaufort hot - houses]3573-the beaufort hot - houses , [Madame Olenska]240-madame olenska sat half - reclined , [her]240-madame olenska head propped on a hand and [her]240-madame olenska wide sleeve leaving the arm bare to the elbow . It was usual for [ladies who received in the evenings]3574-ladies who received in the evenings to wear what were called "[1529-lord] simple dinner dresses " : a close - fitting armour of whale - boned silk , slightly open in the neck , with lace ruffles filling in the crack , and tight sleeves with a flounce uncovering just enough wrist to show an Etruscan gold bracelet or a velvet band . But [Madame Olenska]240-madame olenska , heedless of tradition , was attired in a long robe of red velvet bordered about the chin and down the front with glossy black fur . [Archer]214-archer remembered , on [his]3564-he last visit to [Paris]3-paris , seeing a portrait by [the new painter]3575-the new painter , [Carolus Duran]379-carolus duran , whose pictures were the sensation of [the Salon]3576-the salon , in which [the lady]681-the lady wore one of these bold sheath - like robes with [her]681-the lady chin nestling in fur . There was something perverse and provocative in the notion of fur worn in the evening in [a heated drawing - room]3578-a heated drawing - room , and in the combination of a muffled throat and bare arms ; but the effect was undeniably pleasing . "[1529-lord] [Lord]1529-lord love [us]1530-us -- three whole days at [Skuytercliff]57-skuytercliff ! " [Beaufort]230-beaufort was saying in [his]3579-his loud sneering voice as [Archer]214-archer entered . [[[My]0-i husband]3236-my husband 's house]1547-my husband 's house was always full of [them]1540-painters . " [She]0-i said the words "[3236-my husband] [[my]0-i husband]3236-my husband " as if no sinister associations were connected with them , and in a tone that seemed almost to sigh over the lost delights of [her]0-i married life . [Archer]214-archer looked at [her]0-i perplexedly , wondering if it were lightness or dissimulation that enabled [her]0-i to touch so easily on the past at the very moment when [she]0-i was risking [her]0-i reputation in order to break with it . "[0-i] [I]0-i do think , " [she]0-i went on , addressing [both men]3582-both men , "[0-i] that the imprevu adds to [one]519-one 's enjoyment . " "[0-i] It 's confoundedly dull , anyhow ; [New York]2-new york is dying of dullness , " [Beaufort]230-beaufort grumbled . "[380-campanini] And when [I]0-i try to liven it up for [you]1551-his , [you]1551-his go back on [me]0-i . Come -- think better of it ! " "[1553-they] How delicious ! May [I]0-i think it over , and write to [you]1551-his tomorrow morning ? " [She]0-i spoke amiably , yet with the least hint of dismissal in [her]0-i voice . [Beaufort]230-beaufort evidently felt it , and being unused to dismissals , stood staring at [her]0-i with an obstinate line between [his]1551-his eyes . "[0-i] Why not now ? " "[1551-his] It 's too serious a question to decide at this late hour . " "[1551-his] Do [you]1551-his call it late ? " [She]0-i returned [his]1551-his glance coolly . "[1551-his] Yes ; because [I]0-i have still to talk business with [Mr. Archer]255-archer for a little while . " "[255-archer] Ah , " [Beaufort]230-beaufort snapped . There was no appeal from [her]0-i tone , and with a slight shrug [he]1551-his recovered [his]1551-his composure , took [her]0-i hand , which [he]1551-his kissed with a practised air , and calling out from the threshold : "[0-i] [I]0-i say , [Newland]214-archer , if [you]214-archer can persuade [the Countess]1272-the countess to stop in [town]1128-town of course [you]214-archer 're included in the supper , " left [the room]991-the room with [his]1551-his heavy important step . For a moment [Archer]255-archer fancied that [Mr. Letterblair]357-mr. letterblair must have told [her]0-i of [his]1551-his coming ; but the irrelevance of [her]0-i next remark made [him]255-archer change [his]255-archer mind . "[214-archer] [You]214-archer know painters , then ? [You]214-archer live in [their]1556-their milieu ? " [she]0-i asked , [her]0-i eyes full of interest . "[214-archer] Oh , not exactly . It 's all stupid and narrow and unjust -- but one ca n't make over [society]1441-society . "[357-mr. letterblair] [The individual]1583-the individual , in such cases , is nearly always sacrificed to what is supposed to be the collective interest : [people]637-people cling to any convention that keeps [the family]551-the family together -- protects [the children]1586-the children , if there are any , " [he]255-archer rambled on , pouring out all the stock phrases that rose to [his]255-archer lips in [his]255-archer intense desire to cover over the ugly reality which [her]1569-my poor child silence seemed to have laid bare . Since [she]1569-my poor child would not or could not say the one word that would have cleared the air , [his]255-archer wish was not to let [her]1569-my poor child feel that [he]255-archer was trying to probe into [her]1569-my poor child secret .
