[XIII]382-xiii . It was a crowded night at [[Wallack]383-wallack 's theatre]3598-wallack 's theatre . The play was "[384-the shaughraun] [The Shaughraun]384-the shaughraun , " with [Dion Boucicault]385-dion boucicault in the title role and [Harry Montague]386-harry montague and [Ada Dyas]387-ada dyas as [the lovers]3599-the lovers . The popularity of [the admirable English company]3600-the admirable english company was at its height , and [the Shaughraun]384-the shaughraun always packed [the house]532-the house . In [the galleries]3602-the galleries the enthusiasm was unreserved ; in [the stalls]3603-the stalls and boxes , [people]637-people smiled a little at the hackneyed sentiments and clap - trap situations , and enjoyed the play as much as [the galleries]3602-the galleries did . There was one episode , in particular , that held [the house]532-the house from floor to ceiling . It was that in which [Harry Montague]386-harry montague , after a sad , almost monosyllabic scene of parting with [Miss Dyas]388-miss dyas , bade [her]388-miss dyas good - bye , and turned to go . [The actress]3607-the actress , who was standing near the mantelpiece and looking down into the fire , wore a gray cashmere dress without fashionable loopings or trimmings , moulded to [her]3607-the actress tall figure and flowing in long lines about [her]3607-the actress feet . Around [her]3607-the actress neck was a narrow black velvet ribbon with the ends falling down [her]3607-the actress back . When [[her]3607-the actress wooer]3608-her wooer turned from [her]3607-the actress [she]3607-the actress rested [her]3607-the actress arms against the mantel - shelf and bowed [her]3607-the actress face in [her]3607-the actress hands . On the threshold [he]386-harry montague paused to look at [her]3607-the actress ; then [he]386-harry montague stole back , lifted one of the ends of velvet ribbon , kissed it , and left [the room]991-the room without [her]3607-the actress hearing [him]386-harry montague or changing [her]3607-the actress attitude . And on this silent parting the curtain fell . It was always for the sake of that particular scene that [Newland Archer]214-archer went to see "[384-the shaughraun] [The Shaughraun]384-the shaughraun . " [He]386-harry montague thought the adieux of [Montague]386-harry montague and [Ada Dyas]387-ada dyas as fine as anything [he]386-harry montague had ever seen [Croisette]389-croisette and [Bressant]390-bressant do in [Paris]3-paris , or [Madge Robertson]391-may and [Kendal]90-kendal in [London]79-london ; in its reticence , its dumb sorrow , it moved [him]386-harry montague more than the most famous histrionic outpourings . On the evening in question the little scene acquired an added poignancy by reminding [him]386-harry montague -- [he]386-harry montague could not have said why -- of [his]386-harry montague leave - taking from [Madame Olenska]240-madame olenska after [their]3610-their confidential talk a week or ten days earlier . It would have been as difficult to discover any resemblance between the two situations as between the appearance of [the persons concerned]3611-the persons concerned . [Newland Archer]214-archer could not pretend to anything approaching [the young English actor]3612-the young english actor 's romantic good looks , and [Miss Dyas]388-miss dyas was [a tall red - haired woman of monumental build whose pale and pleasantly ugly face]3613-a tall red - haired woman of monumental build whose pale and pleasantly ugly face was utterly unlike [Ellen Olenska]232-ellen 's vivid countenance . Nor were [Archer]214-archer and [Madame Olenska]240-madame olenska two lovers parting in heart - broken silence ; [they]3610-their were [client]3614-client and [lawyer]3615-lawyer separating after a talk which had given [the lawyer]3616-the lawyer the worst possible impression of [the client]3617-the client 's case . Wherein , then , lay the resemblance that made [the young man]527-the young man 's heart beat with a kind of retrospective excitement ? It seemed to be in [Madame Olenska]240-madame olenska 's mysterious faculty of suggesting tragic and moving possibilities outside the daily run of experience . [She]240-madame olenska had hardly ever said a word to [him]386-harry montague to produce this impression , but it was a part of [her]240-madame olenska , either a projection of [her]240-madame olenska mysterious and outlandish background or of something inherently dramatic , passionate and unusual in [herself]240-madame olenska . [Archer]214-archer had always been inclined to think that chance and circumstance played a small part in shaping [people]637-people 's lots compared with [their]637-people innate tendency to have things happen to [them]637-people . This tendency [he]386-harry montague had felt from the first in [Madame Olenska]240-madame olenska . [The quiet , almost passive young woman]3620-the quiet , almost passive young woman struck [him]386-harry montague as exactly [the kind of person to whom things were bound to happen]3621-the kind of person to whom things were bound to happen , no matter how much [she]3620-the quiet , almost passive young woman shrank from [them]637-people and went out of [her]3620-the quiet , almost passive young woman way to avoid [them]637-people . The exciting fact was [her]3620-the quiet , almost passive young woman having lived in an atmosphere so thick with drama that [her]3620-the quiet , almost passive young woman own tendency to provoke it had apparently passed unperceived . It was precisely the odd absence of surprise in [her]3620-the quiet , almost passive young woman that gave [him]386-harry montague the sense of [her]3620-the quiet , almost passive young woman having been plucked out of a very maelstrom : the things [she]3620-the quiet , almost passive young woman took for granted gave the measure of those [she]3620-the quiet , almost passive young woman had rebelled against . [Archer]214-archer had left [her]3620-the quiet , almost passive young woman with the conviction that [Count Olenski]278-count olenski 's accusation was not unfounded . [The mysterious person who figured in [[his]386-harry montague wife]572-his wife 's past]3622-the mysterious person who figured in his wife 's past as "[3199-the secretary] [the secretary]3199-the secretary " had probably not been unrewarded for [his]386-harry montague share in [her]3620-the quiet , almost passive young woman escape . The conditions from which [she]3620-the quiet , almost passive young woman had fled were intolerable , past speaking of , past believing : [she]3620-the quiet , almost passive young woman was young , [she]3620-the quiet , almost passive young woman was frightened , [she]3620-the quiet , almost passive young woman was desperate -- what more natural than that [she]3620-the quiet , almost passive young woman should be grateful to [[her]3620-the quiet , almost passive young woman rescuer]3624-her rescuer ? The pity was that [her]3620-the quiet , almost passive young woman gratitude put [her]3620-the quiet , almost passive young woman , in [the law]3625-the law 's eyes and [the world]580-the world 's , on a par with [[her]3620-the quiet , almost passive young woman abominable husband]3627-her abominable husband . [Archer]214-archer had made [her]3620-the quiet , almost passive young woman understand this , as [he]386-harry montague was bound to do ; [he]386-harry montague had also made [her]3620-the quiet , almost passive young woman understand that simplehearted kindly [New York]2-new york , on whose larger charity [she]3620-the quiet , almost passive young woman had apparently counted , was precisely [the place where [she]3620-the quiet , almost passive young woman could least hope for indulgence]3628-the place where she could least hope for indulgence . To have to make this fact plain to [her]3620-the quiet , almost passive young woman -- and to witness [her]3620-the quiet , almost passive young woman resigned acceptance of it -- had been intolerably painful to [him]386-harry montague . [He]386-harry montague felt [himself]386-harry montague drawn to [her]3620-the quiet , almost passive young woman by obscure feelings of jealousy and pity , as if [her]3620-the quiet , almost passive young woman dumbly - confessed error had put [her]3620-the quiet , almost passive young woman at [his]386-harry montague mercy , humbling yet endearing [her]3620-the quiet , almost passive young woman . [He]386-harry montague was glad it was to [him]386-harry montague [she]3620-the quiet , almost passive young woman had revealed [her]3620-the quiet , almost passive young woman secret , rather than to the cold scrutiny of [Mr. Letterblair]357-mr. letterblair , or the embarrassed gaze of [[her]3620-the quiet , almost passive young woman family]1211-her family . [He]386-harry montague immediately took it upon [himself]386-harry montague to assure [them]3630-them both that [she]3620-the quiet , almost passive young woman had given up [her]3620-the quiet , almost passive young woman idea of seeking a divorce , basing [her]3620-the quiet , almost passive young woman decision on the fact that [she]3620-the quiet , almost passive young woman had understood the uselessness of the proceeding ; and with infinite relief [they]3630-them had all turned [their]3630-them eyes from the "[3199-the secretary] unpleasantness " [she]3620-the quiet , almost passive young woman had spared [them]3630-them . "[0-i] [I]0-i was sure [Newland]214-archer would manage it , " [Mrs. Welland]218-mrs. welland had said proudly of [[her]0-i future son - in - law]697-her future son - in - law ; and [old Mrs. Mingott]216-mrs. manson mingott , who had summoned [him]697-her future son - in - law for a confidential interview , had congratulated [him]697-her future son - in - law on [his]697-her future son - in - law cleverness , and added impatiently : "[0-i] Silly goose ! " These incidents had made the memory of [his]697-her future son - in - law last talk with [Madame Olenska]240-madame olenska so vivid to [the young man]527-the young man that as the curtain fell on the parting of [the two actors]3633-the two actors [his]697-her future son - in - law eyes filled with tears , and [he]697-her future son - in - law stood up to leave [the theatre]3634-the theatre . There was [no one else in the box]3639-no one else in the box but [Mr. Sillerton Jackson]224-mr. jackson , who was telling [Mrs. Beaufort]230-beaufort in a confidential undertone about [Mrs. Lemuel Struthers]259-mrs. struthers 's last Sunday reception ( where [some people]713-some people reported that there had been dancing ) . Under cover of this circumstantial narrative , to which [Mrs. Beaufort]230-beaufort listened with [her]230-beaufort perfect smile , and [her]230-beaufort head at just the right angle to be seen in profile from [the stalls]3603-the stalls , [Madame Olenska]240-madame olenska turned and spoke in a low voice . "[1599-he] Do [you]1599-he think , " [she]240-madame olenska asked , glancing toward [the stage]547-the stage , "[1599-he] [he]1599-he will send [her]1600-her a bunch of yellow roses tomorrow morning ? " [Archer]214-archer reddened , and [his]1599-he heart gave a leap of surprise . [He]1599-he had called only twice on [Madame Olenska]240-madame olenska , and each time [he]1599-he had sent [her]1600-her a box of yellow roses , and each time without a card . [She]1600-her had never before made any allusion to the flowers , and [he]1599-he supposed [she]1600-her had never thought of [him]1599-he as [the sender]3643-the sender . Now [her]1600-her sudden recognition of the gift , and [her]1600-her associating it with the tender leave - taking on the stage , filled [him]1599-he with an agitated pleasure . "[0-i] [I]0-i was thinking of that too -- [I]0-i was going to leave [the theatre]3634-the theatre in order to take the picture away with [me]0-i , " [he]1599-he said . To [his]1599-he surprise [her]1600-her colour rose , reluctantly and duskily . [She]1600-her looked down at the mother - of - pearl opera - glass in [her]1600-her smoothly gloved hands , and said , after a pause : "[0-i] What do [you]0-i do while [May]391-may is away ? " "[0-i] [I]0-i stick to [my]0-i work , " [he]1599-he answered , faintly annoyed by the question . In obedience to a long - established habit , [the Wellands]324-the wellands had left the previous week for [St. Augustine]91-st. augustine , where , out of regard for the supposed susceptibility of [Mr. Welland]339-mr. welland 's bronchial tubes , [they]324-the wellands always spent the latter part of the winter . [Mr. Welland]339-mr. welland was [a mild and silent man , with no opinions but with many habits]3644-a mild and silent man , with no opinions but with many habits . With these habits none might interfere ; and one of [them]324-the wellands demanded that [[his]339-mr. welland wife]572-his wife and [daughter]928-daughter should always go with [him]339-mr. welland on [his]339-mr. welland annual journey to [the south]3647-the south . To preserve an unbroken domesticity was essential to [his]339-mr. welland peace of mind ; [he]339-mr. welland would not have known where [his]339-mr. welland hair - brushes were , or how to provide stamps for [his]339-mr. welland letters , if [Mrs. Welland]218-mrs. welland had not been there to tell [him]339-mr. welland . As [all the members of [the family]551-the family]3648-all the members of the family adored [each other]695-each other , and as [Mr. Welland]339-mr. welland was the central object of [their]3648-all the members of the family idolatry , it never occurred to [[his]339-mr. welland wife]572-his wife and [May]391-may to let [him]339-mr. welland go to [St. Augustine]91-st. augustine alone ; and [[his]339-mr. welland sons , who were both in the law , and could not leave [New York]2-new york during the winter]3652-his sons , who were both in the law , and could not leave new york during the winter , always joined [him]339-mr. welland for Easter and travelled back with [him]339-mr. welland . It was impossible for [Archer]214-archer to discuss the necessity of [May]391-may 's accompanying [[her]391-may father]3653-her father . The reputation of [[the Mingotts]226-the mingotts ' family physician]3654-the mingotts ' family physician was largely based on the attack of pneumonia which [Mr. Welland]339-mr. welland had never had ; and [his]339-mr. welland insistence on [St. Augustine]91-st. augustine was therefore inflexible . Originally , it had been intended that [May]391-may 's engagement should not be announced till [her]391-may return from [Florida]92-florida , and the fact that it had been made known sooner could not be expected to alter [Mr. Welland]339-mr. welland 's plans . [Archer]214-archer would have liked to join [the travellers]3655-the travellers and have a few weeks of sunshine and boating with [[his]339-mr. welland betrothed]614-his betrothed ; but [he]339-mr. welland too was bound by custom and conventions . Little arduous as [his]339-mr. welland professional duties were , [he]339-mr. welland would have been convicted of frivolity by [the whole Mingott clan]3657-the whole mingott clan if [he]339-mr. welland had suggested asking for a holiday in mid - winter ; and [he]339-mr. welland accepted [May]391-may 's departure with the resignation which [he]339-mr. welland perceived would have to be one of the principal constituents of married life . [He]339-mr. welland was conscious that [Madame Olenska]240-madame olenska was looking at [him]339-mr. welland under lowered lids . [Winsett]326-winsett [himself]326-winsett had a savage abhorrence of social observances : [Archer]263-janey , who dressed in the evening because [he]263-janey thought it cleaner and more comfortable to do so , and who had never stopped to consider that cleanliness and comfort are two of the costliest items in a modest budget , regarded [Winsett]326-winsett 's attitude as part of the boring "[0-i] Bohemian " pose that always made [fashionable people]3692-fashionable people , who changed [their]3692-fashionable people clothes without talking about it , and were not forever harping on the number of [servants one kept]3693-servants one kept , seem so much simpler and less self - conscious than the others . [Winsett]326-winsett was not [a journalist]3672-a journalist by choice . [He]326-winsett was [a pure man of letters , untimely born in a world that had no need of letters]3696-a pure man of letters , untimely born in a world that had no need of letters ; but after publishing one volume of brief and exquisite literary appreciations , of which one hundred and twenty copies were sold , thirty given away , and the balance eventually destroyed by [the publishers]3697-the publishers ( as per contract ) to make room for more marketable material , [he]326-winsett had abandoned [his]326-winsett real calling , and taken a sub - editorial job on [a women]3698-a women 's weekly , where fashion - plates and paper patterns alternated with [New England]39-new england love - stories and advertisements of temperance drinks . On the subject of "[0-i] Hearth - fires " ( as the paper was called ) [he]326-winsett was inexhaustibly entertaining ; but beneath [his]326-winsett fun lurked the sterile bitterness of [the still young man who has tried and given up]3699-the still young man who has tried and given up . [His]326-winsett conversation always made [Archer]263-janey take the measure of [his]263-janey own life , and feel how little it contained ; but [Winsett]326-winsett 's , after all , contained still less , and though [their]1631-their common fund of intellectual interests and curiosities made [their]1631-their talks exhilarating , [their]1631-their exchange of views usually remained within the limits of a pensive dilettantism . "[0-i] The fact is , life is n't much a fit for either of [us]1631-their , " [Winsett]326-winsett had once said . "[0-i] [I]0-i 'm down and out ; nothing to be done about it . [I]0-i 've got only one ware to produce , and there 's no market for it here , and wo n't be in [my]0-i time . But [you]1632-you 're free and [you]1632-you 're well - off . Why do n't [you]1632-you get into touch ? There 's only one way to do it : to go into politics . " [Archer]263-janey threw [his]263-janey head back and laughed . There [one]519-one saw at a flash the unbridgeable difference between [men like [Winsett]326-winsett]3701-men like winsett and [the others]3702-the others -- [Archer]263-janey 's kind . "[1634-the honest man in american politics] Culture ! Yes -- if [we]1635-us had it ! But there are just a few little local patches , dying out here and there for lack of -- well , hoeing and cross - fertilising : the last remnants of the old European tradition that [[your]1632-you forebears]1636-your forebears brought with [them]1636-your forebears . " [Archer]263-janey mentally shrugged [his]263-janey shoulders and turned the conversation back to books , where [Winsett]326-winsett , if uncertain , was always interesting . Emigrate ! But [you]1632-you could n't make [a man like [Winsett]326-winsett]3717-a man like winsett see that ; and that was why [the New York of literary clubs and [exotic restaurants]3719-exotic restaurants]3718-the new york of literary clubs and exotic restaurants , though a first shake made it seem more of a kaleidoscope , turned out , in the end , to be a smaller box , with a more monotonous pattern , than the assembled atoms of [Fifth Avenue]15-fifth avenue . The next morning [Archer]263-janey scoured [the town]3720-the town in vain for more yellow roses . In consequence of this search [he]263-janey arrived late at [the office]3721-the office , perceived that [his]263-janey doing so made no difference whatever to [any one]1150-any one , and was filled with sudden exasperation at the elaborate futility of [his]263-janey life . Why should [he]263-janey not be , at that moment , on [the sands of [St. Augustine]91-st. augustine with May Welland]3723-the sands of st. augustine with may welland ? [No one]619-no one was deceived by [his]263-janey pretense of professional activity . In [old - fashioned legal firms like that of which [Mr. Letterblair]357-mr. letterblair]3725-old - fashioned legal firms like that of which mr. letterblair was the head , and which were mainly engaged in the management of [large estates]3726-large estates and ["[0-i] conservative " investments]3727-" conservative " investments , there were always [two or three young men]3728-two or three young men , fairly well - off , and without professional ambition , who , for a certain number of hours of each day , sat at [their]3728-two or three young men desks accomplishing trivial tasks , or simply reading the newspapers . Though it was supposed to be proper for [them]3728-two or three young men to have an occupation , the crude fact of money - making was still regarded as derogatory , and the law , being a profession , was accounted a more gentlemanly pursuit than business . But [none of [these young men]3730-these young men]3729-none of these young men had much hope of really advancing in [his]263-janey profession , or any earnest desire to do so ; and over many of [them]3730-these young men the green mould of the perfunctory was already perceptibly spreading . It made [Archer]263-janey shiver to think that it might be spreading over [him]263-janey too . [He]263-janey had , to be sure , other tastes and interests ; [he]263-janey spent [his]263-janey vacations in European travel , cultivated [the "[1641-you] clever people " [May]221-may]3731-the " clever people " may spoke of , and generally tried to "[0-i] keep up , " as [he]263-janey had somewhat wistfully put it to [Madame Olenska]240-madame olenska . From [the office]3721-the office [he]263-janey sent a note by messenger to [Madame Olenska]240-madame olenska , asking if [he]263-janey might call that afternoon , and begging [her]240-madame olenska to let [him]263-janey find a reply at [[his]263-janey club]773-his club ; but at [the club]1433-the club [he]263-janey found nothing , nor did [he]263-janey receive any letter the following day . This unexpected silence mortified [him]263-janey beyond reason , and though the next morning [he]263-janey saw a glorious cluster of yellow roses behind [a florist]3737-a florist 's window - pane , [he]263-janey left it there . It was only on the third morning that [he]263-janey received a line by post from [the Countess Olenska]234-the countess olenska . To [his]263-janey surprise it was dated from [Skuytercliff]57-skuytercliff , whither [the van der Luydens]275-the van der luydens had promptly retreated after putting [the Duke]1263-the duke on board [[his]57-skuytercliff steamer]3739-his steamer . "[0-i] [I]0-i ran away , " [the writer]3740-the writer began abruptly ( without the usual preliminaries ) , "[0-i] the day after [I]0-i saw [you]1641-you at the play , and [these kind friends]1642-these kind friends have taken [me]0-i in . [I]0-i wanted to be quiet , and think things over . [You]1641-you were right in telling [me]0-i how kind [they]1642-these kind friends were ; [I]0-i feel [myself]0-i so safe here . [I]0-i wish that [you]1641-you were with [us]1643-us . " [She]0-i ended with a conventional "[0-i] Yours sincerely , " and without any allusion to the date of [her]0-i return . The tone of the note surprised [the young man]527-the young man . What was [Madame Olenska]240-madame olenska running away from , and why did [she]240-madame olenska feel the need to be safe ? [His]527-the young man first thought was of some dark menace from abroad ; then [he]527-the young man reflected that [he]527-the young man did not know [her]240-madame olenska epistolary style , and that it might run to picturesque exaggeration . [Women]3106-women always exaggerated ; and moreover [she]240-madame olenska was not wholly at [her]240-madame olenska ease in English , which [she]240-madame olenska often spoke as if [she]240-madame olenska were translating from the French . "[0-i] Je [me]0-i suis evadee-- " put in that way , the opening sentence immediately suggested that [she]240-madame olenska might merely have wanted to escape from a boring round of engagements ; which was very likely true , for [he]527-the young man judged [her]240-madame olenska to be capricious , and easily wearied of the pleasure of the moment . It amused [him]527-the young man to think of the van der [Luydens]275-the van der luydens ' having carried [her]240-madame olenska off to [Skuytercliff]57-skuytercliff on a second visit , and this time for an indefinite period . The doors of [Skuytercliff]57-skuytercliff were rarely and grudgingly opened to [visitors]3743-visitors , and a chilly week - end was the most ever offered to [the few thus privileged]3744-the few thus privileged . But [Archer]263-janey had seen , on [his]263-janey last visit to [Paris]3-paris , the delicious play of [Labiche]394-labiche , "[0-i] Le Voyage de [M. Perrichon]395-m. perrichon , " and [he]263-janey remembered [M. [The van der Luydens]275-the van der luydens had rescued [Madame Olenska]240-madame olenska from a doom almost as icy ; and though there were many other reasons for being attracted to [her]240-madame olenska , [Archer]263-janey knew that beneath [them]3747-them all lay the gentle and obstinate determination to go on rescuing [her]240-madame olenska . [He]263-janey felt a distinct disappointment on learning that [she]240-madame olenska was away ; and almost immediately remembered that , only the day before , [he]263-janey had refused an invitation to spend the following Sunday with [the Reggie Chiverses]286-the reggie chiverses at [[their]275-the van der luydens house on [the Hudson]58-the hudson]3748-their house on the hudson , [a few miles below [Skuytercliff]57-skuytercliff]3749-a few miles below skuytercliff . [He]263-janey had had [his]263-janey fill long ago of the noisy friendly parties at [Highbank]94-highbank , with coasting , ice - boating , sleighing , long tramps in the snow , and a general flavour of mild flirting and milder practical jokes . [He]263-janey had just received a box of new books from [his]263-janey [London]79-london book - seller , and had preferred the prospect of a quiet Sunday at [home]649-home with [his]263-janey spoils . But [he]263-janey now went into [the club writing - room]3751-the club writing - room , wrote a hurried telegram , and told [the servant]3752-the servant to send it immediately . [He]263-janey knew that [Mrs. Reggie]396-reggie chivers did n't object to [[her]396-reggie chivers visitors]842-her visitors ' suddenly changing [their]842-her visitors minds , and that there was always a room to spare in [[her]396-reggie chivers elastic house]3754-her elastic house . [XV . But on Sunday after luncheon [he]263-janey borrowed [a cutter]3768-a cutter , and drove over to [Skuytercliff]57-skuytercliff . [People]637-people had always been told that [the house at [Skuytercliff]57-skuytercliff]3770-the house at skuytercliff was [an Italian villa]3771-an italian villa . [The house]532-the house had been built by [Mr. van der Luyden]304-mr. van der luyden in [his]304-mr. van der luyden youth , on [his]304-mr. van der luyden return from the "[304-mr. van der luyden] grand tour , " and in anticipation of [his]304-mr. van der luyden approaching marriage with [Miss Louisa Dagonet]298-louisa . From the high ground on which [it]532-the house stood [a series of terraces bordered by balustrades and urns]3775-a series of terraces bordered by balustrades and urns descended in the steel - engraving style to [a small irregular lake with an asphalt edge overhung by rare weeping conifers]3776-a small irregular lake with an asphalt edge overhung by rare weeping conifers . Against the uniform sheet of snow and the greyish winter sky [the Italian villa]3782-the italian villa loomed up rather grimly ; even in [summer]3783-summer [it]3782-the italian villa kept [its]3782-the italian villa distance , and the boldest coleus bed had never ventured nearer than thirty feet from [its]3782-the italian villa awful front . "[304-mr. van der luyden] [Mr. van der Luyden]304-mr. van der luyden , " [the butler]944-the butler continued , "[3197-sir] is in , [sir]3197-sir ; but [my]0-i impression is that [he]304-mr. van der luyden is either finishing [his]304-mr. van der luyden nap or else reading yesterday 's Evening Post . [A groom]3790-a groom took [the cutter]3791-the cutter to [the stables]3792-the stables , and [Archer]214-archer struck through [the park]1318-the park to [the high - road]3794-the high - road . [The village of]3795-the village of [Skuytercliff]57-skuytercliff was only a mile and a half away , but [he]1650-he knew that [Mrs. van der Luyden]297-mrs. van der luyden never walked , and that [he]1650-he must keep to [the road]3796-the road to meet [the carriage]878-the carriage . Presently , however , coming down a foot - path that crossed [the highway]3798-the highway , [he]1650-he caught sight of [a slight figure in a red cloak]3799-a slight figure in a red cloak , with a big dog running ahead . [He]1650-he hurried forward , and [Madame Olenska]240-madame olenska stopped short with a smile of welcome . "[304-mr. van der luyden] Ah , [you]1650-he 've come ! " [she]240-madame olenska said , and drew [her]240-madame olenska hand from [her]240-madame olenska muff . The red cloak made [her]240-madame olenska look gay and vivid , like the [Ellen Mingott]260-ellen of old days ; and [he]1650-he laughed as [he]1650-he took [her]240-madame olenska hand , and answered : "[304-mr. van der luyden] [I]0-i came to see what [you]1651-you were running away from . " [Her]240-madame olenska face clouded over , but [she]240-madame olenska answered : "[0-i] Ah , well -- [you]1650-he will see , presently . " The answer puzzled [him]1650-he . "[1650-he] Why -- do [you]1651-you mean that [you]1650-he 've been overtaken ? [I]0-i 'm so cold after the sermon . And what does it matter , now [you]1650-he 're here to protect [me]0-i ? " "[1650-he] Oh , presently -- let 's run a race first : [my]0-i feet are freezing to the ground , " [she]240-madame olenska cried ; and gathering up the cloak [she]240-madame olenska fled away across the snow , the dog leaping about [her]240-madame olenska with challenging barks . "[0-i] Where did [you]0-i come from ? " [Madame Olenska]240-madame olenska asked . [He]1650-he told [her]0-i , and added : "[0-i] It was because [I]0-i got [your]0-i note . " After a pause [she]0-i said , with a just perceptible chill in [her]0-i voice : "[221-may] [May]221-may asked [you]1650-he to take care of [me]0-i . " "[221-may] [I]0-i did n't need any asking . "[0-i] What did [I]0-i come for , if [I]0-i do n't speak [yours]1650-he ? " "[0-i] Oh , [[my]0-i friend--]1655-my friend-- ! " [She]0-i shrugged again . "[260-ellen] Does anything ever happen in [heaven]3121-heaven ? " [He]1650-he was silent , and [they]3803-they walked on a few yards without exchanging a word . Finally [she]0-i said : "[0-i] [I]0-i will tell [you]1655-my friend-- -- but where , where , where ? [One]519-one ca n't be alone for a minute in [that great seminary of [a house]3206-a house]1658-that great seminary of a house , with all the doors wide open , and always [a servant]1660-a servant bringing tea , or a log for the fire , or the newspaper ! " [he]304-mr. van der luyden said . [She]0-i stood still . "[304-mr. van der luyden] No ; only for today , at least . " [She]0-i ran up the steps and tried the door . "[304-mr. van der luyden] It 's still unlocked -- what luck ! Come in and [we]1665-we can have a quiet talk . " [He]304-mr. van der luyden followed [her]0-i into [the narrow passage]3805-the narrow passage . [His]304-mr. van der luyden spirits , which had dropped at [her]0-i last words , rose with an irrational leap . [The homely little house]3806-the homely little house stood there , [its]3806-the homely little house panels and brasses shining in the firelight , as if magically created to receive them . A big bed of embers still gleamed in the kitchen chimney , under an iron pot hung from an ancient crane . Rush - bottomed arm - chairs faced each other across the tiled hearth , and rows of Delft plates stood on shelves against the walls . [Archer]214-archer stooped over and threw a log upon the embers . " "[0-i] [I]0-i sha'n't be here long , " [he]304-mr. van der luyden rejoined , [his]304-mr. van der luyden lips stiffening with the effort to say just so much and no more . "[0-i] No ; [I]0-i know . But [I]0-i 'm improvident : [I]0-i live in the moment when [I]0-i 'm happy . " The words stole through [him]304-mr. van der luyden like a temptation , and to close [his]304-mr. van der luyden senses to it [he]304-mr. van der luyden moved away from the hearth and stood gazing out at the black tree - boles against the snow . "[260-ellen] [Ellen]260-ellen , if [I]0-i 'm really a help to [you]260-ellen -- if [you]260-ellen really wanted [me]0-i to come -- tell [me]0-i what 's wrong , tell [me]0-i what it is [you]260-ellen 're running away from , " [he]304-mr. van der luyden insisted . [He]304-mr. van der luyden spoke without shifting [his]304-mr. van der luyden position , without even turning to look at [her]260-ellen : if the thing was to happen , it was to happen in this way , with the whole width of [the room]991-the room between [them]3807-they , and [his]304-mr. van der luyden eyes still fixed on the outer snow . During [his]304-mr. van der luyden journey back to [New York]2-new york the next morning , [Archer]214-archer relived with a fatiguing vividness [his]304-mr. van der luyden last moments at [Skuytercliff]57-skuytercliff . [Beaufort]230-beaufort , though clearly annoyed at finding [him]304-mr. van der luyden with [Madame Olenska]240-madame olenska , had , as usual , carried off the situation high - handedly . [His]304-mr. van der luyden way of ignoring [people whose presence]3815-people whose presence inconvenienced [him]304-mr. van der luyden actually gave [them]3815-people whose presence , if [they]3815-people whose presence were sensitive to it , a feeling of invisibility , of nonexistence . [Archer]214-archer , as [the three]3816-the three strolled back through [the park]1318-the park , was aware of this odd sense of disembodiment ; and humbling as it was to [his]304-mr. van der luyden vanity it gave [him]304-mr. van der luyden the ghostly advantage of observing unobserved . [Beaufort]230-beaufort had entered [the little house]3297-the little house with [his]304-mr. van der luyden usual easy assurance ; but [he]304-mr. van der luyden could not smile away the vertical line between [his]304-mr. van der luyden eyes . It was fairly clear that [Madame Olenska]240-madame olenska had not known that [he]304-mr. van der luyden was coming , though [her]240-madame olenska words to [Archer]214-archer had hinted at the possibility ; at any rate , [she]240-madame olenska had evidently not told [him]304-mr. van der luyden where [she]240-madame olenska was going when [she]240-madame olenska left [New York]2-new york , and [her]240-madame olenska unexplained departure had exasperated [him]304-mr. van der luyden . The ostensible reason of [his]304-mr. van der luyden appearance was the discovery , the very night before , of [a "[240-madame olenska] perfect little house]3819-a " perfect little house , " not in [the market]3820-the market , which was really just the thing for [her]240-madame olenska , but would be snapped up instantly if [she]240-madame olenska did n't take it ; and [he]304-mr. van der luyden was loud in mock - reproaches for the dance [she]240-madame olenska had led [him]304-mr. van der luyden in running away just as [he]304-mr. van der luyden had found it . "[240-madame olenska] If only this new dodge for talking along a wire had been a little bit nearer perfection [I]0-i might have told [you]1674-you all this from [town]1128-town , and been toasting [my]0-i toes before the club fire at this minute , instead of tramping after [you]1674-you through the snow , " [he]304-mr. van der luyden grumbled , disguising a real irritation under the pretence of it ; and at this opening [Madame Olenska]240-madame olenska twisted the talk away to the fantastic possibility that [they]3821-they might one day actually converse with [each other]695-each other from [street]3823-street to [street]3823-street , or even -- incredible dream!--from [one town]3825-one town to another . This struck from all three allusions to [Edgar Poe]399-edgar poe and [Jules Verne]400-jules verne , and such platitudes as naturally rise to the lips of the most intelligent when [they]3821-they are talking against time , and dealing with a new invention in which it would seem ingenuous to believe too soon ; and the question of the telephone carried [them]3821-they safely back to [the big house]3826-the big house . [Mrs. van der Luyden]297-mrs. van der luyden had not yet returned ; and [Archer]214-archer took [his]304-mr. van der luyden leave and walked off to fetch the cutter , while [Beaufort]230-beaufort followed [the Countess Olenska]234-the countess olenska [indoors]3827-indoors . It was probable that , little as [the van der Luydens]275-the van der luydens encouraged unannounced visits , [he]304-mr. van der luyden could count on being asked to dine , and sent back to [the station]3828-the station to catch [the nine o'clock train]3829-the nine o'clock train ; but more than that [he]304-mr. van der luyden would certainly not get , for it would be inconceivable to [[his]304-mr. van der luyden hosts]3830-his hosts that [a gentleman travelling without luggage]3831-a gentleman travelling without luggage should wish to spend the night , and distasteful to [them]3830-his hosts to propose it to [a person with whom [they]3830-his hosts were on terms of such limited cordiality as [Beaufort]230-beaufort]3832-a person with whom they were on terms of such limited cordiality as beaufort . [Beaufort]230-beaufort knew all this , and must have foreseen it ; and [his]304-mr. van der luyden taking the long journey for so small a reward gave the measure of [his]304-mr. van der luyden impatience . [He]304-mr. van der luyden was undeniably in pursuit of [the Countess Olenska]234-the countess olenska ; and [Beaufort]230-beaufort had only one object in view in [his]304-mr. van der luyden pursuit of [pretty women]3833-pretty women . [[His]304-mr. van der luyden dull and childless home]3834-his dull and childless home had long since palled on [him]304-mr. van der luyden ; and in addition to more permanent consolations [he]304-mr. van der luyden was always in quest of amorous adventures in [his]304-mr. van der luyden own set . This was [the man from whom [Madame Olenska]240-madame olenska]3835-the man from whom madame olenska was avowedly flying : the question was whether [she]240-madame olenska had fled because [his]304-mr. van der luyden importunities displeased [her]240-madame olenska , or because [she]240-madame olenska did not wholly trust [herself]240-madame olenska to resist [them]3836-them ; unless , indeed , all [her]240-madame olenska talk of flight had been a blind , and [her]240-madame olenska departure no more than a manoeuvre . [Archer]214-archer did not really believe this . Little as [he]304-mr. van der luyden had actually seen of [Madame Olenska]240-madame olenska , [he]304-mr. van der luyden was beginning to think that [he]304-mr. van der luyden could read [her]240-madame olenska face , and if not [her]240-madame olenska face , [her]240-madame olenska voice ; and both had betrayed annoyance , and even dismay , at [Beaufort]230-beaufort 's sudden appearance . But , after all , if this were the case , was it not worse than if [she]240-madame olenska had left [New York]2-new york for the express purpose of meeting [him]304-mr. van der luyden ? If [she]240-madame olenska had done that , [she]240-madame olenska ceased to be an object of interest , [she]240-madame olenska threw in [her]240-madame olenska lot with the vulgarest of [dissemblers]3837-dissemblers : [a woman engaged in a love affair with [Beaufort]230-beaufort "[240-madame olenska] classed " [herself]240-madame olenska irretrievably]3838-a woman engaged in a love affair with beaufort " classed " herself irretrievably . No , it was worse a thousand times if , judging [Beaufort]230-beaufort , and probably despising [him]304-mr. van der luyden , [she]240-madame olenska was yet drawn to [him]304-mr. van der luyden by all that gave [him]304-mr. van der luyden an advantage over [the other men]3839-the other men about [her]240-madame olenska : [his]304-mr. van der luyden habit of [two continents]3840-two continents and two societies , [his]304-mr. van der luyden familiar association with [artists]3520-artists and [actors]1544-actors and [people]637-people generally in [the world]580-the world 's eye , and [his]304-mr. van der luyden careless contempt for local prejudices . [Beaufort]230-beaufort was vulgar , [he]304-mr. van der luyden was uneducated , [he]304-mr. van der luyden was purse - proud ; but the circumstances of [his]304-mr. van der luyden life , and a certain native shrewdness , made [him]304-mr. van der luyden better worth talking to than [many men]3845-many men , morally and socially [[his]304-mr. van der luyden betters]3846-his betters , whose horizon was bounded by [the Battery]12-the battery and [the Central Park]3847-the central park . How should any one coming from [a wider world]3848-a wider world not feel the difference and be attracted by it ? [Madame Olenska]240-madame olenska , in a burst of irritation , had said to [Archer]214-archer that [he]304-mr. van der luyden and [she]240-madame olenska did not talk the same language ; and [the young man]527-the young man knew that in some respects this was true . But [Beaufort]230-beaufort understood every turn of [her]240-madame olenska dialect , and spoke it fluently : [his]304-mr. van der luyden view of life , [his]304-mr. van der luyden tone , [his]304-mr. van der luyden attitude , were merely a coarser reflection of those revealed in [Count Olenski]278-count olenski 's letter . This might seem to be to [his]304-mr. van der luyden disadvantage with [[Count Olenski]278-count olenski 's wife]3590-count olenski 's wife ; but [Archer]214-archer was too intelligent to think that [a young woman like [Ellen Olenska]232-ellen]3851-a young woman like ellen olenska would necessarily recoil from everything that reminded [her]3851-a young woman like ellen olenska of [her]3851-a young woman like ellen olenska past . [She]3851-a young woman like ellen olenska might believe [herself]3851-a young woman like ellen olenska wholly in revolt against it ; but what had charmed [her]3851-a young woman like ellen olenska in it would still charm [her]3851-a young woman like ellen olenska , even though it were against [her]3851-a young woman like ellen olenska will . Thus , with a painful impartiality , did [the young man]527-the young man make out the case for [Beaufort]230-beaufort , and for [[Beaufort]230-beaufort 's victim]3853-beaufort 's victim . A longing to enlighten [her]3853-beaufort 's victim was strong in [him]304-mr. van der luyden ; and there were moments when [he]304-mr. van der luyden imagined that all [she]3853-beaufort 's victim asked was to be enlightened . That evening [he]304-mr. van der luyden unpacked [his]304-mr. van der luyden books from [London]79-london . The box was full of things [he]304-mr. van der luyden had been waiting for impatiently ; a new volume of [Herbert Spencer]401-herbert spencer , another collection of the prolific [Alphonse Daudet]402-alphonse daudet 's brilliant tales , and a novel called "[240-madame olenska] Middlemarch , " as to which there had lately been interesting things said in the reviews . [He]304-mr. van der luyden had declined three dinner invitations in favour of this feast ; but though [he]304-mr. van der luyden turned the pages with the sensuous joy of the book - lover , [he]304-mr. van der luyden did not know what [he]304-mr. van der luyden was reading , and one book after another dropped from [his]304-mr. van der luyden hand . Suddenly , among them , [he]304-mr. van der luyden lit on a small volume of verse which [he]304-mr. van der luyden had ordered because the name had attracted [him]304-mr. van der luyden : "[240-madame olenska] [The House of Life]1676-the house of life . " [He]304-mr. van der luyden took it up , and found [himself]304-mr. van der luyden plunged in an atmosphere unlike any [he]304-mr. van der luyden had ever breathed in books ; so warm , so rich , and yet so ineffably tender , that it gave a new and haunting beauty to the most elementary of human passions . All through the night [he]304-mr. van der luyden pursued through those enchanted pages the vision of [a woman who had the face of [Ellen Olenska]232-ellen]3854-a woman who had the face of ellen olenska ; but when [he]304-mr. van der luyden woke the next morning , and looked out at [the brownstone houses across the street]3855-the brownstone houses across the street , and thought of [his]304-mr. van der luyden desk in [[Mr. Letterblair]357-mr. letterblair 's office]3464-mr. letterblair 's office , and [the family pew in [Grace Church]97-grace church]3857-the family pew in grace church , [his]304-mr. van der luyden hour in [the park of [Skuytercliff]57-skuytercliff]3858-the park of skuytercliff became as far outside the pale of probability as the visions of the night . "[348-mercy] [Mercy]348-mercy , how pale [you]1677-you look , [Newland]214-archer ! " [Janey]263-janey commented over the coffee - cups at breakfast ; and [[his]3127-dear mother]528-his mother added : "[214-archer] [Newland]214-archer , [dear]3127-dear , [I]0-i 've noticed lately that [you]3127-dear 've been coughing ; [I]0-i do hope [you]3127-dear 're not letting [yourself]3127-dear be overworked ? " For it was the conviction of [both ladies]3860-both ladies that , under the iron despotism of [[his]304-mr. van der luyden senior partners]3861-his senior partners , [the young man]527-the young man 's life was spent in the most exhausting professional labours -- and [he]304-mr. van der luyden had never thought it necessary to undeceive [them]3861-his senior partners . The next two or three days dragged by heavily . The taste of the usual was like cinders in [his]304-mr. van der luyden mouth , and there were moments when [he]304-mr. van der luyden felt as if [he]304-mr. van der luyden were being buried alive under [his]304-mr. van der luyden future . [He]304-mr. van der luyden heard nothing of [the Countess Olenska]234-the countess olenska , or of [the perfect little house]3863-the perfect little house , and though [he]304-mr. van der luyden met [Beaufort]230-beaufort at [the club]1433-the club [they]3865-they merely nodded at [each other]695-each other across the whist - tables . "[0-i] Come late tomorrow : [I]0-i must explain to [you]1679-you . [Ellen]232-ellen . " These were the only words it contained . [The young man , who was dining out]3868-the young man , who was dining out , thrust the note into [his]304-mr. van der luyden pocket , smiling a little at the Frenchness of the "[0-i] to [you]1679-you . " After dinner [he]304-mr. van der luyden went to a play ; and it was not until [his]304-mr. van der luyden return [home]649-home , after midnight , that [he]304-mr. van der luyden drew [Madame Olenska]240-madame olenska 's missive out again and re - read it slowly a number of times . There were several ways of answering it , and [he]304-mr. van der luyden gave considerable thought to each one during the watches of an agitated night . That on which , when morning came , [he]304-mr. van der luyden finally decided was to pitch some clothes into a portmanteau and jump on board [a boat that was leaving]3870-a boat that was leaving that very afternoon for [St. Augustine]91-st. augustine . XVI . When [Archer]214-archer walked down [the sandy main street of St. Augustine]3871-the sandy main street of st. augustine to [the house which had been pointed out to [him]304-mr. van der luyden as [Mr. Welland]339-mr. welland 's]3872-the house which had been pointed out to him as mr. welland 's , and saw [May Welland]221-may standing under a magnolia with the sun in [her]221-may hair , [he]304-mr. van der luyden wondered why [he]304-mr. van der luyden had waited so long to come . Here was the truth , here was reality , here was the life that belonged to [him]304-mr. van der luyden ; and [he]304-mr. van der luyden , who fancied [himself]304-mr. van der luyden so scornful of arbitrary restraints , had been afraid to break away from [his]304-mr. van der luyden desk because of what [people]637-people might think of [his]304-mr. van der luyden stealing a holiday ! [Her]221-may first exclamation was : "[0-i] [Newland]214-archer -- has anything happened ? " and it occurred to [him]304-mr. van der luyden that it would have been more "[0-i] feminine " if [she]221-may had instantly read in [his]304-mr. van der luyden eyes why [he]304-mr. van der luyden had come . But when [he]304-mr. van der luyden answered : "[0-i] Yes -- [I]0-i found [I]0-i had to see [you]1680-you , " [her]221-may happy blushes took the chill from [her]221-may surprise , and [he]304-mr. van der luyden saw how easily [he]304-mr. van der luyden would be forgiven , and how soon even [Mr. Letterblair]357-mr. letterblair 's mild disapproval would be smiled away by [a tolerant family]3874-a tolerant family . Early as it was , [the main street]3875-the main street was [no place for any but formal greetings]3876-no place for any but formal greetings , and [Archer]214-archer longed to be alone with [May]221-may , and to pour out all [his]304-mr. van der luyden tenderness and [his]304-mr. van der luyden impatience . It still lacked an hour to [the late Welland]221-may breakfast - time , and instead of asking [him]304-mr. van der luyden to come in [she]221-may proposed that [they]3877-they should walk out to [an old orange - garden]3878-an old orange - garden beyond [the town]3720-the town . [She]221-may had just been for a row on [the river]3880-the river , and the sun that netted the little waves with gold seemed to have caught [her]221-may in its meshes . Across the warm brown of [her]221-may cheek [her]221-may blown hair glittered like silver wire ; and [her]221-may eyes too looked lighter , almost pale in their youthful limpidity . As [she]221-may walked beside [Archer]214-archer with [her]221-may long swinging gait [her]221-may face wore the vacant serenity of [a young marble athlete]3881-a young marble athlete . To [Archer]214-archer 's strained nerves the vision was as soothing as the sight of the blue sky and [the lazy river]3882-the lazy river . [They]3877-they sat down on a bench under the orange - trees and [he]304-mr. van der luyden put [his]304-mr. van der luyden arm about [her]221-may and kissed [her]221-may . It was like drinking at a cold spring with the sun on it ; but [his]304-mr. van der luyden pressure may have been more vehement than [he]304-mr. van der luyden had intended , for the blood rose to [her]221-may face and [she]221-may drew back as if [he]304-mr. van der luyden had startled [her]221-may . "[0-i] What is it ? " [he]304-mr. van der luyden asked , smiling ; and [she]221-may looked at [him]304-mr. van der luyden with surprise , and answered : "[0-i] Nothing . " A slight embarrassment fell on [them]3877-they , and [her]221-may hand slipped out of [his]304-mr. van der luyden . It was the only time that [he]304-mr. van der luyden had kissed [her]221-may on the lips except for [their]3877-they fugitive embrace in [the Beaufort conservatory]3883-the beaufort conservatory , and [he]304-mr. van der luyden saw that [she]221-may was disturbed , and shaken out of [her]221-may cool boyish composure . "[0-i] Tell [me]0-i what [you]1681-you do all day , " [he]304-mr. van der luyden said , crossing [his]304-mr. van der luyden arms under [his]304-mr. van der luyden tilted - back head , and pushing [his]304-mr. van der luyden hat forward to screen the sun - dazzle . To let [her]221-may talk about familiar and simple things was the easiest way of carrying on [his]304-mr. van der luyden own independent train of thought ; and [he]304-mr. van der luyden sat listening to [her]221-may simple chronicle of swimming , sailing and riding , varied by an occasional dance at [the primitive inn]3884-the primitive inn when [a man - of - war]3885-a man - of - war came in . [A few pleasant people from [Philadelphia]29-philadelphia and [Baltimore]49-baltimore]3886-a few pleasant people from philadelphia and baltimore were picknicking at [the inn]3887-the inn , and [the Selfridge Merrys]283-the selfridge merrys had come down for three weeks because [Kate Merry]403-kate merry had had bronchitis . "[1682-they] [The doctors]1683-the doctors want [[my]0-i husband]3236-my husband to feel that [he]3236-my husband is in [[his]3236-my husband own home]1685-his own home ; otherwise [he]3236-my husband would be so wretched that the climate would not do [him]3236-my husband any good , " [she]0-i explained , winter after winter , to the sympathising Philadelphians and [Baltimoreans]3900-baltimoreans ; and [Mr. Welland]339-mr. welland , beaming across a breakfast table miraculously supplied with the most varied delicacies , was presently saying to [Archer]214-archer : "[1686-you] [You]1686-you see , [[my]0-i dear fellow]3209-my dear fellow , [we]1688-we camp -- [we]1688-we literally camp . " [Mr.]3901-mr. and [Mrs. Welland]218-mrs. welland had been as much surprised as [[their]1690-them daughter]3902-their daughter by [the young man]527-the young man 's sudden arrival ; but it had occurred to [him]527-the young man to explain that [he]527-the young man had felt [himself]527-the young man on the verge of a nasty cold , and this seemed to [Mr. Welland]339-mr. welland an all - sufficient reason for abandoning any duty . "[0-i] [I]0-i 'm afraid [Ellen]232-ellen 's ideas are not at all like [ours]1695-ours . [She]232-ellen was barely eighteen when [Medora Manson]229-medora manson took [her]232-ellen back to [Europe]14-europe -- [you]1696-you remember the excitement when [she]232-ellen appeared in black at [her]232-ellen coming - out ball ? " "[232-ellen] But European society is not given to divorce : [Countess Olenska]234-the countess olenska thought [she]232-ellen would be conforming to American ideas in asking for [her]232-ellen freedom . " It was the first time that [the young man]527-the young man had pronounced [her]232-ellen name since [he]527-the young man had left [Skuytercliff]57-skuytercliff , and [he]527-the young man felt the colour rise to [his]527-the young man cheek . [Mrs. Welland]218-mrs. welland smiled compassionately . "[232-ellen] That is just like the extraordinary things that [foreigners]751-foreigners invent about [us]1698-we . [They]751-foreigners think [we]1698-we dine at two o'clock and [countenance divorce]1699-countenance divorce ! " [Archer]255-archer made no comment on this , and [Mrs. Welland]218-mrs. welland continued : "[751-foreigners] But [we]1698-we do most thoroughly appreciate [your]1701-he persuading [Ellen]232-ellen to give up the idea . [[Her]232-ellen grandmother]853-her grandmother and [[her]232-ellen uncle]1703-her uncle [Lovell]217-mrs. lovell mingott could do nothing with [her]232-ellen ; [both of [them]1704-both of them]1704-both of them have written that [her]232-ellen changing [her]232-ellen mind was entirely due to [your]1701-he influence -- in fact [she]232-ellen said so to [[her]232-ellen grandmother]853-her grandmother . " [He]1701-he wondered what [Mrs. Welland]218-mrs. welland would have said if [he]1701-he had uttered the words instead of merely thinking them . [He]1701-he could picture the sudden decomposure of [her]276-ellen firm placid features , to which a lifelong mastery over trifles had given an air of factitious authority . [Traces]407-traces still lingered on them of a fresh beauty like [[her]276-ellen daughter]553-her daughter 's ; and [he]1701-he asked [himself]1701-he if [May]221-may 's face was doomed to thicken into the same middle - aged image of invincible innocence . Ah , no , [he]1701-he did not want [May]221-may to have that kind of innocence , the innocence that seals the mind against imagination and the heart against experience ! "[1701-he] [I]0-i verily believe , " [Mrs. Welland]218-mrs. welland continued , "[0-i] that if the horrible business had come out in the newspapers it would have been [[my]0-i husband]3236-my husband 's death - blow . [I]0-i do n't know any of the details ; [I]0-i only ask not to , as [I]0-i told poor [Ellen]276-ellen when [she]276-ellen tried to talk to [me]0-i about it . Having [an invalid]3690-an invalid to care for , [I]0-i have to keep [my]0-i mind bright and happy . But [Mr. Welland]339-mr. welland was terribly upset ; [he]339-mr. welland had a slight temperature every morning while [we]1713-we were waiting to hear what had been decided . It was the horror of [[his]339-mr. welland girl]1714-his girl 's learning that such things were possible -- but of course , [dear Newland]214-archer , [you]214-archer felt that too . [We]1713-we all knew that [you]214-archer were thinking of [May]221-may . " "[214-archer] [I]0-i 'm always thinking of [May]221-may , " [the young man]527-the young man rejoined , rising to cut short the conversation . [He]527-the young man had meant to seize the opportunity of [his]527-the young man private talk with [Mrs. Welland]218-mrs. welland to urge [her]218-mrs. welland to advance the date of [his]527-the young man marriage . But [he]527-the young man could think of no arguments that would move [her]218-mrs. welland , and with a sense of relief [he]527-the young man saw [Mr. Welland]339-mr. welland and [May]221-may driving up to the door . [His]527-the young man only hope was to plead again with [May]221-may , and on the day before [his]527-the young man departure [he]527-the young man walked with [her]221-may to [the ruinous garden of [the Spanish Mission]3917-the spanish mission]3916-the ruinous garden of the spanish mission . The background lent itself to allusions to European scenes ; and [May]221-may , who was looking [her]221-may loveliest under a wide - brimmed hat that cast a shadow of mystery over [her]221-may too - clear eyes , kindled into eagerness as [he]527-the young man spoke of [Granada]100-granada and [the Alhambra]101-the alhambra . "[0-i] [We]1715-we might be seeing it all this spring -- even the Easter ceremonies at [Seville]102-seville , " [he]527-the young man urged , exaggerating [his]527-the young man demands in the hope of a larger concession . "[221-may] Easter in [Seville]102-seville ? And it will be Lent next week ! " [she]221-may laughed . "[221-may] Why should n't [we]1715-we be married in [Lent]257-lent ? " [he]527-the young man rejoined ; but [she]221-may looked so shocked that [he]527-the young man saw [his]527-the young man mistake . "[221-may] Of course [I]0-i did n't mean that , [dearest]1716-dearest ; but soon after Easter -- so that [we]1715-we could sail at the end of April . [I]0-i know [I]0-i could arrange it at [the office]3721-the office . " [She]221-may smiled dreamily upon the possibility ; but [he]527-the young man perceived that to dream of it sufficed [her]221-may . It was like hearing [him]527-the young man read aloud out of [his]527-the young man poetry books the beautiful things that could not possibly happen in real life . "[0-i] Oh , do go on , [Newland]214-archer ; [I]0-i do love [your]214-archer descriptions . " "[214-archer] But why should they be only descriptions ? Why should n't [we]1715-we make them real ? " "[1715-we] [We]1715-we shall , [dearest]1716-dearest , of course ; next year . " [Her]221-may voice lingered over it . "[1715-we] Do n't [you]214-archer want [them]1719-them to be real sooner ? Ca n't [I]0-i persuade [you]214-archer to break away now ? " [She]221-may bowed [her]221-may head , vanishing from [him]3127-dear under [her]221-may conniving hat - brim . "[0-i] Why should [we]1715-we dream away another year ? Look at [me]0-i , [dear]3127-dear ! Do n't [you]214-archer understand how [I]0-i want [you]214-archer for [[my]0-i wife]3124-my wife ? " For a moment [she]221-may remained motionless ; then [she]221-may raised on [him]3127-dear eyes of such despairing dearness that [he]3127-dear half - released [her]221-may waist from [his]3127-dear hold . But suddenly [her]221-may look changed and deepened inscrutably . "[214-archer] [I]0-i 'm not sure if [I]0-i DO understand , " [she]221-may said . "[0-i] Is it -- is it because [you]214-archer 're not certain of continuing to care for [me]0-i ? " [Archer]214-archer sprang up from [his]3127-dear seat . May Welland rose also ; as [they]3918-they faced [each other]695-each other [she]221-may seemed to grow in womanly stature and dignity . [Both]3920-both were silent for a moment , as if dismayed by the unforeseen trend of [their]3918-they words : then [she]221-may said in a low voice : "[0-i] If that is it -- is there some one else ? " "[0-i] Some one else -- between [you]214-archer and [me]0-i ? " [He]3127-dear echoed [her]221-may words slowly , as though they were only half - intelligible and [he]3127-dear wanted time to repeat the question to [himself]3127-dear . [She]221-may seemed to catch the uncertainty of [his]3127-dear voice , for [she]221-may went on in a deepening tone : "[0-i] Let [us]1723-us talk frankly , [Newland]214-archer . Sometimes [I]0-i 've felt a difference in [you]214-archer ; especially since [our]1723-us engagement has been announced . " "[3127-dear] [Dear]3127-dear -- what madness ! " [he]3127-dear recovered [himself]3127-dear to exclaim . [She]221-may met [his]3127-dear protest with a faint smile . "[3127-dear] If it is , it wo n't hurt [us]1723-us to talk about it . " [She]221-may paused , and added , lifting [her]221-may head with one of [her]221-may noble movements : "[3127-dear] Or even if it 's true : why should n't [we]1723-us speak of it ? [You]214-archer might so easily have made a mistake . " [He]3127-dear lowered [his]3127-dear head , staring at the black leaf - pattern on the sunny path at [their]1723-us feet . "[214-archer] Mistakes are always easy to make ; but if [I]0-i had made one of the kind [you]214-archer suggest , is it likely that [I]0-i should be imploring [you]214-archer to hasten [our]1723-us marriage ? "[0-i] [You]214-archer might want -- once for all -- to settle the question : it 's one way . " [Her]221-may quiet lucidity startled [him]3127-dear , but did not mislead [him]3127-dear into thinking [her]221-may insensible . Under [her]221-may hat - brim [he]3127-dear saw the pallor of [her]221-may profile , and a slight tremor of the nostril above [her]221-may resolutely steadied lips . "[0-i] Well-- ? " [he]3127-dear questioned , sitting down on the bench , and looking up at [her]221-may with a frown that [he]3127-dear tried to make playful . [One]519-one hears and [one]519-one notices -- [one]519-one has [one]519-one 's feelings and ideas . " [Her]1734-her voice had sunk almost to a whisper , and [she]1734-her sat clasping and unclasping [her]1734-her hands about the handle of [her]1734-her sunshade . "[0-i] [[My]0-i dear child]1737-my dear child -- was THAT it ? If [you]0-i only knew the truth ! " [She]1734-her raised [her]1734-her head quickly . "[0-i] Then there is a truth [I]0-i do n't know ? " [Her]0-i face had taken on a look of such tragic courage that [he]1737-my dear child felt like bowing [himself]1737-my dear child down at [her]0-i feet . " [His]1737-my dear child surprise at discovering that [her]0-i fears had fastened upon an episode so remote and so completely of the past as [his]1737-my dear child love - affair with [Mrs. Thorley Rushworth]242-mrs. thorley rushworth gave way to wonder at the generosity of [her]0-i view . There was something superhuman in an attitude so recklessly unorthodox , and if other problems had not pressed on [him]1737-my dear child [he]1737-my dear child would have been lost in wonder at [the prodigy of [[the Wellands]324-the wellands ' daughter]3924-the wellands ' daughter urging [him]1737-my dear child to marry [[his]1737-my dear child former mistress]3925-his former mistress]3923-the prodigy of the wellands ' daughter urging him to marry his former mistress . Such cases do n't always -- present [themselves]1744-themselves quite as simply as ... But that 's no matter ... [I]0-i mean , [each woman]1745-each woman 's right to [her]1745-each woman liberty-- " [He]1737-my dear child pulled [himself]1737-my dear child up , startled by the turn [his]1737-my dear child thoughts had taken , and went on , looking at [her]1743-her with a smile : "[0-i] Since [you]1743-her understand so many things , [dearest]1716-dearest , ca n't [you]1743-her go a little farther , and understand the uselessness of [our]1747-our submitting to another form of the same foolish conventionalities ? If there 's [no one]619-no one and nothing between [us]1747-our , is n't that an argument for marrying quickly , rather than for more delay ? " [She]1743-her flushed with joy and lifted [her]1743-her face to [his]1737-my dear child ; as [he]1737-my dear child bent to it [he]1737-my dear child saw that [her]1743-her eyes were full of happy tears . But in another moment [she]1743-her seemed to have descended from [her]1743-her womanly eminence to helpless and timorous girlhood ; and [he]1737-my dear child understood that [her]1743-her courage and initiative were all for [others]3523-others , and that [she]1743-her had none for [herself]1743-her . It was evident that the effort of speaking had been much greater than [her]1743-her studied composure betrayed , and that at [his]1737-my dear child first word of reassurance [she]1743-her had dropped back into the usual , as [a too - adventurous child]3929-a too - adventurous child takes refuge in [[its]3929-a too - adventurous child mother]3930-its mother 's arms . [Archer]214-archer had no heart to go on pleading with [her]1743-her ; [he]1737-my dear child was too much disappointed at the vanishing of [the new being]3931-the new being who had cast that one deep look at [him]1737-my dear child from [her]1743-her transparent eyes . "[0-i] Whenever [you]1800-you like ; but it must be soon if [you]1800-you want to see [the little house]3297-the little house again . [I]0-i am moving next week . " A pang shot through [him]255-archer at the memory of [his]255-archer lamplit hours in [the low - studded drawing - room]3955-the low - studded drawing - room . Few as they had been , they were thick with memories . "[0-i] Tomorrow evening ? " [She]240-madame olenska nodded . "[0-i] Tomorrow ; yes ; but early . [I]0-i 'm going out . " The next day was a Sunday , and if [she]240-madame olenska were "[0-i] going out " on a Sunday evening it could , of course , be only to [[Mrs. Lemuel Struthers]259-mrs. struthers 's]3956-mrs. lemuel struthers 's . [He]255-archer felt a slight movement of annoyance , not so much at [her]240-madame olenska going [there]732-there ( for [he]255-archer rather liked [her]240-madame olenska going where [she]240-madame olenska pleased in spite of [the van der Luydens]275-the van der luydens ) , but because it was [the kind of house at which [she]240-madame olenska was sure to meet [Beaufort]230-beaufort , where [she]240-madame olenska must have known beforehand that [she]240-madame olenska would meet [him]255-archer]3958-the kind of house at which she was sure to meet beaufort , where she must have known beforehand that she would meet him -- and where [she]240-madame olenska was probably going for that purpose . "[0-i] Very well ; tomorrow evening , " [he]255-archer repeated , inwardly resolved that [he]255-archer would not go early , and that by reaching [her]240-madame olenska door late [he]255-archer would either prevent [her]240-madame olenska from going to [[Mrs. Struthers]259-mrs. struthers 's]3959-mrs. struthers 's , or else arrive after [she]240-madame olenska had started -- which , all things considered , would no doubt be the simplest solution . It was only half - past eight , after all , when [he]255-archer rang the bell under the wisteria ; not as late as [he]255-archer had intended by half an hour -- but a singular restlessness had driven [him]255-archer to [her]240-madame olenska door . [He]255-archer reflected , however , that [Mrs. Struthers]259-mrs. struthers 's Sunday evenings were not like a ball , and that [[her]240-madame olenska guests]3960-her guests , as if to minimise [their]3960-her guests delinquency , usually went early . The one thing [he]255-archer had not counted on , in entering [[Madame Olenska]240-madame olenska 's hall]3961-madame olenska 's hall , was to find hats and overcoats [there]732-there . Why had [she]240-madame olenska bidden [him]255-archer to come early if [she]240-madame olenska was having [people]637-people to dine ? On a closer inspection of the garments besides which [Nastasia]340-nastasia was laying [his]255-archer own , [his]255-archer resentment gave way to curiosity . The overcoats were in fact the very strangest [he]255-archer had ever seen under a polite roof ; and it took but a glance to assure [himself]255-archer that neither of them belonged to [Julius Beaufort]230-beaufort . [One]519-one was a shaggy yellow ulster of "[0-i] reach - [me]0-i - down " cut , the other a very old and rusty cloak with a cape -- something like what [the French]410-the french called a "[411-macfarlane] [Macfarlane]411-macfarlane . " This garment , which appeared to be made for [a person of prodigious size , had evidently seen long and hard wear]3965-a person of prodigious size , had evidently seen long and hard wear , and its greenish - black folds gave out a moist sawdusty smell suggestive of prolonged sessions against [bar - room walls]3966-bar - room walls . On it lay a ragged grey scarf and an odd felt hat of semiclerical shape . [Archer]255-archer raised [his]255-archer eyebrows enquiringly at [Nastasia]340-nastasia , who raised [hers]340-nastasia in return with a fatalistic "[412-gia] [Gia]412-gia ! " as [she]340-nastasia threw open the drawing - room door . [The young man]527-the young man saw at once that [[his]527-the young man hostess]1261-his hostess was not in [the room]991-the room ; then , with surprise , [he]527-the young man discovered another lady standing by the fire . [This lady]3970-this lady , who was long , lean and loosely put together , was clad in raiment intricately looped and fringed , with plaids and stripes and bands of plain colour disposed in a design to which the clue seemed missing . [Her]3970-this lady hair , which had tried to turn white and only succeeded in fading , was surmounted by a Spanish comb and black lace scarf , and silk mittens , visibly darned , covered [her]3970-this lady rheumatic hands . Beside [her]3970-this lady , in a cloud of cigar - smoke , stood [the owners of the two overcoats]3971-the owners of the two overcoats , both in morning clothes that [they]3971-the owners of the two overcoats had evidently not taken off since morning . In one of the two , [Archer]255-archer , to [his]255-archer surprise , recognised [Ned Winsett]326-winsett ; [the other]926-the other and older , who was unknown to [him]255-archer , and whose gigantic frame declared [him]255-archer to be [the wearer of [the "[412-gia] Macfarlane]411-macfarlane]3973-the wearer of the " macfarlane , " had a feebly leonine head with crumpled grey hair , and moved [his]255-archer arms with large pawing gestures , as though [he]255-archer were distributing lay blessings to [a kneeling multitude]3974-a kneeling multitude . [Madame Olenska]240-madame olenska did not move when [he]255-archer came up behind [her]240-madame olenska , and for a second [their]4004-their eyes met in the mirror ; then [she]240-madame olenska turned , threw [herself]240-madame olenska into [her]240-madame olenska sofa - corner , and sighed out : "[1856-my dear one] There 's time for a cigarette . " [He]255-archer handed [her]240-madame olenska the box and lit a spill for [her]240-madame olenska ; and as the flame flashed up into [her]240-madame olenska face [she]240-madame olenska glanced at [him]255-archer with laughing eyes and said : "[1856-my dear one] What do [you]1864-you think of [me]0-i in a temper ? " [Archer]255-archer paused a moment ; then [he]255-archer answered with sudden resolution : "[1864-you] It makes [me]0-i understand what [[your]0-i aunt]1865-your aunt has been saying about [you]0-i . " "[1865-your aunt] [I]0-i knew [she]1865-your aunt 'd been talking about [me]0-i . Well ? " "[1865-your aunt] [She]1865-your aunt said [you]1864-you were used to all kinds of things -- splendours and amusements and excitements -- that [we]1866-we could never hope to give [you]1864-you here . " [Madame Olenska]240-madame olenska smiled faintly into the circle of smoke about [her]240-madame olenska lips . "[1865-your aunt] [Medora]229-medora manson is incorrigibly romantic . It has made up to [her]1865-your aunt for so many things ! " [Archer]255-archer hesitated again , and again took [his]255-archer risk . "[1865-your aunt] Is [[your]1864-you aunt]1865-your aunt 's romanticism always consistent with accuracy ? " "[0-i] [You]0-i mean : does [she]1865-your aunt speak the truth ? " [[Her]240-madame olenska niece]4005-her niece considered . "[1865-your aunt] Well , [I]0-i 'll tell [you]1864-you : in almost everything [she]1865-your aunt says , there 's something true and something untrue . But why do [you]1864-you ask ? What has [she]1865-your aunt been telling [you]1864-you ? " [He]255-archer looked away into the fire , and then back at [her]1865-your aunt shining presence . [His]255-archer heart tightened with the thought that this was [their]4006-their last evening by that fireside , and that in a moment [the carriage]878-the carriage would come to carry [her]1865-your aunt away . "[1865-your aunt] [She]1865-your aunt says -- [she]1865-your aunt pretends that [Count Olenski]278-count olenski has asked [her]1865-your aunt to persuade [you]1864-you to go back to [him]278-count olenski . The expression of [her]240-madame olenska face had not changed ; and [Archer]255-archer remembered that [he]255-archer had before noticed [her]240-madame olenska apparent incapacity for surprise . "[1865-your aunt] [You]1868-you knew , then ? " [he]255-archer broke out . [She]240-madame olenska was silent for so long that the ash dropped from [her]240-madame olenska cigarette . [She]240-madame olenska brushed it to the floor . "[1865-your aunt] [She]1865-your aunt has hinted about a letter : [poor darling]1028-poor darling ! "[1865-your aunt] [You]0-i know that [[your]0-i aunt]1865-your aunt believes [you]0-i will go back ? " [Madame Olenska]240-madame olenska raised [her]240-madame olenska head quickly . [She]240-madame olenska blushed seldom and painfully , as if it hurt [her]240-madame olenska like a burn . "[0-i] Many cruel things have been believed of [me]0-i , " [she]240-madame olenska said . " [She]240-madame olenska pronounced the "[1879-we] [we]1879-we " with a faint emphasis that gave it an ironic sound . [Archer]255-archer felt the irony but did not dare to take it up . After all , [she]240-madame olenska had perhaps purposely deflected the conversation from [her]240-madame olenska own affairs , and after the pain [his]255-archer last words had evidently caused [her]240-madame olenska [he]255-archer felt that all [he]255-archer could do was to follow [her]240-madame olenska lead . But the sense of the waning hour made [him]255-archer desperate : [he]255-archer could not bear the thought that a barrier of words should drop between [them]1879-we again . " [Ellen Olenska]232-ellen made no answer , and did not move . [She]0-i started up , and freeing [herself]0-i from [him]255-archer moved away to the other side of the hearth . "[1890-another woman] Ah , do n't make love to [me]0-i ! [Too many people]1891-too many people have done that , " [she]0-i said , frowning . [Archer]255-archer , changing colour , stood up also : it was the bitterest rebuke [she]0-i could have given [him]255-archer . " "[1901-my poor newland] [You]1901-my poor newland say that because it 's the easiest thing to say at this moment -- not because it 's true . "[1901-my poor newland] Just imagine , " [she]0-i said , "[1901-my poor newland] how stupid and unobservant [I]0-i was ! And [I]0-i was so happy at being among [[my]0-i own people]1910-my own people that [every one [I]0-i met]1911-every one i met seemed kind and good , and glad to see [me]0-i . But from the very beginning , " [she]0-i continued , "[0-i] [I]0-i felt there was [no one]619-no one as kind as [you]1913-his ; [no one who gave [me]0-i reasons that [I]0-i understood for doing what at first seemed so hard and -- unnecessary]1914-no one who gave me reasons that i understood for doing what at first seemed so hard and -- unnecessary . [The very good people]1915-the very good people did n't convince [me]0-i ; [I]0-i felt [they]1915-the very good people 'd never been tempted . But [you]1913-his knew ; [you]1913-his understood ; [you]1913-his had felt the world outside tugging at one with all its golden hands -- and yet [you]1913-his hated the things it asks of [one]519-one ; [you]1913-his hated happiness bought by disloyalty and cruelty and indifference . That was what [I]0-i 'd never known before -- and it 's better than anything [I]0-i 've known . " [She]0-i spoke in a low even voice , without tears or visible agitation ; and each word , as it dropped from [her]0-i , fell into [his]1913-his breast like burning lead . [He]1913-his sat bowed over , [his]1913-his head between [his]1913-his hands , staring at the hearthrug , and at the tip of the satin shoe that showed under [her]0-i dress . [She]0-i bent over [him]1913-his , laying [her]0-i hands on [his]1913-his shoulders , and looking at [him]1913-his with eyes so deep that [he]1913-his remained motionless under [her]0-i gaze . "[0-i] Ah , do n't let [us]1917-us undo what [you]1918-you 've done ! " [she]0-i cried . "[0-i] [I]0-i ca n't go back now to that other way of thinking . [I]0-i ca n't love [you]1918-you unless [I]0-i give [you]1918-you up . Then , abruptly , [his]1913-his anger overflowed . "[230-beaufort] And [Beaufort]230-beaufort ? Is [he]1919-he to replace [me]0-i ? But [Madame Olenska]240-madame olenska only grew a shade paler , and stood with [her]240-madame olenska arms hanging down before [her]240-madame olenska , and [her]240-madame olenska head slightly bent , as [her]240-madame olenska way was when [she]240-madame olenska pondered a question . After the door had closed again [Archer]255-archer continued to look at [her]1918-you with bitter eyes . "[0-i] Why this sacrifice ? Since [you]1918-you tell [me]0-i that [you]1918-you 're lonely [I]0-i 've no right to keep [you]1918-you from [[your]1918-you friends]3310-your friends .
