" "[0-i] Yet [you]1918-you understand [May]221-may ! " [He]255-archer reddened under the retort , but kept [his]255-archer eyes on [her]1918-you . "[221-may] [May]221-may is ready to give [me]0-i up . " "[221-may] What ! Three days after [you]1918-you 've entreated [her]221-may on [your]1918-you knees to hasten [your]1918-you marriage ? " "[1918-you] [She]221-may 's refused ; that gives [me]0-i the right-- " "[1918-you] Ah , [you]1918-you 've taught [me]0-i what an ugly word that is , " [she]1918-you said . [He]255-archer turned away with a sense of utter weariness . [He]255-archer felt as though [he]255-archer had been struggling for hours up the face of a steep precipice , and now , just as [he]255-archer had fought [his]255-archer way to the top , [his]255-archer hold had given way and [he]255-archer was pitching down headlong into darkness . If [he]255-archer could have got [her]1918-you in [his]255-archer arms again [he]255-archer might have swept away [her]1918-you arguments ; but [she]1918-you still held [him]255-archer at a distance by something inscrutably aloof in [her]1918-you look and attitude , and by [his]255-archer own awed sense of [her]1918-you sincerity . At length [he]255-archer began to plead again . "[1918-you] If [we]1925-they do this now it will be worse afterward -- worse for every one-- " "[1918-you] No -- no -- no ! " [she]1918-you almost screamed , as if [he]255-archer frightened [her]1918-you . At that moment the bell sent a long tinkle through [the house]532-the house . [They]1925-they had heard [no carriage]4023-no carriage stopping at the door , and [they]1925-they stood motionless , looking at [each other]695-each other with startled eyes . Outside , [Nastasia]340-nastasia 's step crossed [the hall]755-the hall , the outer door opened , and a moment later [she]340-nastasia came in carrying a telegram which [she]340-nastasia handed to [the Countess Olenska]234-the countess olenska . "[1918-you] [The lady]681-the lady was very happy at the flowers , " [Nastasia]340-nastasia said , smoothing [her]340-nastasia apron . "[681-the lady] [She]681-the lady thought it was [[her]681-the lady signor]1927-her signor marito who had sent [them]1928-them , and [she]681-the lady cried a little and said it was a folly . " [[Her]340-nastasia mistress]1335-her mistress smiled and took the yellow envelope . [She]1335-her mistress tore it open and carried it to the lamp ; then , when the door had closed again , [she]1335-her mistress handed the telegram to [Archer]255-archer . It was dated from [St. Augustine]91-st. augustine , and addressed to [the Countess Olenska]234-the countess olenska . In it [he]255-archer read : "[681-the lady] [Granny]243-granny 's telegram successful . [Papa]406-papa and [Mamma]244-mamma agree marriage after Easter . Am telegraphing [Newland]214-archer . [Am]1929-am too happy for words and love [you]1930-you dearly . [Your]1930-you grateful May . " Half an hour later , when [Archer]255-archer unlocked [his]255-archer own front - door , [he]255-archer found a similar envelope on the hall - table on top of [his]255-archer pile of notes and letters . The message inside the envelope was also from [May Welland]221-may , and ran as follows : "[1930-you] [Parents]1931-parents consent wedding Tuesday after Easter at twelve Grace Church eight [bridesmaids]1932-bridesmaids please see [Rector]420-rector so happy love [May]221-may . " [Archer]255-archer crumpled up the yellow sheet as if the gesture could annihilate the news it contained . Then [he]255-archer pulled out a small pocket - diary and turned over the pages with trembling fingers ; but [he]255-archer did not find what [he]255-archer wanted , and cramming the telegram into [his]255-archer pocket [he]255-archer mounted the stairs . A light was shining through the door of [the little hall - room]4027-the little hall - room which served [Janey]263-janey as [a dressing - room]4028-a dressing - room and boudoir , and [[her]0-i brother]975-her brother rapped impatiently on the panel . The door opened , and [[his]255-archer sister]888-his sister stood before [him]255-archer in [her]888-his sister immemorial purple flannel dressing - gown , with [her]888-his sister hair "[221-may] on pins . " [Her]888-his sister face looked pale and apprehensive . "[221-may] [Newland]214-archer ! [I]0-i hope there 's no bad news in that telegram ? [I]0-i waited on purpose , in case-- " ( No item of [his]255-archer correspondence was safe from [Janey]263-janey . ) [He]255-archer took no notice of [her]888-his sister question . "[0-i] Look here -- what day is Easter this year ? " [She]888-his sister looked shocked at such unchristian ignorance . "[0-i] Easter ? [Newland]214-archer ! Why , of course , the first week in April . Why ? " "[0-i] The first week ? " [He]255-archer turned again to the pages of [his]255-archer diary , calculating rapidly under [his]255-archer breath . "[0-i] The first week , did [you]0-i say ? " [He]255-archer threw back [his]255-archer head with a long laugh . "[0-i] For mercy 's sake what 's the matter ? " "[0-i] Nothing 's the matter , except that [I]0-i 'm going to be married in a month . " [Janey]263-janey fell upon [his]255-archer neck and pressed [him]255-archer to [her]888-his sister purple flannel breast . "[0-i] Oh [Newland]214-archer , how wonderful ! [I]0-i 'm so glad ! But , [dearest]1716-dearest , why do [you]214-archer keep on laughing ? Do hush , or [you]214-archer 'll wake [Mamma]244-mamma . " Book II XIX . The day was fresh , with a lively spring wind full of dust . [All the old ladies in [both families]4032-both families]4031-all the old ladies in both families had got out [their]4031-all the old ladies in both families faded sables and yellowing ermines , and the smell of camphor from the front pews almost smothered the faint spring scent of the lilies banking the altar . [Newland Archer]214-archer , at a signal from [the sexton]4033-the sexton , had come out of [the vestry]4034-the vestry and placed [himself]214-archer with [[his]255-archer best man]4035-his best man on [the chancel step of [Grace Church]97-grace church]4036-the chancel step of grace church . The signal meant that the brougham bearing [the bride]4037-the bride and [[her]4037-the bride father]3653-her father was in sight ; but there was sure to be a considerable interval of adjustment and consultation in [the lobby]3664-the lobby , where [the bridesmaids]4040-the bridesmaids were already hovering like a cluster of Easter blossoms . During this unavoidable lapse of time [the bridegroom]4041-the bridegroom , in proof of [his]4041-the bridegroom eagerness , was expected to expose [himself]4041-the bridegroom alone to the gaze of [the assembled company]4042-the assembled company ; and [Archer]214-archer had gone through this formality as resignedly as through all the others which made of a nineteenth century [New York]2-new york wedding a rite that seemed to belong to the dawn of history . Everything was equally easy -- or equally painful , as [one]519-one chose to put it -- in the path [he]255-archer was committed to tread , and [he]255-archer had obeyed the flurried injunctions of [[his]255-archer best man]4035-his best man as piously as [other bridegrooms]4045-other bridegrooms had obeyed [his]255-archer own , in the days when [he]255-archer had guided [them]4045-other bridegrooms through the same labyrinth . So far [he]255-archer was reasonably sure of having fulfilled all [his]255-archer obligations . [The bridesmaids]4040-the bridesmaids ' eight bouquets of white lilac and lilies - of - [the - valley]558-the - valley had been sent in due time , as well as the gold and sapphire sleeve - links of [the eight ushers]4048-the eight ushers and [the best man]4049-the best man 's cat's - eye scarf - pin ; [Archer]214-archer had sat up half the night trying to vary the wording of [his]255-archer thanks for the last batch of presents from [men friends]4050-men friends and [ex - lady - loves]4051-ex - lady - loves ; the fees for [the Bishop]4052-the bishop and [the Rector]4053-the rector were safely in the pocket of [[his]255-archer best man]4035-his best man ; [his]255-archer own luggage was already at [[Mrs. Manson Mingott]216-mrs. manson mingott 's]4055-mrs. manson mingott 's , where the wedding - breakfast was to take place , and so were the travelling clothes into which [he]255-archer was to change ; and a private compartment had been engaged in [the train that was to carry [the young couple]4057-the young couple to]4056-the train that was to carry the young couple to [[their]4057-the young couple unknown destination]4058-their unknown destination -- concealment of the spot in which the bridal night was to be spent being one of the most sacred taboos of the prehistoric ritual . "[244-mamma] Got the ring all right ? " whispered [young van der Luyden Newland , who was inexperienced in the duties of [a best man]4059-a best man , and awed by the weight of [his]421-young van der luyden newland , who was inexperienced in the duties of a best man , and awed by the weight of his responsibility responsibility]421-young van der luyden newland , who was inexperienced in the duties of a best man , and awed by the weight of his responsibility . [Archer]214-archer made the gesture which [he]255-archer had seen so many [bridegrooms]4060-bridegrooms make : with [his]255-archer ungloved right hand [he]255-archer felt in the pocket of [his]255-archer dark grey waistcoat , and assured [himself]255-archer that the little gold circlet ( engraved inside : [Newland]214-archer to May , April --- , 187- ) was in its place ; then , resuming [his]255-archer former attitude , [his]255-archer tall hat and pearl - grey gloves with black stitchings grasped in [his]255-archer left hand , [he]255-archer stood looking at the door of [the church]4061-the church . Overhead , [Handel]422-handel 's March swelled pompously through the imitation stone vaulting , carrying on its waves the faded drift of the many weddings at which , with cheerful indifference , [he]255-archer had stood on the same chancel step watching [other brides]4062-other brides float up [the nave]4063-the nave toward [other bridegrooms]4045-other bridegrooms . "[244-mamma] How like a first night at [the Opera]517-the opera ! " [he]255-archer thought , recognising all the same faces in the same boxes ( no , pews ) , and wondering if , when the Last Trump sounded , [Mrs. Selfridge Merry]423-mrs. selfridge merry would be there with the same towering ostrich feathers in [her]423-mrs. selfridge merry bonnet , and [Mrs. Beaufort]230-beaufort with the same diamond earrings and the same smile -- and whether suitable proscenium seats were already prepared for [them]4065-them in [another world]4066-another world . After that there was still time to review , one by one , [the familiar countenances in the first rows]4067-the familiar countenances in the first rows ; [the women]4068-the women 's sharp with curiosity and excitement , [the men]1267-the men 's sulky with the obligation of having to put on [their]1267-the men frock - coats before luncheon , and fight for food at the wedding - breakfast . "[244-mamma] Too bad the breakfast is at [old [Catherine]409-old catherine 's]1935-old catherine 's , " [the bridegroom]4041-the bridegroom could fancy [Reggie Chivers]396-reggie chivers saying . "[409-old catherine] But [I]0-i 'm told that [Lovell Mingott]217-mrs. lovell mingott insisted on its being cooked by [[his]217-mrs. lovell mingott own chef]1936-his own chef , so it ought to be good if [one]519-one can only get at it . " And [he]4041-the bridegroom could imagine [Sillerton Jackson]224-mr. jackson adding with authority : "[0-i] [[My]0-i dear fellow]3209-my dear fellow , have n't [you]3209-my dear fellow heard ? It 's to be served at small tables , in the new English fashion . " [Archer]214-archer 's eyes lingered a moment on the left - hand pew , where [[his]4041-the bridegroom mother]528-his mother , who had entered [the church]4061-the church on [Mr. Henry van der Luyden]304-mr. van der luyden 's arm , sat weeping softly under [her]528-his mother Chantilly veil , [her]528-his mother hands in [[her]528-his mother grandmother]853-her grandmother 's ermine muff . "[263-janey] [Poor Janey]263-janey ! " [he]4041-the bridegroom thought , looking at [[his]4041-the bridegroom sister]888-his sister , "[263-janey] even by screwing [her]1939-her head around [she]1939-her can see only the people in the few front pews ; and [they]1940-they 're mostly dowdy [Newlands]41-newlands and [Dagonets]296-the dagonets . " On the hither side of the white ribbon dividing off the seats reserved for the families [he]4041-the bridegroom saw [Beaufort]230-beaufort , tall and redfaced , scrutinising [the women]4068-the women with [his]4041-the bridegroom arrogant stare . Beside [him]4041-the bridegroom sat [[his]4041-the bridegroom wife]572-his wife , all silvery chinchilla and violets ; and on the far side of the ribbon , [Lawrence Lefferts]223-lawrence lefferts 's sleekly brushed head seemed to mount guard over the invisible deity of "[1940-they] [Good Form " who presided at the ceremony]4077-good form " who presided at the ceremony . [Archer]263-janey wondered how many flaws [Lefferts]223-lawrence lefferts 's keen eyes would discover in the ritual of [his]223-lawrence lefferts divinity ; then [he]4041-the bridegroom suddenly recalled that [he]4041-the bridegroom too had once thought such questions important . The things that had filled [his]4041-the bridegroom days seemed now like a nursery parody of life , or like the wrangles of [mediaeval schoolmen]4078-mediaeval schoolmen over metaphysical terms that [nobody]3102-nobody had ever understood . A stormy discussion as to whether the wedding presents should be "[4077-good form " who presided at the ceremony] shown " had darkened the last hours before the wedding ; and it seemed inconceivable to [Archer]263-janey that [grown - up people]4080-grown - up people should work [themselves]4080-grown - up people into a state of agitation over such trifles , and that the matter should have been decided ( in the negative ) by [Mrs. Welland]218-mrs. welland 's saying , with indignant tears : "[0-i] [I]0-i should as soon turn [the reporters]1941-the reporters loose in [[my]0-i house]3341-my house . " Yet there was a time when [Archer]263-janey had had definite and rather aggressive opinions on all such problems , and when everything concerning the manners and customs of [[his]263-janey little tribe]4081-his little tribe had seemed to [him]263-janey fraught with world - wide significance . "[1941-the reporters] And all the while , [I]0-i suppose , " [he]263-janey thought , "[0-i] [real people]1943-real people were living somewhere , and real things happening to [them]1943-real people ... " "[1943-real people] THERE [THEY]1943-real people COME ! " breathed [the best man]4049-the best man excitedly ; but [the bridegroom]4041-the bridegroom knew better . The cautious opening of the door of [the church]4061-the church meant only that [Mr. Brown]424-mr. brown [the livery - stable keeper ( gowned in black in [his]424-mr. brown intermittent character of sexton]4085-the livery - stable keeper ( gowned in black in his intermittent character of sexton ) was taking a preliminary survey of the scene before marshalling [his]424-mr. brown forces . The door was softly shut again ; then after another interval it swung majestically open , and a murmur ran through [the church]4061-the church : "[551-the family] [The family]551-the family ! " [Mrs. Welland]218-mrs. welland came first , on the arm of [[her]218-mrs. welland eldest son]4087-her eldest son . [Her]218-mrs. welland large pink face was appropriately solemn , and [her]218-mrs. welland plum - coloured satin with pale blue side - panels , and blue ostrich plumes in a small satin bonnet , met with general approval ; but before [she]218-mrs. welland had settled [herself]218-mrs. welland with a stately rustle in the pew opposite [Mrs. Archer]214-archer 's [the spectators]4088-the spectators were craning [their]4088-the spectators necks to see who was coming after [her]218-mrs. welland . Wild rumours had been abroad the day before to the effect that [Mrs. Manson Mingott]216-mrs. manson mingott , in spite of [her]218-mrs. welland physical disabilities , had resolved on being present at the ceremony ; and the idea was so much in keeping with [her]218-mrs. welland sporting character that bets ran high at the clubs as to [her]218-mrs. welland being able to walk up [the nave]4063-the nave and squeeze into a seat . It was known that [she]218-mrs. welland had insisted on sending [[her]218-mrs. welland own carpenter]4090-her own carpenter to look into the possibility of taking down the end panel of the front pew , and to measure the space between the seat and the front ; but the result had been discouraging , and for one anxious day [[her]218-mrs. welland family]1211-her family had watched [her]218-mrs. welland dallying with the plan of being wheeled up [the nave]4063-the nave in [her]218-mrs. welland enormous Bath chair and sitting enthroned in it at the foot of [the chancel]4093-the chancel . The idea of this monstrous exposure of [[her]218-mrs. welland person]4094-her person was so painful to [[her]218-mrs. welland relations]1476-her relations that [they]1476-her relations could have covered with gold [the ingenious person who suddenly discovered that the chair was too wide to pass between the iron uprights of the awning which extended from [the church]4061-the church door to the curbstone]4096-the ingenious person who suddenly discovered that the chair was too wide to pass between the iron uprights of the awning which extended from the church door to the curbstone . The idea of doing away with this awning , and revealing [the bride]4037-the bride to [the mob of [dressmakers]4100-dressmakers and [newspaper reporters who stood outside fighting to get near the joints of the canvas]4101-newspaper reporters who stood outside fighting to get near the joints of the canvas]4099-the mob of dressmakers and newspaper reporters who stood outside fighting to get near the joints of the canvas , exceeded even [old Catherine]409-old catherine 's courage , though for a moment [she]218-mrs. welland had weighed the possibility . "[551-the family] Why , [they]1945-they might take a photograph of [[my]0-i child]3142-my child AND PUT IT IN THE PAPERS ! " [Mrs. Welland]218-mrs. welland exclaimed when [[her]218-mrs. welland mother]605-her mother 's last plan was hinted to [her]218-mrs. welland ; and from this unthinkable indecency [the clan]3450-the clan recoiled with a collective shudder . [The ancestress]860-the ancestress had had to give in ; but [her]218-mrs. welland concession was bought only by the promise that the wedding - breakfast should take place under [her]218-mrs. welland roof , though ( as the [Washington]111-washington Square connection said ) with [[the Wellands]324-the wellands ' house]4105-the wellands ' house in easy reach it was hard to have to make a special price with [Brown]424-mr. brown to drive one to [the other end of nowhere]4106-the other end of nowhere . Though all these transactions had been widely reported by [the Jacksons]289-the jacksons a sporting minority still clung to the belief that [old Catherine]409-old catherine would appear in [church]1413-church , and there was a distinct lowering of the temperature when [she]409-old catherine was found to have been replaced by [[her]0-i daughter - in - law]552-her daughter - in - law . [Mrs. Lovell Mingott]217-mrs. lovell mingott had the high colour and glassy stare induced in ladies of [her]218-mrs. welland age and habit by the effort of getting into a new dress ; but once the disappointment occasioned by [[her]218-mrs. welland mother - in - law]4109-her mother - in - law 's non - appearance had subsided , it was agreed that [her]218-mrs. welland black Chantilly over lilac satin , with a bonnet of Parma violets , formed the happiest contrast to [Mrs. Welland]218-mrs. welland 's blue and plum - colour . Far different was the impression produced by [the gaunt and mincing lady who followed on [Mr. Mingott]237-mr. mingott 's arm]4110-the gaunt and mincing lady who followed on mr. mingott 's arm , in a wild dishevelment of stripes and fringes and floating scarves ; and as [this last apparition]4111-this last apparition glided into view [Archer]214-archer 's heart contracted and stopped beating . [He]237-mr. mingott had taken it for granted that [the Marchioness Manson]318-the marchioness manson was still in [Washington]111-washington , where [she]318-the marchioness manson had gone some four weeks previously with [[her]318-the marchioness manson niece]4005-her niece , [Madame Olenska]240-madame olenska . It was generally understood that [their]4113-their abrupt departure was due to [Madame Olenska]240-madame olenska 's desire to remove [[her]318-the marchioness manson aunt]1194-her aunt from the baleful eloquence of [Dr. Agathon Carver]413-dr. carver , who had nearly succeeded in enlisting [her]218-mrs. welland as [a recruit for [the Valley of Love]4116-the valley of love]4115-a recruit for the valley of love ; and in the circumstances [no one]619-no one had expected [either of [the ladies]754-the ladies]4118-either of the ladies to return for the wedding . For a moment [Archer]214-archer stood with [his]237-mr. mingott eyes fixed on [Medora]229-medora manson 's fantastic figure , straining to see who came behind [her]229-medora manson ; but [the little procession]4120-the little procession was at an end , for [all the lesser members of [the family]551-the family]4121-all the lesser members of the family had taken [their]4121-all the lesser members of the family seats , and [the eight tall ushers]4123-the eight tall ushers , gathering [themselves]4123-the eight tall ushers together like birds or insects preparing for some migratory manoeuvre , were already slipping through the side doors into [the lobby]3664-the lobby . "[1945-they] [Newland]214-archer -- [I]0-i say : [SHE]214-archer 'S HERE ! " [the best man]4049-the best man whispered . [Archer]214-archer roused [himself]214-archer with a start . A long time had apparently passed since [his]237-mr. mingott heart had stopped beating , for [the white and rosy procession]4126-the white and rosy procession was in fact half way up [the nave]4063-the nave , [the Bishop]4052-the bishop , [the Rector]4053-the rector and [two white - winged assistants]4130-two white - winged assistants were hovering about the flower - banked altar , and the first chords of the Spohr symphony were strewing their flower - like notes before [the bride]4037-the bride . [Archer]214-archer opened [his]237-mr. mingott eyes ( but could they really have been shut , as [he]237-mr. mingott imagined ? ) , and felt [his]237-mr. mingott heart beginning to resume its usual task . The music , the scent of the lilies on [the altar]4132-the altar , the vision of the cloud of tulle and orange - blossoms floating nearer and nearer , the sight of [Mrs. Archer]214-archer 's face suddenly convulsed with happy sobs , the low benedictory murmur of [the Rector]4053-the rector 's voice , the ordered evolutions of [the eight pink bridesmaids]4134-the eight pink bridesmaids and [the eight black ushers]4135-the eight black ushers : all these sights , sounds and sensations , so familiar in themselves , so unutterably strange and meaningless in [his]237-mr. mingott new relation to them , were confusedly mingled in [his]237-mr. mingott brain . "[0-i] [[My]0-i God]3096-my god , " [he]237-mr. mingott thought , "[0-i] HAVE [I]0-i got the ring?"--and once more [he]237-mr. mingott went through [the bridegroom]4041-the bridegroom 's convulsive gesture . Then , in a moment , [May]221-may was beside [him]237-mr. mingott , such radiance streaming from [her]221-may that it sent a faint warmth through [his]237-mr. mingott numbness , and [he]237-mr. mingott straightened [himself]237-mr. mingott and smiled into [her]221-may eyes . "[0-i] Dearly beloved , [we]1948-we are gathered together here , " [the Rector]4053-the rector began ... The ring was on [her]221-may hand , [the Bishop]4052-the bishop 's benediction had been given , [the bridesmaids]4040-the bridesmaids were a - poise to resume [their]4040-the bridesmaids place in the procession , and the organ was showing preliminary symptoms of breaking out into the Mendelssohn March , without which [no newly - wedded couple]4140-no newly - wedded couple had ever emerged upon [New York]2-new york . "[1948-we] [Your]0-i arm -- [I]0-i SAY , GIVE [HER]1949-her [YOUR]0-i ARM ! " [young Newland]214-archer nervously hissed ; and once more [Archer]214-archer became aware of having been adrift far off in [the unknown]4141-the unknown . What was it that had sent [him]237-mr. mingott [there]732-there , [he]237-mr. mingott wondered ? Perhaps the glimpse , among [the anonymous spectators in the transept]4143-the anonymous spectators in the transept , of a dark coil of hair under a hat which , a moment later , revealed itself as belonging to [an unknown lady with a long nose]4144-an unknown lady with a long nose , so laughably unlike the person whose image [she]221-may had evoked that [he]237-mr. mingott asked [himself]237-mr. mingott if [he]237-mr. mingott were becoming subject to hallucinations . And now [he]237-mr. mingott and [[his]237-mr. mingott wife]572-his wife were pacing slowly down [the nave]4063-the nave , carried forward on the light Mendelssohn ripples , the spring day beckoning to [them]4147-their through widely opened doors , and [Mrs. Welland]218-mrs. welland 's chestnuts , with big white favours on [their]4147-their frontlets , curvetting and showing off at the far end of [the canvas tunnel]4148-the canvas tunnel . [The footman]4149-the footman , who had a still bigger white favour on [his]4149-the footman lapel , wrapped [May]221-may 's white cloak about [her]221-may , and [Archer]214-archer jumped into the brougham at [her]221-may side . [She]221-may turned to [him]237-mr. mingott with a triumphant smile and [their]4147-their hands clasped under [her]221-may veil . "[1859-darling] [Darling]1859-darling ! " [Archer]214-archer said -- and suddenly the same black abyss yawned before [him]237-mr. mingott and [he]237-mr. mingott felt [himself]237-mr. mingott sinking into it , deeper and deeper , while [his]237-mr. mingott voice rambled on smoothly and cheerfully : "[1859-darling] Yes , of course [I]0-i thought [I]0-i 'd lost the ring ; no wedding would be complete if [the poor devil of [a bridegroom]1952-a bridegroom]1951-the poor devil of a bridegroom did n't go through that . But [you]1859-darling DID keep [me]0-i waiting , [you]1859-darling know ! [I]0-i had time to think of every horror that might possibly happen . " [She]221-may surprised [him]237-mr. mingott by turning , in full [Fifth Avenue]15-fifth avenue , and flinging [her]221-may arms about [his]237-mr. mingott neck . "[0-i] But none ever CAN happen now , can it , [Newland]214-archer , as long as [we]1953-we two are together ? " Every detail of the day had been so carefully thought out that [the young couple]4057-the young couple , after the wedding - breakfast , had ample time to put on [their]4057-the young couple travelling - clothes , descend the wide Mingott stairs between [laughing bridesmaids]4151-laughing bridesmaids and [weeping parents]4152-weeping parents , and get into the brougham under the traditional shower of rice and satin slippers ; and there was still half an hour left in which to drive to [the station]3828-the station , buy the last weeklies at the bookstall with the air of [seasoned travellers]4154-seasoned travellers , and settle [themselves]4057-the young couple in [the reserved compartment in which [[May]221-may 's maid]4156-may 's maid]4155-the reserved compartment in which may 's maid had already placed [her]4156-may 's maid dove - coloured travelling cloak and glaringly new dressing - bag from [London]79-london . [The old du Lac aunts at [Rhinebeck]96-rhinebeck]4157-the old du lac aunts at rhinebeck had put [[their]4157-the old du lac aunts at rhinebeck house]4158-their house at the disposal of [the bridal couple]4159-the bridal couple , with a readiness inspired by the prospect of spending a week in [New York]2-new york with [Mrs. Archer]214-archer ; and [Archer]214-archer , glad to escape the usual "[214-archer] bridal suite " in [a [Philadelphia]29-philadelphia or [Baltimore]49-baltimore hotel]4160-a philadelphia or baltimore hotel , had accepted with an equal alacrity . [May]221-may was enchanted at the idea of going to [the country]3706-the country , and childishly amused at the vain efforts of [the eight bridesmaids]4162-the eight bridesmaids to discover where [[their]4162-the eight bridesmaids mysterious retreat was situated]4163-their mysterious retreat was situated . It was thought "[214-archer] very English " to have [a country - house]4164-a country - house lent to one , and the fact gave a last touch of distinction to what was generally conceded to be the most brilliant wedding of the year ; but where [the house]532-the house was [no one]619-no one was permitted to know , except [the parents of [bride]4168-bride and [groom]4169-groom]4167-the parents of bride and groom , who , when taxed with the knowledge , pursed [their]4167-the parents of bride and groom lips and said mysteriously : "[1954-they] Ah , [they]1954-they did n't tell [us--]1955-us-- " which was manifestly true , since there was no need to . Once [they]4162-the eight bridesmaids were settled in [[their]4162-the eight bridesmaids compartment]4170-their compartment , and [the train]4171-the train , shaking off the endless wooden suburbs , had pushed out into the pale landscape of spring , talk became easier than [Archer]214-archer had expected . [May]221-may was still , in look and tone , [the simple girl of yesterday]4172-the simple girl of yesterday , eager to compare notes with [him]4173-him as to the incidents of the wedding , and discussing [them]4174-them as impartially as [a bridesmaid]4175-a bridesmaid talking it all over with [an usher]4176-an usher . At first [Archer]214-archer had fancied that this detachment was the disguise of an inward tremor ; but [her]221-may clear eyes revealed only the most tranquil unawareness . [She]221-may was alone for the first time with [[her]221-may husband]663-her husband ; but [[her]221-may husband]663-her husband was only [the charming comrade of yesterday]4179-the charming comrade of yesterday . There was [no one whom [she]221-may liked as much]4180-no one whom she liked as much , [no one whom [she]221-may trusted as completely]4181-no one whom she trusted as completely , and [the culminating "[1954-they] lark " of the whole delightful adventure of engagement and marriage]4182-the culminating " lark " of the whole delightful adventure of engagement and marriage was to be off with [him]4173-him alone on a journey , like [a grownup person]4183-a grownup person , like [a "[1954-they] married woman]4184-a " married woman , " in fact . It was wonderful that -- as [he]4173-him had learned in [the Mission garden at [St. Augustine]91-st. augustine]4185-the mission garden at st. augustine -- such depths of feeling could coexist with such absence of imagination . But [he]4173-him remembered how , even then , [she]221-may had surprised [him]4173-him by dropping back to inexpressive girlishness as soon as [her]221-may conscience had been eased of its burden ; and [he]4173-him saw that [she]221-may would probably go through life dealing to the best of [her]221-may ability with each experience as it came , but never anticipating any by so much as a stolen glance . Perhaps that faculty of unawareness was what gave [her]221-may eyes their transparency , and [her]221-may face the look of representing [a type]4186-a type rather than [a person]4187-a person ; as if [she]221-may might have been chosen to pose for a Civic Virtue or [a Greek goddess]4188-a greek goddess . The blood that ran so close to [her]221-may fair skin might have been a preserving fluid rather than a ravaging element ; yet [her]221-may look of indestructible youthfulness made [her]221-may seem neither hard nor dull , but only primitive and pure . In the thick of this meditation [Archer]214-archer suddenly felt [himself]214-archer looking at [her]221-may with the startled gaze of [a stranger]3408-a stranger , and plunged into a reminiscence of the wedding - breakfast and of [Granny Mingott]243-granny 's immense and triumphant pervasion of it . [May]221-may settled down to frank enjoyment of the subject . "[1954-they] [I]0-i was surprised , though -- weren't you?--that [aunt Medora]229-medora manson came after all . [Ellen]232-ellen wrote that [they]1956-they were neither of [them]1956-they well enough to take the journey ; [I]0-i do wish it had been [she]232-ellen who had recovered ! Did [you]1957-he see the exquisite old lace [she]232-ellen sent [me]0-i ? " [He]1957-he had known that the moment must come sooner or later , but [he]1957-he had somewhat imagined that by force of willing [he]1957-he might hold it at bay . "[1957-he] Yes -- [I]0-i -- no : yes , it was beautiful , " [he]1957-he said , looking at [her]1957-he blindly , and wondering if , whenever [he]1957-he heard those two syllables , all [his]1957-he carefully built - up world would tumble about [him]1957-he like a house of cards . "[0-i] Are n't [you]1957-he tired ? In [all the rainy desert of autumnal [London]79-london]4203-all the rainy desert of autumnal london there were only [two people whom [the Newland Archers]261-the newland archers knew]4204-two people whom the newland archers knew ; and these two [they]261-the newland archers had sedulously avoided , in conformity with the old [New York]2-new york tradition that it was not "[427-mrs. carfry] dignified " to force [[one]519-one 's self]4206-one 's self on the notice of [one 's acquaintances]4207-one 's acquaintances in [foreign countries]4208-foreign countries . [Mrs. Archer]214-archer and [Janey]263-janey , in the course of [their]1975-their visits to [Europe]14-europe , had so unflinchingly lived up to this principle , and met the friendly advances of [[their]1975-their fellow - travellers]4209-their fellow - travellers with an air of such impenetrable reserve , that [they]1975-their had almost achieved the record of never having exchanged a word with [a "[232-ellen] foreigner " other than [those employed in [hotels]4212-hotels and [railway - stations]4213-railway - stations]4211-those employed in hotels and railway - stations]4210-a " foreigner " other than those employed in hotels and railway - stations . [[Their]1975-their own compatriots]4214-their own compatriots -- save [those previously known or properly accredited]4215-those previously known or properly accredited -- [they]1975-their treated with an even more pronounced disdain ; so that , unless [they]1975-their ran across [a Chivers]396-reggie chivers , [a Dagonet]298-louisa or [a Mingott]217-mrs. lovell mingott , [their]1975-their months abroad were spent in an unbroken tete - a - tete . But the utmost precautions are sometimes unavailing ; and one night at [Botzen]112-botzen [one of [the two English ladies in [the room across the passage]4218-the room across the passage]4217-the two english ladies in the room across the passage ( whose names , dress and social situation were already intimately known to [Janey]263-janey]4216-one of the two english ladies in the room across the passage ( whose names , dress and social situation were already intimately known to janey ) had knocked on the door and asked if [Mrs. Archer]214-archer had a bottle of liniment . [The other lady]4219-the other lady -- [[the intruder]4220-the intruder 's sister]4221-the intruder 's sister , [Mrs. Carfry]427-mrs. carfry -- had been seized with a sudden attack of bronchitis ; and [Mrs. Archer]214-archer , who never travelled without [a complete family pharmacy]4222-a complete family pharmacy , was fortunately able to produce the required remedy . [Mrs. Carfry]427-mrs. carfry was very ill , and as [she]427-mrs. carfry and [[her]427-mrs. carfry sister]4223-her sister [Miss Harle]428-miss harle were travelling alone [they]1975-their were profoundly grateful to [[the Archer]4224-the archer ladies , who supplied [them]1975-their with ingenious comforts and [whose efficient maid]4226-whose efficient maid helped to nurse [the invalid]4227-the invalid back to health]4225-the archer ladies , who supplied them with ingenious comforts and whose efficient maid helped to nurse the invalid back to health . When [the Archers]261-the newland archers left [Botzen]112-botzen [they]261-the newland archers had no idea of ever seeing [Mrs. Carfry]427-mrs. carfry and [Miss Harle]428-miss harle again . Nothing , to [Mrs. Archer]214-archer 's mind , would have been more "[427-mrs. carfry] undignified " than to force [[one]519-one 's self]4206-one 's self on the notice of [a "[427-mrs. carfry] foreigner " to whom [one]519-one had happened to render an accidental service]4230-a " foreigner " to whom one had happened to render an accidental service . But [Mrs. Carfry]427-mrs. carfry and [[her]427-mrs. carfry sister]4223-her sister , to [whom this point of view was unknown , and who would have found it]4233-whom this point of view was unknown , and who would have found it utterly incomprehensible , felt [themselves]1975-their linked by an eternal gratitude to [the "[427-mrs. carfry] delightful Americans " who had been so kind at [Botzen]112-botzen]4234-the " delightful americans " who had been so kind at botzen . With touching fidelity [they]1975-their seized every chance of meeting [Mrs. Archer]214-archer and [Janey]263-janey in the course of [their]1975-their continental travels , and displayed a supernatural acuteness in finding out when [they]1975-their were to pass through [London]79-london on [their]1975-their way to or from [the States]113-the states . The intimacy became indissoluble , and [Mrs. Archer]214-archer and [Janey]263-janey , whenever [they]1975-their alighted at [Brown 's Hotel]114-brown 's hotel , found [themselves]1975-their awaited by [two affectionate friends]4235-two affectionate friends who , like [themselves]1975-their , cultivated ferns in Wardian cases , made macrame lace , read the memoirs of [the Baroness Bunsen]429-the baroness bunsen and had views about [the occupants of [the leading [London]79-london pulpits]4237-the leading london pulpits]4236-the occupants of the leading london pulpits . "[427-mrs. carfry] It 's all very well for [you]1976-you , [Newland]214-archer ; [you]1976-you KNOW [them]1977-them . " [Newland]214-archer leaned back in [his]1976-you chair and smiled at [her]1716-dearest . [She]1716-dearest looked handsomer and more [Diana]431-diana - like than ever . The moist English air seemed to have deepened the bloom of [her]1716-dearest cheeks and softened the slight hardness of [her]1716-dearest virginal features ; or else it was simply the inner glow of happiness , shining through like a light under ice . "[0-i] Wear , [dearest]1716-dearest ? [I]0-i thought a trunkful of things had come from [Paris]3-paris last week . " "[0-i] Yes , of course . " [He]4244-he tried to enter into [her]1716-dearest perplexity . "[0-i] But do n't [Englishwomen]1981-englishwomen dress just like [everybody else]1558-everybody else in the evening ? "[3127-dear] Why not wear [your]0-i wedding - dress ? That ca n't be wrong , can it ? " "[1716-dearest] Oh , [dearest]1716-dearest ! If [I]0-i only had it [here]3155-here ! " [The Newland Archers]4246-the newland archers were on [their]4246-the newland archers way [home]649-home , after a three months ' wedding - tour which [May]221-may , in writing to [[her]221-may girl friends]4248-her girl friends , vaguely summarised as "[432-worth] blissful . " [They]4246-the newland archers had not gone to [the Italian Lakes]115-the italian lakes : on reflection , [Archer]263-janey had not been able to picture [[his]263-janey wife]572-his wife in that particular setting . [Her]221-may own inclination ( after a month with the [Paris]3-paris dressmakers ) was for mountaineering in July and swimming in August . This plan [they]4246-the newland archers punctually fulfilled , spending July at [Interlaken]116-interlaken and [Grindelwald]117-grindelwald , and August at [a little place called [Etretat]118-etretat , on [the Normandy coast]4251-the normandy coast , which [some one]687-some one had recommended as quaint and quiet]4250-a little place called etretat , on the normandy coast , which some one had recommended as quaint and quiet . Once or twice , in [the mountains]4253-the mountains , [Archer]263-janey had pointed southward and said : "[432-worth] There 's [Italy]63-italy " ; and [May]221-may , [her]221-may feet in a gentian - bed , had smiled cheerfully , and replied : "[432-worth] It would be lovely to go [there]732-there next winter , if only [you]1992-you did n't have to be in [New York]2-new york . " But in reality travelling interested [her]221-may even less than [he]263-janey had expected . [She]221-may regarded it ( once [her]221-may clothes were ordered ) as merely an enlarged opportunity for walking , riding , swimming , and trying [her]221-may hand at the fascinating new game of lawn tennis ; and when [they]4246-the newland archers finally got back to [London]79-london ( where [they]4246-the newland archers were to spend a fortnight while [he]263-janey ordered [HIS]263-janey clothes ) [she]221-may no longer concealed the eagerness with which [she]221-may looked forward to sailing . In [London]79-london nothing interested [her]221-may but [the theatres]4254-the theatres and [the shops]4255-the shops ; and [she]221-may found [the theatres]4254-the theatres less exciting than [the Paris cafes chantants]4257-the paris cafes chantants where , under the blossoming horse - chestnuts of [the Champs Elysees]119-the champs elysees , [she]221-may had had the novel experience of looking down from [the restaurant terrace]4258-the restaurant terrace on [an audience of "[432-worth] cocottes]4259-an audience of " cocottes , " and having [[her]221-may husband]663-her husband interpret to [her]221-may as much of the songs as [he]263-janey thought suitable for bridal ears . [Archer]263-janey had reverted to all [his]263-janey old inherited ideas about marriage . It was less trouble to conform with the tradition and treat [May]221-may exactly as [all [his]263-janey friends]4261-all his friends treated [[their]4261-all his friends wives]4262-their wives than to try to put into practice the theories with which [his]263-janey untrammelled bachelorhood had dallied . There was no use in trying to emancipate [a wife who had not the dimmest notion that [she]221-may was not free]4263-a wife who had not the dimmest notion that she was not free ; and [he]263-janey had long since discovered that [May]221-may 's only use of the liberty [she]221-may supposed [herself]221-may to possess would be to lay it on the altar of [her]221-may wifely adoration . [Her]221-may innate dignity would always keep [her]221-may from making the gift abjectly ; and a day might even come ( as it once had ) when [she]221-may would find strength to take it altogether back if [she]221-may thought [she]221-may were doing it for [his]263-janey own good . But with a conception of marriage so uncomplicated and incurious as [hers]221-may such a crisis could be brought about only by something visibly outrageous in [his]263-janey own conduct ; and the fineness of [her]221-may feeling for [him]263-janey made that unthinkable . Whatever happened , [he]263-janey knew , [she]221-may would always be loyal , gallant and unresentful ; and that pledged [him]263-janey to the practice of the same virtues . All this tended to draw [him]263-janey back into [his]263-janey old habits of mind . If [her]221-may simplicity had been the simplicity of pettiness [he]263-janey would have chafed and rebelled ; but since the lines of [her]221-may character , though so few , were on the same fine mould as [her]221-may face , [she]221-may became the tutelary divinity of all [his]263-janey old traditions and reverences . Such qualities were scarcely of the kind to enliven foreign travel , though they made [her]221-may so easy and pleasant [a companion]4264-a companion ; but [he]263-janey saw at once how [they]4265-their would fall into place in [their]4265-their proper setting . [He]263-janey had no fear of being oppressed by [them]4265-their , for [his]263-janey artistic and intellectual life would go on , as it always had , outside the domestic circle ; and within it there would be nothing small and stifling -- coming back to [[his]263-janey wife]572-his wife would never be like entering [a stuffy room]4267-a stuffy room after a tramp in the open . And when [they]4265-their had [children]3115-children the vacant corners in both [their]4265-their lives would be filled . All these things went through [his]263-janey mind during [their]4265-their long slow drive from [Mayfair]120-mayfair to [South Kensington]121-south kensington , where [Mrs. Carfry]427-mrs. carfry and [[her]427-mrs. carfry sister]4223-her sister lived . [Archer]263-janey too would have preferred to escape [[their]4265-their friends]4270-their friends ' hospitality : in conformity with the family tradition [he]263-janey had always travelled as [a sight - seer and looker - on]4271-a sight - seer and looker - on , affecting a haughty unconsciousness of the presence of [[his]263-janey fellow - beings]4272-his fellow - beings . Once only , just after [Harvard]433-harvard , [he]263-janey had spent a few gay weeks at [Florence]65-florence with [a band of [queer Europeanised Americans]4274-queer europeanised americans]4273-a band of queer europeanised americans , dancing all night with [titled ladies in [palaces]4276-palaces]4275-titled ladies in palaces , and gambling half the day with [the rakes and dandies of [the fashionable club]4278-the fashionable club]4277-the rakes and dandies of the fashionable club ; but it had all seemed to [him]263-janey , though the greatest fun in [the world]580-the world , as unreal as a carnival . [These queer cosmopolitan women]4280-these queer cosmopolitan women , deep in complicated love - affairs which [they]4280-these queer cosmopolitan women appeared to feel the need of retailing to [every one [they]4280-these queer cosmopolitan women met]4281-every one they met , and [the magnificent young officers]4282-the magnificent young officers and [elderly dyed wits who were [the subjects]4284-the subjects or the recipients of [their]4280-these queer cosmopolitan women confidences]4283-elderly dyed wits who were the subjects or the recipients of their confidences , were too different from [the people [Archer]263-janey had grown up among]4285-the people archer had grown up among , too much like [expensive and rather malodorous hot - house exotics]4286-expensive and rather malodorous hot - house exotics , to detain [his]263-janey imagination long . To introduce [[his]263-janey wife]572-his wife into such a society was out of the question ; and in the course of [his]263-janey travels [no other]4288-no other had shown any marked eagerness for [his]263-janey company . Not long after [their]4280-these queer cosmopolitan women arrival in [London]79-london [he]263-janey had run across [the Duke of St. Austrey]343-st. austrey , and [the Duke]1263-the duke , instantly and cordially recognising [him]263-janey , had said : "[432-worth] Look [me]0-i up , wo n't you?"--but [no proper - spirited American]4290-no proper - spirited american would have considered that a suggestion to be acted on , and the meeting was without a sequel . [They]4280-these queer cosmopolitan women had even managed to avoid [[May]221-may 's English aunt]4291-may 's english aunt , [[the banker]609-the banker 's wife , who was still in [Yorkshire]122-yorkshire]4293-the banker 's wife , who was still in yorkshire ; in fact , [they]4280-these queer cosmopolitan women had purposely postponed going to [London]79-london till the autumn in order that [their]4280-these queer cosmopolitan women arrival during the season might not appear pushing and snobbish to [these unknown relatives]4294-these unknown relatives . "[432-worth] Probably there 'll be nobody at [Mrs. Carfry's]434-mrs. carfry's -- [London]79-london 's [a desert]1993-a desert at this season , and [you]1994-you 've made [yourself]1994-you much too beautiful , " [Archer]263-janey said to [May]221-may , who sat at [his]263-janey side in the hansom so spotlessly splendid in [her]221-may sky - blue cloak edged with swansdown that it seemed wicked to expose [her]221-may to the [London]79-london grime . "[1994-you] [I]0-i do n't want [them]1995-their to think that [we]1996-we dress like [savages]1997-savages , " [she]221-may replied , with a scorn that [Pocahontas]435-pocahontas might have resented ; and [he]263-janey was struck again by the religious reverence of [even the most unworldly American women]4295-even the most unworldly american women for the social advantages of dress . "[1995-their] It 's [their]1995-their armour , " [he]263-janey thought , "[1995-their] [their]1995-their defence against the unknown , and [their]1995-their defiance of it . " And [he]263-janey understood for the first time the earnestness with which [May]221-may , who was incapable of tying a ribbon in [her]221-may hair to charm [him]263-janey , had gone through the solemn rite of selecting and ordering [her]221-may extensive wardrobe . [He]263-janey had been right in expecting the party at [Mrs. Carfry]427-mrs. carfry 's to be a small one . Besides [[their]1996-we hostess]4296-their hostess and [[her]221-may sister]4223-her sister , [they]1996-we found , in [the long chilly drawing - room]4298-the long chilly drawing - room , only [another shawled lady]4299-another shawled lady , [a genial Vicar who was [[her]221-may husband]663-her husband]4300-a genial vicar who was her husband , [a silent lad whom [Mrs. Carfry]427-mrs. carfry named as [[her]221-may nephew]4303-her nephew]4302-a silent lad whom mrs. carfry named as her nephew , and [a small dark gentleman with lively eyes whom [she]221-may introduced as [[his]263-janey tutor]4305-his tutor , pronouncing a French name as [she]221-may did so]4304-a small dark gentleman with lively eyes whom she introduced as his tutor , pronouncing a french name as she did so . Into [this dimly - lit and dim - featured group [May Archer]430-archer]4306-this dimly - lit and dim - featured group may archer floated like a swan with the sunset on [her]221-may : [she]221-may seemed larger , fairer , more voluminously rustling than [[her]221-may husband]663-her husband had ever seen [her]221-may ; and [he]663-her husband perceived that the rosiness and rustlingness were the tokens of an extreme and infantile shyness . "[1995-their] What on earth will [they]1998-their expect [me]0-i to talk about ? " [her]221-may helpless eyes implored [him]663-her husband , at the very moment that [her]221-may dazzling apparition was calling forth the same anxiety in [their]1998-their own bosoms . But beauty , even when distrustful of itself , awakens confidence in the manly heart ; and [the Vicar]4308-the vicar and [the French - named tutor]4309-the french - named tutor were soon manifesting to [May]430-archer [their]1998-their desire to put [her]221-may at [her]221-may ease . In spite of [their]1998-their best efforts , however , the dinner was a languishing affair . [Archer]430-archer noticed that [[his]430-archer wife]572-his wife 's way of showing [herself]572-his wife at [her]572-his wife ease with [foreigners]751-foreigners was to become more uncompromisingly local in [her]572-his wife references , so that , though [her]572-his wife loveliness was an encouragement to admiration , [her]572-his wife conversation was a chill to repartee . [The Vicar]4308-the vicar soon abandoned the struggle ; but [the tutor]4313-the tutor , who spoke the most fluent and accomplished English , gallantly continued to pour it out to [her]572-his wife until [the ladies]754-the ladies , to the manifest relief of [all concerned]4315-all concerned , went up to [the drawing - room]983-the drawing - room . [The Vicar]4308-the vicar , after a glass of port , was obliged to hurry away to a meeting , and [the shy nephew , who appeared to be an invalid]4318-the shy nephew , who appeared to be an invalid , was packed off to bed . But [Archer]430-archer and [the tutor]4313-the tutor continued to sit over [their]1998-their wine , and suddenly [Archer]430-archer found [himself]430-archer talking as [he]430-archer had not done since [his]430-archer last symposium with [Ned Winsett]326-winsett . [The Carfry nephew]4320-the carfry nephew , it turned out , had been threatened with consumption , and had had to leave [Harrow]123-harrow for [Switzerland]124-switzerland , where [he]4320-the carfry nephew had spent two years in [the milder air of [Lake Leman]125-lake leman]4321-the milder air of lake leman . Being [a bookish youth]4322-a bookish youth , [he]4320-the carfry nephew had been entrusted to [M. Riviere]436-m. riviere , who had brought [him]4320-the carfry nephew back to [England]28-england , and was to remain with [him]4320-the carfry nephew till [he]4320-the carfry nephew went up to [Oxford]126-oxford the following spring ; and [M. Riviere]436-m. riviere added with simplicity that [he]4320-the carfry nephew should then have to look out for another job . It seemed impossible , [Archer]430-archer thought , that [he]4320-the carfry nephew should be long without one , so varied were [his]4320-the carfry nephew interests and so many [his]4320-the carfry nephew gifts . [He]4320-the carfry nephew was [a man of about thirty , with a thin ugly face]4323-a man of about thirty , with a thin ugly face ( May would certainly have called [him]4320-the carfry nephew common - looking ) to which the play of [his]4320-the carfry nephew ideas gave an intense expressiveness ; but there was nothing frivolous or cheap in [his]4320-the carfry nephew animation . [[His]4320-the carfry nephew father]4324-his father , who had died young , had filled a small diplomatic post , and it had been intended that [the son]4325-the son should follow the same career ; but an insatiable taste for letters had thrown [the young man]527-the young man into journalism , then into authorship ( apparently unsuccessful ) , and at length -- after other experiments and vicissitudes which [he]4320-the carfry nephew spared [[his]4320-the carfry nephew listener]4327-his listener -- into tutoring [English youths in [Switzerland]124-switzerland]4328-english youths in switzerland . Before that , however , [he]4320-the carfry nephew had lived much in [Paris]3-paris , frequented [the Goncourt grenier]378-the goncourt brothers , been advised by [Maupassant]437-maupassant not to attempt to write ( even that seemed to [Archer]430-archer a dazzling honour ! ) , and had often talked with [Merimee]373-merimee in [[[his]4320-the carfry nephew mother]528-his mother 's house]4330-his mother 's house . [He]4320-the carfry nephew had obviously always been desperately poor and anxious ( having [a mother]4331-a mother and [an unmarried sister]4332-an unmarried sister to provide for ) , and it was apparent that [his]4320-the carfry nephew literary ambitions had failed . [His]4320-the carfry nephew situation , in fact , seemed , materially speaking , no more brilliant than [Ned Winsett]326-winsett 's ; but [he]4320-the carfry nephew had lived in a world in which , as [he]4320-the carfry nephew said , [no one who loved ideas need hunger mentally]4333-no one who loved ideas need hunger mentally . As it was precisely of that love that poor [Winsett]326-winsett was starving to death , [Archer]430-archer looked with a sort of vicarious envy at [this eager impecunious young man who had fared so richly in [his]4320-the carfry nephew poverty]4334-this eager impecunious young man who had fared so richly in his poverty . "[1998-their] [You]1999-you see , [Monsieur]2000-monsieur , it 's worth everything , is n't it , to keep [one]519-one 's intellectual liberty , not to enslave [one]519-one 's powers of appreciation , [one]519-one 's critical independence ? It was because of that that [I]0-i abandoned journalism , and took to so much duller work : tutoring and private secretaryship . There is a good deal of drudgery , of course ; but [one]519-one preserves [one]519-one 's moral freedom , what [we]2006-we call in French one 's quant a soi . And when [one]519-one hears good talk [one]519-one can join in it without compromising any opinions but [one]519-one 's own ; or [one]519-one can listen , and answer it inwardly . Ah , good conversation -- there 's nothing like it , is there ? The air of ideas is the only air worth breathing . And so [I]0-i have never regretted giving up either diplomacy or journalism -- [two different forms of the same self - abdication]2010-two different forms of the same self - abdication . " [He]2011-monsieur fixed [his]2011-monsieur vivid eyes on [Archer]430-archer as [he]2011-monsieur lit another cigarette . "[0-i] Voyez - vous , [Monsieur]2011-monsieur , to be able to look life in the face : that 's worth living in [a garret]2012-a garret for , is n't it ? But , after all , [one]519-one must earn enough to pay for the garret ; and [I]0-i confess that to grow old as [a private tutor]2014-a private tutor -- or a ' private ' anything -- is almost as chilling to the imagination as a second secretaryship at [Bucharest]127-bucharest . Sometimes [I]0-i feel [I]0-i must make a plunge : an immense plunge . Do [you]2015-you suppose , for instance , there would be any opening for [me]0-i in [America]25-america -- in [New York]2-new york ? " [Archer]430-archer looked at [him]2011-monsieur with startled eyes . [New York]2-new york , for [a young man who had frequented the Goncourts and [Flaubert]438-flaubert]4335-a young man who had frequented the goncourts and flaubert , and who thought the life of ideas the only one worth living ! [He]430-archer continued to stare at [M. Riviere]436-m. riviere perplexedly , wondering how to tell [him]436-m. riviere that [his]436-m. riviere very superiorities and advantages would be the surest hindrance to success . "[2015-you] [New York]2-new york -- [New York]2-new york -- but must it be especially [New York]2-new york ? " [he]430-archer stammered , utterly unable to imagine what lucrative opening [[his]430-archer [native city]4337-native city]1388-his native city could offer to [a young man to whom good conversation appeared to be the only necessity]4338-a young man to whom good conversation appeared to be the only necessity . A sudden flush rose under [M. Riviere]436-m. riviere 's sallow skin . "[0-i] [I]0-i -- [I]0-i thought it [[your]0-i metropolis]2016-your metropolis : is not the intellectual life more active [there]732-there ? " [he]430-archer rejoined ; then , as if fearing to give [[his]430-archer hearer]4339-his hearer the impression of having asked a favour , [he]430-archer went on hastily : "[519-one] [One]519-one throws out random suggestions -- more to [one]519-one 's self than to [others]3523-others . " During the homeward drive [Archer]430-archer pondered deeply on this episode . [His]430-archer hour with [M. Riviere]436-m. riviere had put new air into [his]430-archer lungs , and [his]430-archer first impulse had been to invite [him]430-archer to dine the next day ; but [he]430-archer was beginning to understand why [married men]4340-married men did not always immediately yield to [their]4340-married men first impulses . "[427-mrs. carfry] [That young tutor]2022-that young tutor is [an interesting fellow]2023-an interesting fellow : [we]2024-we had some awfully good talk after dinner about books and things , " [he]430-archer threw out tentatively in the hansom . [May]430-archer roused [herself]430-archer from one of the dreamy silences into which [he]430-archer had read so many meanings before six months of marriage had given [him]430-archer the key to them . "[2024-we] [The little Frenchman]2025-the little frenchman ? Was n't [he]2025-the little frenchman dreadfully common ? " [she]4341-she questioned coldly ; and [he]430-archer guessed that [she]4341-she nursed a secret disappointment at having been invited out in [London]79-london to meet [a clergyman]4342-a clergyman and [a French tutor]4343-a french tutor . The disappointment was not occasioned by the sentiment ordinarily defined as snobbishness , but by old [New York]2-new york 's sense of what was due to it when it risked its dignity in [foreign lands]4344-foreign lands . If [[May]430-archer 's parents]4345-may 's parents had entertained [the Carfrys]439-the carfrys in [Fifth Avenue]4346-fifth avenue [they]4345-may 's parents would have offered [them]439-the carfrys something more substantial than [a parson]4347-a parson and [a schoolmaster]4348-a schoolmaster . But [Archer]430-archer was on edge , and took [her]0-i up . "[2025-the little frenchman] Common -- common WHERE ? " [he]430-archer queried ; and [she]0-i returned with unusual readiness : "[2025-the little frenchman] Why , [I]0-i should say anywhere but in [[his]2026-he school - room]2027-his school - room . [Those people]2028-those people are always awkward in society . But then , " [she]0-i added disarmingly , "[0-i] [I]0-i suppose [I]0-i should n't have known if [he]2026-he was clever . " [Archer]430-archer disliked [her]0-i use of the word "[2026-he] clever " almost as much as [her]0-i use of the word "[0-i] common " ; but [he]430-archer was beginning to fear [his]430-archer tendency to dwell on the things [he]430-archer disliked in [her]0-i . After all , [her]0-i point of view had always been the same . It was that of all [the people [he]430-archer had grown up among]4349-the people he had grown up among , and [he]430-archer had always regarded it as necessary but negligible . "[0-i] Ah -- then [I]0-i wo n't ask [him]2026-he to dine ! " [he]430-archer concluded with a laugh ; and [May]430-archer echoed , bewildered : "[0-i] Goodness -- ask [the Carfrys ' tutor]2029-the carfrys ' tutor ? [He]2026-he 's looking for a job in [New York]2-new york . " [Her]0-i surprise increased with [her]0-i indifference : [he]430-archer almost fancied that [she]0-i suspected [him]430-archer of being tainted with "[2026-he] foreignness . "[0-i] Oh , [Newland]214-archer , how funny ! Is n't that FRENCH ? " On the whole , [he]430-archer was glad to have the matter settled for [him]430-archer by [her]0-i refusing to take seriously [his]430-archer wish to invite [M. Riviere]436-m. riviere . Another after - dinner talk would have made it difficult to avoid the question of [New York]2-new york ; and the more [Archer]430-archer considered it the less [he]430-archer was able to fit [M. Riviere]436-m. riviere into any conceivable picture of [New York]2-new york as [he]430-archer knew it . [He]430-archer perceived with a flash of chilling insight that in future many problems would be thus negatively solved for [him]430-archer ; but as [he]430-archer paid the hansom and followed [[his]430-archer wife]572-his wife 's long train into [the house]532-the house [he]430-archer took refuge in the comforting platitude that the first six months were always the most difficult in marriage . "[0-i] After that [I]0-i suppose [we]2033-we shall have pretty nearly finished rubbing off each other 's angles , " [he]430-archer reflected ; but the worst of it was that [May]430-archer 's pressure was already bearing on the very angles whose sharpness [he]430-archer most wanted to keep . XXI . [The small bright lawn]4356-the small bright lawn stretched away smoothly to [the big bright sea]4357-the big bright sea . The turf was hemmed with an edge of scarlet geranium and coleus , and cast - iron vases painted in chocolate colour , standing at intervals along the winding path that led to [the sea]4358-the sea , looped their garlands of petunia and ivy geranium above the neatly raked gravel . Half way between the edge of [the cliff]4359-the cliff and [the square wooden house]4360-the square wooden house ( which was also chocolate - coloured , but with the tin roof of [the verandah]1733-the verandah striped in yellow and brown to represent an awning ) two large targets had been placed against a background of shrubbery . On the other side of [the lawn]4362-the lawn , facing the targets , was pitched [a real tent , with benches and garden - seats about [it]4363-a real tent , with benches and garden - seats about it]4363-a real tent , with benches and garden - seats about it . A number of [ladies in summer dresses]4364-ladies in summer dresses and [gentlemen in grey frock - coats and tall hats]4365-gentlemen in grey frock - coats and tall hats stood on [the lawn]4362-the lawn or sat upon the benches ; and every now and then [a slender girl in starched muslin]4367-a slender girl in starched muslin would step from [the tent]4368-the tent , bow in hand , and speed [her]4367-a slender girl in starched muslin shaft at one of the targets , while [the spectators]4088-the spectators interrupted [their]4088-the spectators talk to watch the result . [Newland Archer]214-archer , standing on [the verandah of [the house]532-the house]4370-the verandah of the house , looked curiously down upon this scene . On each side of the shiny painted steps was a large blue china flower - pot on a bright yellow china stand . A spiky green plant filled each pot , and below [the verandah]1733-the verandah ran a wide border of blue hydrangeas edged with more red geraniums . Behind [him]4373-he , the French windows of [the drawing - rooms through which [he]4373-he had passed]4374-the drawing - rooms through which he had passed gave glimpses , between swaying lace curtains , of glassy parquet floors islanded with chintz poufs , dwarf armchairs , and velvet tables covered with trifles in silver . [The Newport Archery Club]4375-the newport archery club always held [its]4375-the newport archery club August meeting at [the Beauforts ']4376-the beauforts ' . The sport , which had hitherto known [no rival but croquet]4377-no rival but croquet , was beginning to be discarded in favour of lawn - tennis ; but the latter game was still considered too rough and inelegant for social occasions , and as an opportunity to show off pretty dresses and graceful attitudes the bow and arrow held [their]4376-the beauforts ' own . [Archer]214-archer looked down with wonder at the familiar spectacle . It surprised [him]4373-he that life should be going on in the old way when [his]4373-he own reactions to it had so completely changed . It was [Newport]104-newport that had first brought home to [him]4373-he the extent of the change . In [New York]2-new york , during the previous winter , after [he]4373-he and [May]430-archer had settled down in [the new greenish - yellow house]4378-the new greenish - yellow house with the bow - window and [the Pompeian vestibule]4379-the pompeian vestibule , [he]4373-he had dropped back with relief into the old routine of [the office]3721-the office , and the renewal of this daily activity had served as a link with [his]4373-he former self . Then there had been the pleasurable excitement of choosing a showy grey stepper for [May]430-archer 's brougham ( [the Wellands]324-the wellands had given [the carriage]878-the carriage ) , and the abiding occupation and interest of arranging [[his]4373-he new library]4382-his new library , which , in spite of family doubts and disapprovals , had been carried out as [he]4373-he had dreamed , with a dark embossed paper , Eastlake book - cases and "[0-i] sincere " arm - chairs and tables . At the Century [he]4373-he had found [Winsett]326-winsett again , and at the Knickerbocker [the fashionable young men of [his]4373-he own set]4383-the fashionable young men of his own set ; and what with the hours dedicated to the law and those given to dining out or entertaining [friends]3276-friends at [home]649-home , with an occasional evening at the Opera or the play , the life [he]4373-he was living had still seemed a fairly real and inevitable sort of business . But [Newport]104-newport represented the escape from duty into an atmosphere of unmitigated holiday - making . [Archer]430-archer had tried to persuade [May]430-archer to spend the summer on [a remote island off [the coast of [Maine]128-maine]4387-the coast of maine]4386-a remote island off the coast of maine ( called , appropriately enough , [Mount Desert]129-mount desert ) , where [a few hardy Bostonians]4388-a few hardy bostonians and [Philadelphians]4389-philadelphians were camping in ["[0-i] native " cottages]4390-" native " cottages , and whence came reports of enchanting scenery and a wild , almost trapper - like existence amid [woods and waters]4391-woods and waters . But [the Wellands]324-the wellands always went to [Newport]104-newport , where [they]324-the wellands owned one of [the square boxes on [the cliffs]4393-the cliffs]4392-the square boxes on the cliffs , and [[their]324-the wellands son - in - law]4394-their son - in - law could adduce no good reason why [he]430-archer and [May]430-archer should not join [them]324-the wellands [there]732-there . As [Mrs. Welland]218-mrs. welland rather tartly pointed out , it was hardly worth while for [May]430-archer to have worn [herself]430-archer out trying on summer clothes in [Paris]3-paris if [she]218-mrs. welland was not to be allowed to wear them ; and this argument was of a kind to which [Archer]430-archer had as yet found no answer . [May]430-archer [herself]430-archer could not understand [his]430-archer obscure reluctance to fall in with so reasonable and pleasant a way of spending the summer . [She]218-mrs. welland reminded [him]430-archer that [he]430-archer had always liked [Newport]104-newport in [his]430-archer bachelor days , and as this was indisputable [he]430-archer could only profess that [he]430-archer was sure [he]430-archer was going to like it better than ever now that [they]4396-they were to be there together . But as [he]430-archer stood on [the Beaufort verandah]4397-the beaufort verandah and looked out on [the brightly peopled lawn]4398-the brightly peopled lawn it came home to [him]430-archer with a shiver that [he]430-archer was not going to like it at all . It was not [May]430-archer 's fault , [poor dear]4399-poor dear . If , now and then , during [their]4396-they travels , [they]4396-they had fallen slightly out of step , harmony had been restored by [their]4396-they return to the conditions [she]218-mrs. welland was used to . [He]430-archer had always foreseen that [she]218-mrs. welland would not disappoint [him]430-archer ; and [he]430-archer had been right . [He]430-archer had married ( as [most young men]4400-most young men did ) because [he]430-archer had met [a perfectly charming girl]4401-a perfectly charming girl at the moment when a series of rather aimless sentimental adventures were ending in premature disgust ; and [she]4401-a perfectly charming girl had represented peace , stability , comradeship , and the steadying sense of an unescapable duty . [He]430-archer could not say that [he]430-archer had been mistaken in [his]430-archer choice , for [she]4401-a perfectly charming girl had fulfilled all that [he]430-archer had expected . It was undoubtedly gratifying to be [the husband of one of [the handsomest and most popular young married women in [New York]2-new york]4403-the handsomest and most popular young married women in new york , especially when [she]4401-a perfectly charming girl was also [one of the sweetest - tempered and most reasonable of [wives]4405-wives]4404-one of the sweetest - tempered and most reasonable of wives]4402-the husband of one of the handsomest and most popular young married women in new york , especially when she was also one of the sweetest - tempered and most reasonable of wives ; and [Archer]430-archer had never been insensible to such advantages . As for the momentary madness which had fallen upon [him]430-archer on the eve of [his]430-archer marriage , [he]430-archer had trained [himself]430-archer to regard it as the last of [his]430-archer discarded experiments . The idea that [he]430-archer could ever , in [his]430-archer senses , have dreamed of marrying [the Countess Olenska]234-the countess olenska had become almost unthinkable , and [she]4401-a perfectly charming girl remained in [his]430-archer memory simply as the most plaintive and poignant of a line of ghosts . But all these abstractions and eliminations made of [his]430-archer mind a rather empty and echoing place , and [he]430-archer supposed that was one of the reasons why [the busy animated people on [the Beaufort lawn]4407-the beaufort lawn]4406-the busy animated people on the beaufort lawn shocked [him]430-archer as if [they]4406-the busy animated people on the beaufort lawn had been [children]3115-children playing in [a grave - yard]4409-a grave - yard . [He]430-archer heard a murmur of skirts beside [him]430-archer , and [the Marchioness Manson]318-the marchioness manson fluttered out of [the drawing - room]983-the drawing - room window . As usual , [she]318-the marchioness manson was extraordinarily festooned and bedizened , with a limp Leghorn hat anchored to [her]318-the marchioness manson head by many windings of faded gauze , and a little black velvet parasol on a carved ivory handle absurdly balanced over [her]318-the marchioness manson much larger hatbrim . "[3140-my dear] [[My]0-i dear]3140-my dear [Newland]214-archer , [I]0-i had no idea that [you]214-archer and [May]430-archer had arrived ! [You]214-archer [yourself]214-archer came only yesterday , [you]214-archer say ? Ah , business -- business -- professional duties ... [I]0-i understand . [Many husbands]2035-many husbands , [I]0-i know , find it impossible to join [[their]2035-many husbands wives]4262-their wives here except for the week - end . " [She]318-the marchioness manson cocked [her]318-the marchioness manson head on one side and languished at [him]3140-my dear through screwed - up eyes . "[2035-many husbands] But marriage is one long sacrifice , as [I]0-i used often to remind [[my]0-i Ellen--]2037-my ellen-- " [Archer]430-archer 's heart stopped with the queer jerk which it had given once before , and which seemed suddenly to slam a door between [himself]3140-my dear and [the outer world]4411-the outer world ; but this break of continuity must have been of the briefest , for [he]3140-my dear presently heard [Medora]229-medora manson answering a question [he]3140-my dear had apparently found voice to put . "[0-i] No , [I]0-i am not staying [here]3155-here , but with [the Blenkers]365-the blenkers , in [their]2039-their delicious solitude at [Portsmouth]130-portsmouth . " [She]0-i drooped slightly beneath [her]0-i protecting brim , and added with a faint blush : "[2041-the blenkers] This week [Dr. Agathon Carver]413-dr. carver is holding a series of Inner Thought meetings [there]732-there . " Strolling toward [them]4412-them from [the tent]4368-the tent [Beaufort]230-beaufort advanced over [the lawn]4362-the lawn , tall , heavy , too tightly buttoned into a [London]79-london frock - coat , with one of [his]4415-his own orchids in its buttonhole . [Archer]430-archer , who had not seen [him]4415-his for two or three months , was struck by the change in [his]4415-his appearance . In the hot summer light [his]4415-his floridness seemed heavy and bloated , and but for [his]4415-his erect square - shouldered walk [he]4415-his would have looked like [an over - fed and over - dressed old man]4416-an over - fed and over - dressed old man . There were all sorts of rumours afloat about [Beaufort]230-beaufort . In the spring [he]4415-his had gone off on a long cruise to [the West Indies]131-the west indies in [[his]4415-his new steam - yacht]4417-his new steam - yacht , and it was reported that , at various points where [he]4415-his had touched , [a lady resembling [Miss Fanny Ring]349-miss fanny ring]4418-a lady resembling miss fanny ring had been seen in [[his]4415-his company]4419-his company . [The steam - yacht]4420-the steam - yacht , built in [the Clyde]132-the clyde , and fitted with [tiled bath - rooms]4421-tiled bath - rooms and other unheard - of luxuries , was said to have cost [him]4415-his half a million ; and the pearl necklace which [he]4415-his had presented to [[his]4415-his wife]572-his wife on [his]4415-his return was as magnificent as such expiatory offerings are apt to be . [Beaufort]230-beaufort 's fortune was substantial enough to stand the strain ; and yet the disquieting rumours persisted , not only in [Fifth Avenue]15-fifth avenue but in [Wall Street]133-wall street . [Some people]713-some people said [he]4415-his had speculated unfortunately in railways , others that [he]4415-his was being bled by [one of [the most insatiable members of [her]4424-one of the most insatiable members of her profession profession]4425-the most insatiable members of her profession]4424-one of the most insatiable members of her profession ; and to every report of threatened insolvency [Beaufort]230-beaufort replied by a fresh extravagance : the building of [a new row of orchid - houses]4426-a new row of orchid - houses , the purchase of a new string of [race - horses]4427-race - horses , or the addition of a new Meissonnier or Cabanel to [[his]4415-his picture - gallery]4428-his picture - gallery . [May Welland]218-mrs. welland was just coming out of [the tent]4368-the tent . In [her]218-mrs. welland white dress , with a pale green ribbon about the waist and a wreath of ivy on [her]218-mrs. welland hat , [she]218-mrs. welland had the same Diana - like aloofness as when [she]218-mrs. welland had entered [the Beaufort ball - room]4432-the beaufort ball - room on the night of [her]218-mrs. welland engagement . In the interval not a thought seemed to have passed behind [her]218-mrs. welland eyes or a feeling through [her]218-mrs. welland heart ; and though [[her]218-mrs. welland husband]663-her husband knew that [she]218-mrs. welland had the capacity for both [he]663-her husband marvelled afresh at the way in which experience dropped away from [her]218-mrs. welland . [She]218-mrs. welland had [her]218-mrs. welland bow and arrow in [her]218-mrs. welland hand , and placing [herself]218-mrs. welland on the chalk - mark traced on the turf [she]218-mrs. welland lifted the bow to [her]218-mrs. welland shoulder and took aim . The attitude was so full of a classic grace that a murmur of appreciation followed [her]218-mrs. welland appearance , and [Archer]430-archer felt the glow of proprietorship that so often cheated [him]430-archer into momentary well - being . [[Her]218-mrs. welland rivals]4434-her rivals -- [Mrs. Reggie Chivers]396-reggie chivers , [the Merry girls]4435-the merry girls , and [divers rosy Thorleys]227-the thorleys , [Dagonets]296-the dagonets and [Mingotts]226-the mingotts , stood behind [her]218-mrs. welland in a lovely anxious group , brown heads and golden bent above the scores , and pale muslins and flower - wreathed hats mingled in a tender rainbow . [All]4436-all were young and pretty , and bathed in summer bloom ; but [not one]4437-not one had the nymph - like ease of [[his]430-archer wife]572-his wife , when , with tense muscles and happy frown , [she]218-mrs. welland bent [her]218-mrs. welland soul upon some feat of strength .
